PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare: Abortions
PETITION.PARA: The Honourable President and members of the Senate assembled in Parliament. This petition of the below citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the Senate that we support the continued cover for all abortions on the Medicare schedule. We oppose any attempt to restrict access to the rebate under Medicare.

Medicare cannot pretend to be a universal health care system without providing a rebate for a termination of pregnancy. Those who will be hardest hit by proposals to restrict access to items 6469, 274 and 275 on the Medicare schedule are poorer and disadvantaged women who will not be able to meet the cost of a non-subsidised abortion.
Your petitioners humbly pray and request that the Senate will vote against any attempt to restrict access to abortion or any abortion-related items on the Medicare schedule.

PETITION.TITLE: Community Services and Health Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate. We, the undersigned registered medical practitioners of Australia, oppose changes to general medical practice contained in the Community Services and Health Legislation Amendment Act. We believe that:
There should not be two tiers of medical insurance rebates for General Practice.
Undergraduate training in general practice should be upgraded, and continuing medical education should be an independent activity controlled by the profession.
The mechanism for establishing the vocational register proposed in the Act is unacceptable.
Vocational training for general practice should be structured so that appropriate skills can be acquired in a reasonable and not an excessive time.
The present and proposed Medicare rebates for general practitioner services are inadequate.
Therefore we humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled will support the medical profession to achieve these resolutions.

PETITION.TITLE: Tasmania: VHF/UHF Transmission
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The petition of the undersigned residents of Tasmania respectfully showeth:
that the mountainous terrain and geography of Tasmania makes VHF television transmissions the most suitable for the State;
that more than 30,000 Tasmanians will have to purchase new television receivers and new antennae if commercial television in the State is forced to change from the VHF to the UHF band.

Your petitioners therefore request that the requirement by the Department of Transport and Communications to force Tasmania's two commercial television stations to change from the VHF to the UHF band by 1993 be immediately rescinded.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I table the explanatory memorandum and move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this Bill be now read a second time.

Mr President, the purpose of the Bill is to reduce the quorum of the Senate from one-third to one-quarter. Section 22 of the Constitution lays down that, unless the Parliament otherwise provides, the presence of at least one-third of the whole number of the senators shall be necessary to constitute a meeting of the Senate for the exercise of its powers. This Bill proposes that the number of senators required to form a quorum should be 19, rather than the 26 which are currently required.

There is little doubt that over the years there has been considerable growth in the demands on senators' available time outside their chamber responsibilities. First and foremost has been the dramatic growth in the Senate committee system. Most people accept that this has significantly increased the quality of Senate chamber scrutiny and, through that, the effectiveness of government. I remind senators that, by and large, Senate committees do not meet when the Senate itself is sitting, and that senators have to reserve substantial time outside sitting hours to fulfil their commitments to the various committees upon which they serve. This places concomitant pressure on the use of their time when the Senate is sitting.

I do not think that anyone would seriously suggest that all senators should be in attendance for every minute that the Senate is sitting. We have long accepted that there are many genuine demands on a senator's time which are quite a legitimate expression of the role of being a senator. The pairs system is a tangible illustration of such acceptance.

Ministers are heavily involved in the administration of their portfolios, and the tasks associated with representing in the Senate their colleagues in the House of Representatives. They have many calls on their time from Cabinet and Cabinet committee work. The Opposition front bench is similarly involved in the work of shadow cabinet, and other party office holders face like responsibilities. All senators must give up time to the demands of party and back bench committees.

In addition to this, senators face an ever increasing volume of correspondence for their attention, and must meet with a wide variety of delegations and visitors. It is now more than ever the case that they have statewide constituencies. It is important, therefore, that we ensure that senators can carry out these activities without frequent and unnecessary disruptions, and that they can plan their schedules with as much certainty as possible. Reducing the size of the quorum and, hopefully, the frequency with which quorums are called, is one way of so doing.

The proposal in this legislation is not designed to lessen the importance of the chamber. Attendance in the Senate and participation in its deliberations will still remain the most important role that senators perform. But it must be recognised that the quorum requirement does not of itself keep senators in the chamber. The standard of debate, the interest of senators in matters before the Senate, the level of importance or controversy-all these factors determine the attendance of senators. The quorum merely sets a minimum attendance level on the basis of what is thought to be a reasonable number of the total number of senators to take decisions on behalf of their fellows.

Altering the number of senators required to constitute a quorum will not affect the ability of any senator to call for a division of the Senate to decide a question. And the calling of a division, as we are all aware, invariably results in an attendance in the chamber substantially exceeding that required by the quorum provision. Section 22 of the Constitution envisaged that the quorum requirement could be subject to change in the light of senators' experience of the demands of their office. I believe that we have now arrived at the time when it is appropriate to make such a change.

The House of Representatives quorum was recently reduced from one-third to one-fifth. The Senate Select Committee on Legislation Procedures, in its report on 1 December 1988, found that, for the Senate, a quorum based on one-quarter of the senators-19 senators-seemed more reasonable than a quorum requiring the presence of only one-fifth. The Senate on Tuesday passed a resolution agreeing in principle to that recommendation of the Committee, and this Bill is designed to bring that recommendation into effect.

The acceptance of this proposal will result in a quorum requirement which compares favourably with those operating in other legislatures both within and outside Australia. It will in no way diminish the power of the Senate, but will, to the contrary, assist in improving the working environment of senators. I commend the Bill to the Senate

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed from 6 December.
TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT BILL (No. 5) 1989

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Page 1, clause 2, lines 8 and 9, leave out the clause, insert the following clause:
``2. (1) Subject to subsection (2) this Act commences on the day on which it receives the Royal Assent.
``(2) Subparagraph 78 (1) (a) (xcvi) of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 inserted by section 9 of this Act is to be taken to have come into effect on 10 November 1989.''.
(2) Page 5, clause 9, after proposed subparagraph 78 (1) (a) (xcv), add the following new subparagraph:
`` `(xcvi) the Nursing Mothers' Association of Australia;'.''.
The substantive amendment is to page 5, clause 9, which will add the following subparagraph:
`(xcvi) the Nursing Mothers' Association of Australia;'.

The first amendment is to have an addition to the Act to come into force on 10 December this year. The campaign to add the Nursing Mothers Association of Australia to the list of those associations that are granted tax deductability status has been running for quite some time. About six months ago I moved a motion in respect of this proposition which was defeated. The reasons that I set out at significant length on that day still stand. We are dealing with the second largest women's organisation in Australia and one which contributes-if one wants to put it in dollar terms-an extraordinarily large amount to the health and well-being of the Australian community. The Nursing Mothers Association of Australia has 1,700 counsellors in a very large number of local groups spread over the whole of Australia. The aim of the Association is to promote breastfeeding as being a desirable start to a baby's life.

Honourable senators will be very much aware that the trend and the feeling in years past have moved very strongly in favour of bottle-feeding. Medical evidence showed very clearly that the significant increases in children's diseases, particularly infections, were such that there was a problem with bottle-feeding. This is not only an Australian problem but a world wide problem. The World Health Organisation mounted a very strong campaign in recent years to try to reverse the trend with regard to bottle-feeding, particularly in Third World countries. In those countries the very large number of infant deaths was attributable directly to bottle-feeding, mainly because of the inability to sterilise the bottles and to weigh and prepare sterilised amounts of formula for bottle-feeding.

In Australia, while there would be very few cases of infection attributable to non-sterile bottle-feeding, undoubtedly the medical evidence is overwhelming that in a whole range of areas, breastfeeding is an extremely desirable healthy activity. In Australia it has led to a decreased mortality rate. There are long term health benefits, particularly in respect of the cardiovascular system, the digestive and respiratory functions and even, as suggested by the most recent material, brain functions. We can attribute quite clearly-quite a number of studies have done this in an incontrovertible way-enormous savings in the areas of hospitalisation, education and a whole range of other types of treatments. Not only does breastfeeding benefit babies, but recent studies have shown a decreased rate of breast and ovarian cancers in women who breastfeed. Since approximately one in 15 Australian women will contract breast cancer at some stage in their lives, the benefits of breastfeeding are clear.

This organisation is operating on its own funds, and provides a free service to Australian women. I suppose that I should declare my own interest in this matter in that my wife has been a long term member of the Association and a nursing mother's counsellor. So I am familiar with the enormous number of hours that these 1,700 women put in by counselling other women on the phone with regard to the first days, weeks and months of a baby's life. The Association's activities are not limited to the notion of breastfeeding. Given the way in which our society is structured in terms of the nuclear family and given that people in Australia move so often, as often as not, young women who have children do not have the support of their extended family. Whereas in the past in our society, almost every woman having a baby probably would have had a sister or some other near relative available to counsel her on the types of problems that she would meet in those early days and months, the types of difficulties and ways of overcoming them, that, now, is not available. When a baby has been crying, probably for hours on end, often enormous stress is placed on the woman. The ability to phone somebody, talk to that person about the problem and get reliable, factual, detailed information from somebody who is familiar with the difficulties and who has children and babies of her own, is of enormous comfort and help. I believe that it can be shown, quite correctly, to assist in the reduction of violence against children and babies.

In these amendments we are simply looking to allow the Nursing Mothers Association, that saves the community such a very large amount of money, the ability to raise funds and to have a tax deductable status while doing so. A large number of groups have such a status. I think it would be very difficult for a considerable number of them to be able to show that they provide anywhere near the benefits that this Association gives to the community. There is always a cost involved in these exercises. Now that the Government has withdrawn its grant from this organisation-it was given $73,000 in the last grant-the Association is operating with a deficit in the current financial year and is seeking to move into a large fundraising activity to try to cover that amount of money.

In addition, the Lactation Resource Centre, which has been acknowledged as one of the best in the world, needs to be housed. An inventory, a library and training facilities need to be made available so that the centre can be of use. In doing that, the Association wants to get corporate and individual sponsorship. Undoubtedly, tax deductability in this situation will mean a far better response from the public. I believe that the type of funds that this Association needs to continue its very good work will be forthcoming.

Since I last moved this amendment, the campaign by the Nursing Mothers Association has been a very active one. The Association contacted its members and asked them to write to the Government and to their local members about this issue, drawing attention to the benefits that would be accrued through its having a tax deductable status for donations. Some 10,000 letters have been written by Association members on this matter in the last six months. In response to that, the Treasurer (Mr Keating) issued a statement last Sunday in which the Government reversed its previous stance, having now decided to amend the tax law. The Treasurer in the press release said:
The Government has decided to amend the income tax law to allow deductions for gifts to the value of $2 or more made on or after 10 November . . .

The first part of my amendment starts from 10 November so that it coincides with that statement, made last Sunday, by Mr Keating. I think that all the members of the Nursing Mothers Association welcome the Government's decision in this regard. Fortuitously, since this is the first opportunity to legislate with regard to this issue, this Bill, which probably would have been debated last week except for the pressure of business, was actually held over so that it is available for us to amend. I urge total support for this amendment. My understanding is that the Government intends now to look in detail at the list of associations that have tax deductability status. That is a good idea. Some of the points made in the debate last time this matter was before us are worth looking at. But in any review, undoubtedly, this Association would be either at the top or very near to the top of the list of organisations that deserve that type of support.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise not to speak against the amendments-indeed, the cause is most worthy and desirous of recognition-but to mention the lack of appropriateness of choosing the debate on the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5), a contentious Bill about massive changes to corporate and superannuation taxation, in which to move them. Only yesterday we had a more appropriate avenue, the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4), an omnibus Bill which dealt with a wide range of issues. Senator Macklin of the Australian Democrats is not correct when he says that this is the first occasion that he has had to bring his amendments forward. Yesterday was certainly an occasion when he could have brought them forward, and it would have been a more appropriate time to have done so.

SPEECH.PARA: These very worthy amendments have effectively taken away the cut and thrust of one of the most horrendous pieces of taxation legislation that has ever come before this place. Indeed, the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) this morning chose not to continue his remarks in the committee stage because he wanted the issue to lapse as conveniently as possible. But I am not prepared to allow it to lapse.

The Minister, in his response yesterday concerning a dialogue between the Commissioner for Taxation and certain outside bodies, mentioned that there must be an outcome to those sorts of discussions. That outcome must be seen by the Senate to be manifested in tangible ways. It must be reflected in changes to both the Income Tax Assessment Act and the Taxation Administration Act. The Government must then demonstrate to us its bona fides and those of the Commissioner of Taxation so as to give full effect to the concerns of such outside bodies as the Australian Society of Accountants, the Taxation Institute of Australia, the Chartered Institute of Accountants and others.

Earlier I raised the issue of the discretions of the Commissioner of Taxation under the Income Tax Assessment Act. They do not fit easily with self-assessment. Something has to be done about that in a tangible way. There has to be a mechanism by which it can be ensured that the internal arrangements within the Australian Taxation Office can cope with self-assessment and that those arrangements are fair and reasonable so far as taxpayers are concerned. We know that the Tax Commissioner is reviewing the question of an avenue, by means of a remission of interest payable where an assessment is amended, to encourage businesses subject to the new self-assessment arrangements to lodge requests ahead of their returns. That is fine, but we must go a lot further. This is just one of the myriad of areas that must be acknowledged and looked at.

The new ruling in this area masks a major problem with the new self-assessment program. Many tax practitioners believe that the Tax Office will be swamped with requests for rulings and will be unable to provide clarification within a reasonable period, thus leaving companies in the dark. With only a short time to go before the new mechanism is in place and no binding rulings as yet issued, companies have no guarantees of protection. Companies are likely to want to lodge requests for advice on any doubtful aspect as an insurance policy against paying both the interest penalty and the more severe culpability penalty which apply when a taxpayer withholds relevant information. The present legislation offers no protection for a company that makes a full and true disclosure of contentious issues in its tax return. Given that the Australian Taxation Office currently handles about 40,000 queries per annum from corporate entities and others, I ask what assurances can corporations receive from the Minister and from the Australian Taxation Office that this body has actually changed its structures in order to handle the mountain of queries that must surely eventuate from the introduction of self-assessment.

Further, there are a number of areas that need looking into. I note that the Government is not even listening to these questions, so we cannot expect a thorough response. Will the Government consider replacing the present system to provide options to the present harsh, unreasonable penalties which appear to apply in all circumstances? For instance, should a culpability penalty apply only in circumstances where there is no reasonable basis for the stance taken in the preparation of the return? Could not both the United States and the Canadian system of self-assessment be considered in the administration of penalties for so-called honest mistakes? There is a need for a taxpayer's right of appeal on a penalty, for example, where the penalty is less than 20 per cent of the tax imposed. We are looking at a new system of taxation, and the Government has changed only part of the system rather than the complete system as would be required in an open and democratic review.

In the name of open government, will the Minister advise the Committee of the recommended changes within the Australian Taxation Office to ensure that the system of self-assessment is fair and reasonable so far as taxpayers are concerned? In other words, will the Government table a copy of the minutes, or a portion or precis of those minutes, between the Australian Taxation Office and that selected group of so-called professional advisers that he has-we do not know who they are-that he referred to earlier when responding to similar legislation? The Minister is relying on this professional advice and making rulings on it when at the same time members of the profession are putting up their hands in horror and saying, `Yes, we like the thrust of it but, by cripes, you are killing the profession in the meantime and giving us a bad reputation'. There has to be a more open mechanism where these discussions can be put on the table of this chamber so that honourable senators know what is going on.

Under proposed new section 166a of the Bill, the current assessment notice for corporations will disappear as from next year. There are suggestions-they are only suggestions-from the Taxation Office that there will, however, be a form. Can the Minister advise the purpose and the likely contents of such a form and at what stage it will normally be issued? After all, we have legislation for self-assessment before us but no proper mechanisms so that people know where they are going and what rights they have. There is an uneasiness about the extensive use of discretionary power under the legislation. The question that must be asked is whether, under self-assessment, this discretionary power should be minimised or replaced with specific legislative enactments to ensure absolute certainty. Absolute certainty is associated with full disclosure because the penalties for failure are so horrendous. There needs to be proper and appropriate protection. What sort of government do we have here? Do we have a dictatorship which forces things down people's necks, giving them no right of appeal, and with no justice in the system? There must be justice. I hope that this chamber is the last bastion of justice in this country.

With subsequent administrative changes to both the Taxation Administration Act and the Income Tax Assessment Act, today's legislative changes put excessive discretion and decision-making power in the hands of bureaucrats rather than with the legislature. Merely saying that the Government is having discussions with some advisory group or another tends to diminish communication with this Parliament. It is up to the Minister to re-establish an appropriate communication to tell the people of Australia what is going on. He should not have discussions behind closed doors and issue, at a later date, legislation that is not appropriate to protect the rights of ordinary decent citizens.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before we continue our consideration of the Bill, I point out that the Committee is taking the Bill as a whole. Senator Macklin has moved two amendments. I think that it would help orderly debate if we cleared those amendments first.

TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to address some remarks and questions to the Minister under clause 1 of the Bill, the short title, because they are of a general nature and can therefore be best treated under that clause. As Senator Watson has very properly pointed out, this Bill is an extremely important Bill. The Bill when initially announced by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) in the Budget Speech on 15 August, purported to change quite dramatically the timing of payment of company tax by all companies except those with a tax liability of less than $1,000, which roughly speaking means companies with an income of less than $2,500, to cause all such companies to pay their income tax in respect of the previous income year very much earlier than previously. As the subsequent furore has very clearly demonstrated, that had the most horrific consequences for all companies, particularly small businesses. We all know that the Government does not worry much, or does not seem to worry much, about small businesses. It continually attacks them in one way or another. Nevertheless, that proposal would have had very significant consequences for them.

SPEECH.PARA: My first question to the Minister is: why did the Government originally announce this legislation incorporating a major change of this kind without any prior consultation with industry? I can understand that there are occasions when governments do have to announce measures without prior consultation because to consult in advance may lead to the possibility of leaks, insider information and so on, which could have certain market consequences; therefore it would not be proper for government under those circumstances to undertake a consultation process. But no such arguments obtained in this case. This is a general change in the timing of tax provisions. I suppose one could say that, if the Government had consulted and word had got out, there could have been a fall on the stock exchange generally in terms of the impact of such changes on company profits and so on. But I regard that as a rather thin argument, if that is the kind of argument that the Government will advance. Why was there no consultation?

My second question is: given the palpable stupidity-I do not apologise in this context for using that word-of setting that initial threshold of $1,000 tax liability, which is roughly equivalent to a taxable income of $2,500, for companies and other related funds, et cetera to which the Bill is applicable, why did the Government originally propose a threshold of that kind in the Budget Speech?

TALK.START.PARA: —Of what kind-$1,000?

—Yes. That is my second question. The Minister does not have to take it from me that it was a stupid threshold; the Government subsequently admitted it. On 2 November the Government backed off the $1,000 threshold and substituted a $20,000 tax liability threshold, which is roughly speaking equivalent to a taxable income of $50,000 per annum. I simply ask: Why did it take the Government 2 3/4 months to arrive at such an obvious conclusion-that the original $1,000 threshold was wrong? Why did it not arrive at that conclusion in the first place? One reason, which I suppose is implicit in my first question, is that it did not consult anybody. My third question is: did the Government simply fail to understand the effects of such a measure on small companies?

SPEECH.PARA: My next question is: when the Government did start beating a retreat on its budgetary pronouncement through its statement on 2 November-that was its first retreat-why did it confine the exemption at that time to a threshold of company tax liability of less than $20,000? That would cover basically sole proprietorship-and not a very well-to-do sole proprietorship-because any sole proprietor business with a taxable income of more than roughly $50,000 would be over the threshold anyway. In other words, the Government's first retreat on 2 November still left the great majority of small businesses, including a lot of sole proprietors, exposed.

I make that point not merely because I want the Minister to answer the questions that I have asked, but also because it is important to note, as was noted in the second reading debate, that the $20,000 threshold still remains there for the future, apart from the so-called transitional year of 1990-91. So my questions about the applicability or suitability of a threshold of tax liability of only $20,000 still remain valid, under the Government's proposal under this Bill, for years after the next transitional year. I think the Australian Democrats will move an amendment on that, which we will no doubt debate in due course when we come to clause 36 of the Bill. I will reserve my remarks on the Democrats' amendment until that time.

Finally, the Opposition announced on the morning of 22 November that it proposed to move an amendment in the House of Representatives to increase the $20,000 threshold to $80,000, I think-in other words, to quadruple it-which is the equivalent of a taxable income of roughly $200,000. Only then, later that afternoon, did the Government panic and put out what one might call its final position, or its position as finally reflected in this Bill. It went one better, so to speak-I do not object to that-and produced an even larger threshold of $400,000 tax liability, which is roughly equivalent to a taxable income of $1m. So hurried was that response by the Government to the Opposition's move earlier on the same day that in the Minister's statement he did not even include at that time an estimate of the revenue effects of the measure. That has since been rectified, as the Minister correctly pointed out yesterday morning, in the newly circulated explanatory memorandum. But, at the time, the Government was in such haste that it could not even put out a revenue estimate accompanying the change. I ask the Minister whether I am right in my belief, supported by that string of evidence, that what we have seen in this Bill is a catalogue of ill thought out, hastily conceived, hastily executed and inadequate-and I would almost say, unworthy-proposals.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to Senator Stone's last question is: I do not believe so. To forestall Senator Watson getting excited again, the questions that he raised are not relevant to the clauses of the Bill that are under consideration right now. Therefore, I will not deal with them right now; I will deal with them later. In response to Senator Stone, the underlying purpose of this section of the Bill is to put incorporated enterprises on a more comparable and equal basis, in respect of the timing of the payment of their tax liabilities, to the great majority of taxpayers-that is, pay as you earn taxpayers. I am sure that Senator Stone understands that. Therefore, on those grounds, I do not believe that there is any in principle reason for exempting from the provisions of the Bill any incorporated enterprise at all, including what is virtually a sole proprietorship.

SPEECH.PARA: As is often the case with tax legislation, judgments are made about the point at which the financial effects of dragging a large number of people under the coverage of a particular change are worth the additional administrative costs entailed for both the Australian Taxation Office and the people concerned. That is always a judgment. I do not think this is the first time that governments have changed the judgments they initially made about what is an appropriate cut-off point. I do not think the Treasurer, or anyone else, would claim that the cut-off point which the Government has now proposed is an infallible judgment. Therefore, people such as Senator Stone can dispute it and say that it should be something else. They may be right or they may be wrong. But somebody has to make a judgment about what figures actually get written into the legislation such as this and that is the prerogative of the Government, subject to it getting the legislation through the Parliament.

Senator Stone criticised the Government for not consulting the accounting profession prior to announcing the legislation. That is probably true; there was no consultation. But Senator Stone cannot have it both ways in saying, as he does, that the Bill will have catastrophic consequences for some businesses and also that it is so insignificant and trivial that there was no valid security bar on prior discussion with people within the accounting profession or with some businesses. In other words, if the position is really as catastrophic as Senator Stone claims it will be for at least some businesses, there are advantages available to people who have prior knowledge of the possibility of legislation. Senator Stone cannot have it both ways.

I was asked why the Government took so long-from, I think, Budget night to 22 November-to change the figure that was originally announced by the Treasurer (Mr Keating). Senator Stone might as well have asked me, `How long is a piece of string?'. Senator Stone implicitly says that the Government is incredibly stupid to have taken two months to announce that change. I could put a question to the Opposition like this: Given that the Opposition bases its capital gains policy on a presumption that that policy will change saving and investment behaviour in the right way, why is the Opposition so stupid as to fail to realise that behaviour cannot be changed retrospectively? It not only proposes to bring in legislation which makes an heroic assumption to underpin it; it also intends to make it retrospective. Behaviour cannot be changed retrospectively. I do not want to have a debate about that now. Senator Stone asked why the Government was so stupid that it took two months to change its mind about something. I might as well ask the Opposition why it is so stupid that it embraces a piece of legislation, or proposes a policy to be enacted, that is so stupid that it does not recognise that behaviour cannot be changed retrospectively. The last point I make is that we are indulging in another second reading debate rather than what is properly committee stage consideration. I hope we will not continue to do that for too much longer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stone Sen J.O.

TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —As to the Minister's closing comment, I can assure him that there is no intention on the part of the Opposition to prolong these matters. The Minister would acknowledge that this is a very big and highly complex Bill. It is simply not possible for any speaker, including me, to cover in the course of a 30-minute second reading speech all matters which one would wish to address. I am taking advantage of the fact that we are now dealing with clause 1 of the Bill in committee to take up one or two additional points-one or two only-which I think bear further scrutiny. I ask the Minister to maintain his patience while we continue and conclude that process.

SPEECH.PARA: I am glad the Minister said that he was not proposing to debate the Opposition's capital gains tax. I am sure you would rule him out of order if we were to do so, Mr Temporary Chairman. We will debate that next year when the legislation repealing the capital gains tax is brought before the Parliament by the new Government. I do not want to be diverted further by the Minister in that way.

Before I come to my second point, I want to say in response to the Minister's remarks that I have not made any claim that the Bill, as now constituted, will have catastrophic effects-I think that was the Minister's claim-because it has now been very considerably corrected. Indeed, as the press statement by the then Acting Treasurer on 22 November made clear, the Government's proposals, so far as they concern the transitional year at any rate, which was the immediate concern, will effectively exempt from the application of the Bill 98 per cent of companies. We would accept that if only 2 per cent of the companies are left to be affected by the Bill in that time one could hardly claim, and I have certainly made no such claim, that it will produce a catastrophe. The only companies that will be left, by definition, will be rather large companies.

TALK.START.PARA: —Large companies are in trouble too.

—Yes, I will accept that. Nevertheless, we are concerned here with small companies. I know that the Government is always concerned with big business but the Opposition concerns itself with small business, particularly. What I did say, in talking about the question of consultation, was that I saw no reason why the Government could not have consulted because I do not believe there were any such market sensitivities in relation to this matter. Had there been, they could have been resolved immediately by the Government making an announcement that it was consulting, thereby informing everybody. The whole point about markets is that, as long as one has a level playing field so far as information is concerned, there can be no question of people being placed in privileged positions by the consultation process. I do not accept what the Minister said about that. I think, on reflection, he will agree-I hope he would-that perhaps he was a little intemperate in that part of his remarks.

SPEECH.PARA: I will leave that matter there and come to another aspect I wish to raise under this clause of the Bill-the revenue or the financial impact. When these proposals were initially announced in the Budget Speech it was said that they would result in dragging forward-these are not quite the words of the Treasurer (Mr Keating), but they have this impact-into 1989-90 some $885m of revenue on a one-off basis and that in 1990-91 they would have an ongoing effect of saving $330m in public debt interest. That is because of the bringing forward of the time within the financial year at which company tax payments would have to be made, thereby relieving the normal Budget arrangements whereby the Budget is in deficit in the first six to nine months of the year and temporary financing-the issue of treasury notes or, in previous days, government bonds-has to be undertaken and interest costs are incurred by the Government in that process.

The Government says that in the initial financial estimate, because company payments would be made earlier in the year it would have to borrow less in the early months of the financial year than it had previously and that would relieve it of those temporary financing costs to the extent of a saving of $330m a year. I say that by way of background before going to the point I want to make because it is quite a complicated matter. From discussion with people outside I know that not everybody understands that sort of public debt interest saving point.

As I said before, when the Government beat its first retreat on this matter by announcing the initial increase in the threshold from $1,000 tax liability to $20,000 tax liability it announced that there would be very little loss in revenue gain this financial year. Again that is rather a puzzle to many people but it is actually perfectly logical because most of that revenue gain this year comes from so-called early balancing companies-that is, companies which balance not later than 31 May. The biggest of those companies is none other than Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd, which balances on 31 May and which pays a very large amount of tax. Under the provisions of this Bill and the final Bill it will have to pay twice this financial year. It will have to pay 85 per cent of its tax liability before this financial year closes.

The reason the Government has amended the 15-day rule to the 28-day rule is to allow the transactions from 31 May balancing companies still to come within this financial year. Otherwise the Government would have lost the cosmetic benefit to the Budget of ripping $850m of revenue this financial year. It is purely cosmetic-one of the sleight of hand things that the Treasurer is renowned for and is so good at.

I want to speak more about the public debt interest estimate. In the 2 November statement the Government estimated that the public debt interest saving would now be reduced from $330m a year to $150m a year. I see an adviser shaking his head but I think I am correct that that was a statement made at the time. However, I am puzzled by one matter. I think Senator Short raised this in the second reading debate but did not get any response-although, to be fair, the Minister perhaps was not called on to make a response at that time. Senator Short pointed out that the revised explanatory memorandum, now based on the Government's final position of 22 November-not 2 November-still contains a somewhat reduced estimate for the revenue gain this year, which has now been reduced to $855m. That is a further loss of $25m from the position of 2 November. We accept and do not challenge that. It has to do with the fact that the Government has not made much difference to at least the big early balancing companies. But the estimate in the explanatory memorandum still has a revenue gain of only $150m in 1990-91 instead of the original $330m.

TALK.START.PARA: —A revenue gain or a PDI saving?

—It is actually the same thing but the explanatory memorandum says that it is `estimated to produced a revenue gain' of $855m in 1989-90 and $150m in 1990-91. I agree with the Minister when he says it is a public debt interest saving. In fact, it is not a revenue gain at all and so should be placed on the other side of the Budget. It is an outlay saving, not a revenue gain. But I will not take a point on the looseness of the language; it is just a technical oversight or slip. But I cannot explain-and I hope the Minister will explain to me-why the significant change between 2 November and 22 November has produced no apparent change in the estimate of the public debt interest saving.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The officials have just confirmed that Senator Stone has misunderstood the reference to $150m. That is the effect in the next financial year of companies being obliged to pay their tax liability on the day on which their assessment is lodged rather than 28 days afterwards. The amount of $880m or whatever it was in the Budget figure to be brought forward for this year is a one-off figure. On the revenue side there is an additional one-off figure of $150m in the next financial year because the companies will be obliged to pay on the day the returns are lodged.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Stone raised some other matters. Other than to take account of the various relatively small changes that have been made, the Government has not changed its estimates of either the revenue enhancement this year or the public debt interest (PDI) savings flowing therefrom. I think the following is an exhaustive list. This year there is a $25m cost to revenue of the transitional provisions for companies with taxable incomes of up to $1m or thereabouts. The amendment which the Australian Democrats intend to move-to increase the limit for exempt companies from $20,000 to $80,000 tax liability-would cost an estimated $2m in revenue. The Government's decision announced last month, to increase the limit from $1,000 to $20,000 would be ongoing, not one-off, and would cost, at the outside, $5m, and probably somewhat less than that.

Apart from those three matters, the revenue and PDI estimates that were put out in the Budget remain the Government's estimates. Like all such estimates, they will probably be shown to be wrong in the end. Indeed, it would be quite amazing if they were shown to be precisely right. But we have not seen any reason to change them.

TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not detain the Committee for much longer on this matter. I thank the Minister for Finance for clarifying the explanatory memorandum's reference to the $150m figure. It is true that I-and Senator Short in his remarks yesterday-misunderstood that figure and thought it referred to the public debt interest saving. I am glad to have that clarification. It raises the question as to why the explanatory memorandum makes no reference to the public debt interest saving, unlike the Budget Speech. If I understood him correctly, the Minister has now said that the estimate has not changed, although I find that very difficult to understand.
—Other than the changes of the $25m.

—The $25m is the saving because this financial year the Government will not get quite so much from the early balancing companies. As I understand it; there is no argument about that. But I am puzzled by another claim by the Minister, or the officials beside him, that there will be a very significant change in the timing of payments, from 15 days after balance date to 28 days after balance date for all companies between the day the Budget was brought down and 22 November, the date of introduction of the Bill into the Parliament. For a very great number of companies there will also be an extension of time to pay. According to the advisers and the Minister, this will not make any difference at all to the speed with which revenue is received into the Treasury and therefore the extent to which the Treasury is required to call on temporary financing, with the interest costs of doing so. I hope that I have not misrepresented the Minister in recapitulating what I think he said. All I can say is that I do not understand how that can be. But I will not detain the Committee further on the point. I would be grateful if the Minister, out of charity, could perhaps let me have some explanation.
—Out of what?

—I know that that creates a certain amount of incredulity on the part of Senator Puplick. Nevertheless, I am prepared to concede to the Minister that he is a charitable person where these matters are concerned. I ask him whether he will be so good as to let us have a considered statement on the effects of the 22 November measure compared with the Budget on the public debt interest component saving.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot guarantee that but I think we should be able to get such a statement.

SPEECH.PARA: Clauses agreed to.
Clauses 8 to 35-by leave-taken together.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stone Sen J.O.

TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to raise a matter in relation to clause 8 of the Bill. There seems to be a good deal of confusion about this. As honourable senators would well recall, clause 8 of the Bill deals with tax-related expenses. This clause picks up what I call the Watson proposal, named after Senator Watson whose recent private member's Bill advanced the proposition which the Government has in effect accepted in this area of the Bill. I do not want to talk further about that as such. But I am sure that the Minister is aware that this has raised in the public arena the whole question of the deductability of interest on borrowings used to make payments of taxes. Yesterday's Australian Financial Review contained a report by Mr Barry Dunstan, who is a financial journalist of some repute. Mr Dunstan used to be the Finance Editor of the Melbourne Herald some years ago before he went to work for the Australian Financial Review. He is, therefore, not some cub reporter. Mr Dunstan has reported a statement by Mr Boucher in a manner which has left me, at any rate, more than a little confused. I have taken the trouble to get hold of Mr Boucher's press release dated 5 December, on which Mr Dunstan's report was apparently based. Although I think it is an attempt by the Commission of Taxation to clarify the public debate, I have to say that it still leaves me more than a little uncertain as to whether it totally does clarify it. I will come back to that.

SPEECH.PARA: Before I conclude my remarks on Mr Boucher's statement, I refer to the fact that this matter was touched upon in the press statement of the then Acting Treasurer, Mr Dawkins, on 22 November. I quote one short paragraph under the heading `Deductibility of Interest on Loans Used to Pay Company Tax' on page 3 of the press release. Mr Dawkins said:

Representations received on the company tax collection arrangements have also focussed on the issue of whether interest payments on loans taken out to finance income tax payments are deductible for tax purposes. In view of the submissions received from business organisations and tax professionals, this issue is being reviewed. The findings of the review will be announced in due course.

I want to make two comments about that. The first is that if there is no doubt about this matter, one wonders why these representations received should have given rise to the question and why the Minister should have seen it as necessary to include that paragraph in his press statement. The matter is clear either one way or the other: on the one hand, interest payments on loans taken out in order to pay company taxes are properly deductable as an expense of doing business, which I should have thought, on the face of it, they ought to be. If that is the case, I would have hoped that it could have been stated clearly at the time or simply been ignored. It would have been better to have it stated but the other course was available. If, on the other hand, they are not deductable, again I would have hoped that the Minister could have clearly stated that at the time. It would appear from the Minister's statement that there was genuine uncertainty. Otherwise, there would have been no need for the Minister to say `this issue is being reviewed'. So that is my first point, that there did appear on 22 November to be genuine uncertainty.

The second comment I want to make is that this is now 7 December-which is 15 days later-and, as far as I am aware, there has been no definitive statement from the Government giving us the outcome of that review. I have to ask: Why not? We are referring to a ministerial statement; not a statement by the Commissioner. Given the rather keen interest, shall I say, of the business community in whether such interest payments on loans used to pay company taxes are or are not deductable, I would have hoped that the Minister would have taken early steps to remove the uncertainty. But so far at least, the Treasurer (Mr Keating) has not seen fit to do that following his return from overseas. What we have had-if this is the response in lieu-is a statement from the Commissioner, who, of course, is perfectly appropriate; he administers the tax law and it is he, in the first instance at least, who would make such a ruling. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the Commissioner's press release of 5 December. It is a public document.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
COMMISSIONER SLAMS MISLEADING STATEMENTS
The Commissioner of Taxation, Mr Trevor Boucher, today criticised misleading media comments on the deductibility of interest paid on borrowings to pay income tax.

The comments arose in the context of the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5) 1989, which is now before the Parliament. it has been suggested that paragraph 69 (5) (c) in clause 8 of the Bill proposes to make such interest charges non-deductible.

``The proposed section 69 has no such effect,'' said Mr Boucher. ``All it does it give effect to the Budget measure to allow a deduction for expenses incurred by taxpayers in connection with the management or administration of their income tax affairs. Paragraph 69 (5) (c) is necessary to ensure that the payment of income tax and related financing costs is excluded from the operation of this section, and remains to be considered under the general deduction provision; section 51.''
Mr Boucher noted in this context the generally accepted view that interest charges on borrowings raised to pay income tax are non-deductible.

``But in real terms,'' he continued, ``there is no practical basis for disallowing deductions for interest on borrowings forming part of a general pool of business funds from which tax is paid. And nothing in the Bill changes that either.''
In making his comments the Commissioner also drew attention to the review of this aspect of income tax law which was announced by the Acting Treasurer on 22 November 1989.
CANBERRA
5 December 1989
Contact Officer: Bob Cousins

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Committee. The Commissioner began by saying that he criticised misleading media comments on the deductability of interest paid on borrowings to pay income tax. He goes on to say that proposed new section 69 (5) (c) in clause 8 has given rise to this debate and what he calls `misleading media comments'. He points out-and I do not wish to challenge this in any way:

SPEECH.PARA: Paragraph 69 (5) (c) is necessary to ensure that the payment of income tax and related financing costs is excluded from the operation of this section . . .
That is the section of the Bill relating to what I call the Watson amendment. That is fine; we have no quarrel with that. The press release then stated:
Mr Boucher noted in this context the generally accepted view-
underline those words `the generally accepted view'-
that interest charges on borrowings raised to pay income tax are non-deductible.

``But in real terms,'' he continued, ``there is no practical basis for disallowing deductions for interest on borrowings forming part of a general pool of business funds from which tax is paid. And nothing in the Bill changes that either.''

I agree with that-nothing in the Bill does change that. But I have to say with respect to Mr Boucher that his statement of 5 December leaves that uncertainty unresolved. He refers to `the generally accepted views that interest charges on borrowings raised to pay income tax are non-deductible'. He does not say that view is wrong; he does not controvert that view. He simply says:
. . . in real terms . . . there is no practical basis for disallowing deductions . . .

Of course, I would have to agree with that, in a sense, too. It is obvious when one thinks about it that a company which has working capital involving borrowings, overdraft, or other forms of borrowings on which it is paying interest in the normal course of events, it does not, so to speak, corral its income tax payment and say, `I can't exclude from by business expenses that part of the interest payments on my overdraft which relates to the payment of my income tax'. It could do that, no doubt, if the Commissioner had a ruling which required it to do so, but I would wager that there are no such procedures. As a matter of practical business operation that will not happen and the Commissioner, in effect, acknowledges that in the penultimate paragraph of his press statement.

I think that is rather unsatisfactory. The Commissioner has acknowledged a `generally accepted view' that interest charges on borrowings raised to pay income tax are non-deductable, but in the next breath, in the very next paragraph, he says that `in real terms there is no practical basis' for disallowing them. I suggest that it is high time that matter was cleared up and a clear ruling given including, if necessary-in fact, preferably-changes to the law. I would have hoped that that was exactly the process that the then Acting Treasurer, Mr Dawkins, had in mind when on 22 November he made a statement that the issue was being reviewed and that the findings of the review would be announced in due course.

I ask the Minister to tell us how far advanced the review is, whether we are to take it that the Commissioner's statement of 5 December represents the formal outcome of that review, whether we can expect something more in that regard-I would hope so-and whether he has any other comments to make in relation to my general comment that, even as discussed in the Commissioner's statement, that leaves the issue basically in abeyance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I noted the Minister's comments earlier that he did not want to have a full second reading debate at this stage. The Minister can prevent a repeat of the second reading debate in the committee stage by answering the points that were raised during the second reading debate. I intend to raise a couple of points that were brought out then and to which we have had no satisfactory answers. The two points relate to true and full disclosure and the extension beyond the four-year period on which the Commissioner can amend an assessment, whether by increasing or decreasing it. As honourable senators are well aware there has been provision for full disclosure in the tax Act for a long time. If a person has shown true and full disclosure an adjustment could be made later to the effect that he is not liable to pay heavy penalties.

SPEECH.PARA: As we move towards self-assessment and abridged tax returns, it may be a bit hard for a person to make a full disclosure; nevertheless, the disclosure may be truthful, to the best of his ability. Taxpayers will no longer be protected in that regard. In the case of the deductability or otherwise of an item, two answers could be given. The return could be contentious, and thus could be held over for three or four years. If a tax audit is conducted and an underpayment of tax is picked up, the person has to find not only the money to pay the tax but also the money to pay the penalty. The money to pay the tax may have been reinvested in the business. I believe that is an important point. There is no mechanism by which a person can ask for a spot assessment. I know that rulings can be asked for, but I think the Australian Taxation Office will be kept busy all year if rulings were asked for on every point. One has to ask: Does the ruling necessarily stick? As I said in my second reading stage speech, a commissioner may give an opinion this year, but a vastly different opinion may be given in four years time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Panizza, unless I am mistaken, you are not dealing with clauses 8 to 35.
—Yes, I am.
—Which clause are you dealing with?

—Clause 31. The other point I would like to raise to which we never got an answer relates to the extension of the four-year period in which the Commissioner can vary an assessment, by increasing or decreasing it. Previously the time limit was three years for true and full disclosure and six years where there was not full disclosure. The Commissioner, for some reason or other, can apply to the Federal Court to have the four-year period extended. I think it is reasonable for him to have that right, as long as it is not used when the Department has a backlog of cases to consider. It worries me that there is no provision-as far as I can see, unless someone can show me where it is-for the taxpayer to appear before the Federal Court and put his argument as to why that period should not be extended. These questions were posed during the second reading debate and have not been answered. I would like a response from the Minister.
—Mr Temporary Chairman--

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would rather deal with the things that have been raised already if Senator Watson does not mind, before everybody forgets what they are.
—I just wished to further the debate on the deductability of interest.
—Senator Stone has raised the deductability of interest. He used the term `generally accepted view'-
—That's the Commissioner's statement.

—That is taken from the Commissioner's press statement. It has been described to me as an interpretation of the law which, as far as I know, though, has never had the status of a formal ruling, but it has been the Commissioner's interpretation of the law that that is the case. It is a bit like wrestling with a column of smoke; it does not really mean anything, as the Commissioner's own statement in the second last paragraph suggested, because one cannot unscramble the egg. This is not the only example where it applies.

SPEECH.PARA: Interest costs for personal housing are certainly not deductable from taxable income. Somebody may buy a farm-it is probably applicable in other circumstances as well, and it is certainly applicable in this circumstance-which costs $500,000. There may be a house on the farm that is worth $50,000 in which the new owner lives. The new owner may borrow $250,000 to pay the $500,000 total purchase price and claim interest on that $250,000, as a tax deduction. That deduction is allowed. Implicitly the taxpayer says, `I bought the house with my own money and I borrowed the money to buy the land', even though it probably has a common title deed. That happens, and some of us have known for a long time that it happens. I do not know whether anything could or should be done about it. Deductions from income tax for interest paid on one's own house are unequivocally not deductable, but there are certain circumstances under which that principle or that law is effectively unenforceable. I think the same applies to the question of whether interest paid on money borrowed to pay tax is tax deductable. The Commissioner's press statement does not constitute the Government's response to the review, which I think Mr Dawkins announced on 22 November, and I am afraid that I cannot tell the honourable senator when there will be a formal response.

Senator Panizza asked me a couple of questions, firstly about whether the Commissioner will be seeking an extension of the four-year amendment period to five years, and secondly whether the same privileges would be available to an individual. I think that was the point of the honourable senator's question.

TALK.START.PARA: —I asked whether the Commissioner was going to the Federal Court to ask for an extension of the four-year period. From what I can see, the taxpayer does not have the right to put his case as to why that period should not be extended.

—My advice is that there is no strictly formalised legal right for taxpayers, but an informal legal opinion has been received by the Australian Taxation Office that a court would normally allow a person so affected that opportunity anyway. In other words, it is not under the specific provisions of this legislation but under a more nebulous concept of natural justice. So I do not think the honourable senator has anything to worry about.

SPEECH.PARA: I think the other question that Senator Panizza raised impinges somewhat on, or has some commonality with, the matters that Senator Watson raised earlier and focus on the fact that, under the provisions of this Bill, the assessment is made at the time the return is lodged; therefore, it is subject to immediate payment.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no assessment.

—It is a self-assessment. If a taxpayer seeks a ruling or an opinion from the Tax Office prior to that, and the Tax Office can respond in time, there is no problem. But the fact that the lodgment of the return is now virtually the same thing as the assessment and the liability to pay means that the Commissioner cannot consider-I think I made a similar point yesterday; indeed, there is a fair bit about this in my second reading speech-the request for information, for a ruling, or for a de facto ruling, if he does not get the request prior to the lodgment of the assessment. I do not think that is entirely soluble unless the taxpayer requests the Commissioner for advice prior to lodging the return.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to make a couple of other points. There may well be some problems in the administration of this-and I do not think there is anything unusual about that when taxation law is changed-but I do not believe that the problems will be as horrendous as Senator Watson's tone suggested. Senator Watson, Senator Stone and I are probably all old enough to remember when provisional tax was first introduced in 1951. Some extreme rhetoric was thrown around about that. The tax was likened to theft, confiscation and all that sort of thing and it was suggested that this was the sort of thing we would have expected if Hitler had won the war instead of losing it. It required non-pay-as-you-earn taxpayers to bring the timing of their tax liability closer into line with the timing of PAYE taxpayers, which is the same purpose that this part of the Bill has. Some of the people affected by those sorts of changes are always going to complain about them. But I guess that self-assessment is part of that as well. When self-assessment for individuals was introduced, I think in 1986, there were dire predictions of the unmanageable consequences of it. I do not think it was trouble-free, but I do not believe that the problems that arose were nearly as severe as the critics or commentators suggested. I believe that the same will happen in this case.

Senator Watson asked me to guarantee, to him and to the Opposition, that they will be satisfied with the outcome of the consultations which have already taken place and which the Commissioner has indicated will continue to take place. I cannot give him that sort of guarantee and I do not really think there is much point in talking about it any more. We will just have to wait for the outcome, and if Senator Watson is right, or is close to being right, he can belt the Government around the ears next year over it. But there is not really much we can do about it at this stage.

TALK.START.PARA: —I hope that that is not the end of the Minister's response to the dozen questions that I asked.
—Mr Temporary Chairman, I take a point of order. I understand that the Committee is presently dealing with clauses 8 to 35 of the Bill.
—Yes, that is right.

—To some extent people have been talking about clause 36. I want to talk about clause 36 in a moment too, but I think it would be more orderly if we disposed of clauses 8 to 35-as far as I am concerned, the Minister has made his response to them-and we can then get on with clause 36.

—I asked Senator Panizza to confirm whether he was speaking to these clauses and, as I understand it, Senator Walsh has responded to the matters raised by Senator Panizza. Do the matters that Senator Watson wants to raise fall inside clauses 8 to 35?

—Self-assessment covers more than just one clause in this Bill. The self-assessment part of it comes under the clauses we are looking at at present-clauses 8 to 35. True self-assessment can go on to clause 36. I hope that this debate will not be truncated again because of certain people's misunderstanding of what is contained in certain provisions. I wish to further this debate on this question of the deductability of interest to finance income tax payments. I ask the Minister for Finance to clarify not only his statements but also the press statement of the Commissioner of Taxation. It appears from that statement and from the Minister's response this morning that we have another example of what I would refer to as target specific taxation, which is quite reprehensible. It appears from the Minister's example and the Commissioner's press statement that those large companies that are drawing their lines of credit in such a way as to cover a multitude of transactions, including the raising of taxation, will be able to deduct the interest paid on those lines of credit. In essence, that is what the Minister has told us. However, if a person who owns a small business goes along to his bank manager at a point in time and raises money for the purpose of paying this tax, that is not tax deductable. I ask the Minister to clarify that point.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not attempt to clarify the statement of the Commissioner of Taxation; I will not try to read the Commissioner's mind. If the honourable senator wants to question him he will have to wait for a Senate Estimates committee, or something like that.
—That is a pretty unsatisfactory situation.

—I will not try to read the Commissioner's mind. But the Commissioner's statement draws attention to a fact that perhaps should have been recognised long ago. I gave the honourable senator another example-which I think was very clear-of where the letter of the law, in reality, often cannot be applied. There may be ways of making it applicable if there were extensive amendments. The current review may take account of this.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Watson mentioned small business. The usual line that comes from the Opposition is that every small business person is up to his neck in debt, but Senator Watson now proposes that few or none of them are in debt. Conceptually, I do not think it matters much whether they are in debt or credit. If someone who has a credit-an interest earning deposit-and no business debt gets a tax assessment which wipes out his cash deposit, he no longer earns interest on that. So on the other side of the coin, he is getting the equivalent of a tax deduction for his interest payments, that is, he is no longer being assessed for the interest that he is no longer receiving but that he would have been receiving if he had not had to pay his tax assessment. In both cases, and in almost every case that I can think of, the underlying reality is that it is unenforceable, regardless of what the law might be. That has been the case for a long time. Perhaps some government, decades ago, should have acknowledged this and decided whether it would explicitly acknowledge that the law is unenforceable and tried to make it enforceable. I find it difficult to see how one could do that without huge administrative problems and discretions, which normally the Opposition, and other people, do not like. I do not see any point, Senator Watson, in pursuing it further.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw the attention of the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) back to self-assessment. I am fully aware that, when one lodges a self-assessed tax return, that is the assessment. As the Minister said, one can get a ruling beforehand if there are any contentious issues. I totally agree with that, but unfortunately it takes a long time to get a ruling from the Australian Taxation Office. There are certain deadlines one has to meet when lodging a tax return if one does not want to receive a penalty. I will give an example of a case of a tax ruling that has taken a long time and, I believe, has not been resolved yet. It is to do with pre-harvest and post-harvest wheat payments. That case has been around since September in the Australian Wheat Board letter. There was one opinion. Then I believe that opinion changed and now it has changed again. So one can see the time that it takes to come up with a ruling.

SPEECH.PARA: Where there cannot be any other safety measures implemented which prevent those penalties being imposed-when there is a case of two answers on a contentious issue-one may be able to look at the idea of lodging a self-assessment return, subject to a Commissioner's ruling which has been asked for: not a Commissioner's ruling on the assessment lodged, but one that has been asked for before the assessment was lodged. One may be able to lodge an assessment subject to that. If the Commissioner's ruling goes in a way which it was not expected to, then one may have the right to amend one's assessment without incurring penalties.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I meant to say before-and it is relevant to what Senator Panizza said-that, if there is some claim for a deduction which a taxpayer believes will be allowed but which may not be, then ideally the taxpayer gets a ruling from the Australian Tax Office before lodging the return/assessment. It may not always happen, either because the taxpayer was too late in lodging the request or because the Tax Office cannot respond quickly enough. I believe that this is correct and, if it is not, I will ask the officials to tell me so. In such a situation the taxpayer lodges the return/assessment on the assumption that the taxpayer's interpretation of the particular claim for deduction is correct. If it is subsequently disallowed by the Commissioner, who then increases the assessment, he may impose interest on it for late payment, and impose a penalty. But the Commissioner also has the discretion to waive both. I would expect that in that sort of case that is precisely what the Commissioner would do.

SPEECH.PARA: I know that various members of the Opposition criticise the extent to which the Commissioner's discretion is available. While I can see some merit in that, it is often the best way to resolve those issues. If the Commissioner does something really outrageous there are other appeal mechanisms available, including the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, although some of us may have reservations about whether that should be used. I suspect that Senator Stone shares my views on that.

However, the Commissioner does have this discretion to waive penalties and interest in that sort of situation. On the other hand, if the taxpayer is just putting up try-ons or worse, the purpose of which is pretty clearly to defer the payment of the taxpayer's tax liability, I would expect the Commissioner to apply both interest for late payment and some sort of penalty. In those circumstances, I believe that the Commissioner should do so.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise another issue. What changes does the Australian Taxation Office intend to make for its internal arrangements or to provide extra resources to cope with the mountain of rulings that are going to be required as a result of self-assessment? I understand that there are something like 40,000 inquiries a year. There will certainly be a lot of rulings required and, given the problems that Senator Panizza has raised, a lot of those rulings will not be given until after the returns are lodged. What changes does the Commissioner intend to make and what additional resources does he intend to apply to ensure that those rulings are going to be given in time?
—I have just been told that the belief of the Australian Taxation Office is that it has sufficient resources to deal with this.
—It is not dealing with it now.

—I suppose that the definition of dealing with it is a bit subjective as well. Some people might expect a reply the next day, but no sensible person would. That is clearly ridiculous. Whether it is reasonable to expect a reply in two weeks or six weeks is probably a legitimate question. If the Tax Office believes that it has a need for extra resources to deal with this issue, the Commissioner has the option of redirecting existing resources within the Tax Office or making an application to the Government for extra resources. We would all be well advised to think about that if and when it happens.

—I go back to the question originally raised by Senator Stone and also addressed by Senator Watson-the question of interest being deductable. I would like to be a little more specific, because the answer that the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) seems to be giving is that it would be wise for all people who find themselves obliged to meet the new timetable for paying taxation to maintain a pool of borrowings so that they may be able to have deductable interest payable on moneys raised to pay that tax. What happens in the grey areas? What happens where there is a facility to raise funds but no funds are raised, and the borrowing of the funds or the drawing on that facility coincides with the need to make the tax payment? What happens where people clearly do go and raise loans which match the sums that they have to meet by way of taxation payments? Does that mean that there is one rule for some and one rule for others? When will there be a definite ruling so that people who are obliged to make those decisions can do so with a clear conscience?

—The hypothetical situation that Senator Bishop has put up, if I have understood it correctly, is: what happens to a company-it could also be an individual-which is neither in credit nor in debit and it gets its tax assessment, say $10,000, and it goes out and borrows $10,000? I suppose the number of people who would be in that exact position would be negligible anyway. But I think what the Commissioner is saying in the press statement is that the law really has been unenforceable. While not attempting to read the Commissioner's mind or speak on his behalf when I am not authorised to do so and, indeed, do not feel competent to do so, I think that what is being said in that press statement is that the interest paid on money borrowed to pay the tax liability would in one way or another become tax deductable. If Senator Bishop would like an answer from the Commissioner on the question she has put, I will ask the Treasurer (Mr Keating) to get a definitive letter from the Commissioner on that.

—With respect, it seems to me that the press statement that has been incorporated by Senator Stone seems to be, in the first paragraph, firstly an intimidation saying, `It would be better if you don't claim it', and then further down in the statement `If you do claim it, it will probably be okay'. Far from Senator Walsh, in his answer, covering the answer to my so-called hypothetical question, the situation could be that a corporation or an individual is in debt to the tune of, say, $100,000 and they get a requirement to make a payment requiring a borrowing of $20,000 and the Commissioner decides that that extra raising was very simply done for the purpose of meeting the taxation payment. Is it within his discretion to so do, or is he saying in that press statement that he simply will not do it? It seems to me that he is wanting to have a quid each way.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stone Sen J.O.

TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to reinforce what Senator Bishop has said. In effect, what she is doing is simply drawing out a further conclusion, and a very important conclusion, to the point I originally raised. I am sure the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) is correct when he says that in practice, probably, in most cases, the Commissioner of Taxation will not, shall I say, strike out as an expense an interest cost incurred by a taxpayer who actually borrows to pay his or her income tax; company tax in the case we are referring to, but income tax generally.

SPEECH.PARA: I hope the Minister will agree with my earlier comments that the situation we now seem to have, which is well distilled in the press statement that has now been incorporated in Hansard is totally unsatisfactory. On the one hand, the Commissioner refers to the `generally accepted view' that such interest costs are not properly deductable. He does not say that that general view is wrong. On the contrary, the clear implication is that it is a `generally accepted view' within the Tax Office as well, and if people actually come to the Commissioner and ask for a ruling, that is the generally accepted ruling they will get. But then the Commissioner goes on to say, in the immediately following paragraph-I am quoting from memory now-`In real terms the practical effects are as follows'-namely, that since money is fungible and one has borrowings for a multiplicity of purposes and interest payable on all of those borrowings, it is going to be difficult for the Commissioner to sort out those which are made for purposes of paying tax and those which are made for other purposes.
