That was the Minister's example about somebody buying a farm on which a dwelling house exists. I think he was right in what he said in that respect.

I just put it to the Minister that this is a pretty unsatisfactory state of affairs. Here I pick up a point which I think Senator Watson was making earlier-and I hope I am not misinterpreting his comments. I think he was saying that when this Bill becomes law companies will be required to self-assess but they will no longer have, under the new provisions, a course open to them of putting before the Commissioner a true and full disclosure of a doubt in their minds arising out of their own self-assessment processes, including the doubt in this area. I put it to the Minister: When this Bill is law, what if a company draws up its own assessment of its income tax liability for the year in question, but in the year in question it actually paid its income tax for the past year and did so on the basis of having made some borrowings and incurred some interest as a consequence? Does it include that interest as an expense or does it exclude it? Let us assume that it includes it. Under the present provisions, it would, I presume, say to the Commissioner, `We have included this interest cost but we are not absolutely sure that that is the way the law stands. Therefore, we bring it to your attention that we have included it so that if you rule otherwise, you can exclude it'. That would protect the company from any penalty if the Commissioner did in fact vary its own assessment.

The problem, which we will come to in more detail when we get to clause 36 in a formal sense, is that the new provision does not allow for that kind of protective process on the part of the taxpayer. The example we are talking about now, which is the consequences in that regard of the continuing uncertainty as to whether or not interest payments on borrowings which are in practice used to pay income tax bills is deductable, is one of the uncertainties against the taxation consequences of which a taxpayer can no longer protect himself in terms of the new section 36. So I hope the Minister will understand that there is a genuine problem. I am not expecting him to be able to solve the problem today in the Committee, but it would be nice if he acknowledged that the problem exists, and if he were to tell us that, in his opinion at least, he will be advising the Treasurer that the problem does exist and that he ought to get it settled.

It is no good the Minister saying that, on the one hand, the Commissioner has a generally accepted view of the law but, on the other hand, he does not enforce the law. That is rather like saying, `We could have in this country a uniform speed limit of 30 kilometres an hour applying throughout the whole country, but that nobody would enforce it because it would be a stupid law to have; but we should not worry about it on that consequence because nobody would enforce it'. That simply brings the law-in the case of speed limits in that analogy-into contempt. I suggest that if we have a `generally accepted view' of the law, to quote the Commissioner, which says that interest costs in respect of borrowings made to pay income tax payments are not deductable, but that he is never going to enforce it or will do so very rarely, that also brings the tax law into contempt. I think that is undesirable.

TALK.START.PARA: —I reinforce what has been said by my colleagues Senator Watson, Senator Bishop and Senator Stone on this point. It is something I raised in my speech on the second reading. I am trying to make the point to the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) that all the points that have been raised here are of very great significance. But we have added this complication of introducing the self-assessment system and, consequently, setting up a situation where, as Senator Stone has just pointed out, there is no finality that can be established in favour of the taxpayer or otherwise. The problem is that there is a continuing in-limbo situation where there is no understanding of the final effect of the law and where the Commissioner of Taxation himself, according to his press release, is not prepared to say one way or the other what the law is. We think that is a very unsatisfactory situation which goes to the heart of the parliamentary debate on this piece of legislation. Quite frankly, unless we have a clear indication from the Minister as to what the law is intended to do and what it really means, why should Parliament support a law that is so faulty in its effect and its application and which clearly has not been explained properly by the Government?
—It has been doing it for the last 50-odd years.
—That doesn't make it right.

—I am glad that Senator Parer intervened to say that. The point is that the law as I have understood it to be applied allows deductions for interest in these circumstances on tax paid under the normal provisions of section 51 of the Act. I think it has been a general understanding in the accounting and legal professions for a long time, but now we have the comments of the Taxation Commissioner, as reported in his press statement yesterday, which raise serious doubts about that. The more important question I wish to add to Senator Stone's remarks is this: What is the intention of the Government in including in the Bill clause 8, which sets down a specific prohibition on deductions of interest in these cases? Does this have a retrospective effect? Does it apply because of the new self-assessment provisions? Is it intended that it apply to all taxation paid by corporations or is it only to apply to that corporation tax which is incurred as a result of the application of the new collection system? What is the Government's intention in this regard? I think it has a bearing on how we understand what the Commissioner of Taxation is trying to say about the deductability of interest under section 51.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I hope we can wrap up this matter fairly soon. The point raised by Senator Messner I think is covered in the Commissioner's press release. This sleeping dog has been lying around for decades-I suspect probably since 1936.
—Why have a specific provision in there to prohibit it? That is the question. If it has been a sleeping dog, fair enough, but--

—I am amazed to hear Senator Watson say that, because implicit in that comment is the idea that, if there is a bit of a hole in the tax law somewhere and a few people in the know are exploiting it, then that is all right. There is a problem; the Government has acknowledged that there is a problem. I think it was the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, Mr Dawkins, whom Senator Stone has already quoted, who said on 22 November that there was a problem and that we were having a review. I think the Commissioner's press release acknowledges that there is a problem, but I do not think we should rush into hasty commitments about what will be done about it.

SPEECH.PARA: This is not a new problem. This problem was also applicable-although it may be more obvious now-in the days of a taxpayer putting in his or her own return and the Commissioner making the assessment. The treatment of interest paid on money borrowed to pay tax, like last year's tax, would depend on whether the taxpayer who submitted a tax return specified whether he or she had paid the $10,000 tax assessment six months ago. That applied before self-assessment. Senator Messner may be right in that it is perhaps more obvious now, but it did exist before. He can be sanctimonious about this Government's negligence and the present Commissioner's negligence and the negligence of every commissioner and every government for the last 50-odd years. It has become more obvious and we are reviewing it, but I repeat that I do not think we should rush to any hasty conclusions.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why pass it? Why include this provision in the Bill?

—It does not make the situation any worse than it has been for 50-odd years, and the Bill is important. I put this to Senator Messner: supposing there is a pay as you earn taxpayer who has some other income, who gets a tax assessment on that and who borrows money to pay the tax assessment and then claims the interest on that but, at the same time, pays off a housing mortgage or a portion of a housing mortgage. It seems to me that there is a need to be very careful in giving a precise, detailed response to this problem in case we open up other loopholes in the tax law. We have had stacks of examples over many decades where making a change somewhere to correct a perceived anomaly opens up loopholes elsewhere which lead to a bottom line which is worse.
—Practitioners have always separated it.

—If Senator Watson means that practitioners have always separated out money borrowed for the purpose of paying taxes, I am incredulous if that is true. I do not think that there is any point in going on with this. The Opposition may not be satisfied, but there is really no alternative other than to wait for the review.

—I wish to clarify the further point the Minister has now raised; that is the question of the Commissioner's press statement and its explanation as to why clause 8 is included in the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5) 1989. I am afraid that I have not seen that press statement; all I have seen are press reports of it, and that point was not mentioned. Is the Minister saying that clause 8 is included in the legislation so as to disallow, for tax purposes, a deduction of interest in respect of the new collection system or is it in respect of all taxation payments? I would like to have that on the record.
—I am advised that that clause applies to all taxpayers, not just corporate taxpayers.

—As I understand it, what the Minister is saying is that it applies to all taxpayers, whether individuals, trusts, superannuation funds, companies or whatever, therefore the logical conclusion is that this clause applies to all taxation payments, not just the new collections under the new proposals which are the subject of this Bill.
—My advice is that that is so, in so far as that clause is applicable. Of course, we should remember that there is section 51 of the Act as well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —This will be my last point on the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5) 1989. The Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) admitted that there has been a slight awakening of the sleeping dog. But in this case he has to admit that this Bill treats taxpayers differently in regard to their cash flow.

SPEECH.PARA: One can take the case of the average wheat grower in Australia who starts laying out expenditure around 1 April-coincidentally, just after the tax bill is due to be paid, which is generally 31 March. That is the time at which the wheat grower will normally commence to go into debt. The highest point of debt, or the lowest state of one's finances, is when seeding is finished; then, in August one sells the wool clip and the harvest then comes in in November; and the highest point of cash flow-the highest amount in the bank-is in December-January. Following that one starts paying expenses, including overdraft and that is when the tax bill comes in-while one is still in credit. One pays the tax bill but by doing so, in theory, one's bank account is run down to almost zero. That year is finished, another one starts and one starts borrowing again.

I believe that such a taxpayer can legitimately claim every cent that he has paid in interest. He has paid tax out of his farm income and borrows later so that he still has a cash flow to plant the new crop. That is vastly different from the case of people who have an average cash flow, whereby money keeps flowing in as it is flowing out. Such a taxpayer has to borrow when there is suddenly a lump sum tax bill to pay, and obviously cannot claim the interest. The point I am making is that in this legislation that distinction is not drawn, and such taxpayers should not be treated in the same way.

TALK.START.PARA: —Given the admission that the Australian Taxation Office has no trouble in handling the present requests for income tax rulings, and the Minister's statement this morning that it does not anticipate any great increase and expects to be able to cope with the new self-assessment procedure and the rulings that will follow from that procedure, how long does it take for an average ruling to be given from the time it is received in the Taxation Office to the time it is sent back to the taxpayer?
—I do not know-I am sure nobody will be amazed at that-and the officials do not know, either. I will try to get a response for Senator Watson in the not too distant future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K. .

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to ask the Minister a question following his answer to Senator Messner concerning the application of the new section 69 to all tax transactions and tax-related matters. One should read clause 8 and clause 50 together. Clause 50 states:

SPEECH.PARA: Nothing in section 170 of the Principal Act prevents the amendments of an assessment made before the commencement of this section for the purpose of giving effect to this Act.

TALK.START.PARA: —Sorry; what are you referring to?

—I am talking about reading clause 8 and clause 50 of the Bill together; the fact that, hitherto, we have been discussing the predicament of a taxpayer who has to raise funds in order to meet the taxes which he will have to meet sooner, in accordance with this Bill; and the analogies that the Minister has drawn, which were illustrations of the second of the paragraphs referred to by Senator Stone in the Commissioner's press release, that is, that one cannot unscramble the omelette.

SPEECH.PARA: It seems, by reading these two clauses together, that there is an intention to unscramble the omelette and do so retrospectively. Indeed, the Minister's answer to Senator Messner's question as to just exactly what the new section 69 applies to perhaps renders all previous assessments liable to be reopened, with regard to moneys raised, to be examined to see what component of those moneys raised might have attracted tax to be paid at the time.

TALK.START.PARA: —My advice is that the overriding section about interest payments is section 51. There are matters for interpretation, but there is no amendment to section 51 in this Bill.

—Will the Minister take on notice a request to provide a step-by-step catalogue of how the Commissioner intends to assist the taxpayer to ensure there is absolute certainty in the preparation of his return and his understanding of the Act associated with self-assessment? What steps does the Commissioner or the Government intend to take to amend the Act to change internal procedures to ensure that these grey areas are removed because they cannot be tolerated in a system of self-assessment? As far as the taxpayer is concerned, he must be spot-on at the time he lodges his return. Could the Minister catalogue the items and the areas which he intends to change-either by legislation, internal procedures or taxation rulings-to ensure that there is a greater element of certainty to enable the taxpayer to prepare his return in the knowledge that he understands the law completely?
—I cannot answer that question now, but I will certainly take it on notice. It is a reasonable request.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to follow up Senator Bishop's question and the answer given by the Minister. I go back to some of the earlier remarks that he made in respect of whether there has been full and true disclosure of interest claimed as a deduction in respect of tax payments. Apart from clause 50 of this Bill to which Senator Bishop just referred, we should perhaps remind ourselves of the present procedures which the Commissioner for Taxation adopts for the amendment of assessments under the present law, which apply until this Bill is adopted.

SPEECH.PARA: Firstly, as I understand it, the Commissioner cannot attack an assessment where there has been full and true disclosure by the taxpayer of all the relevant facts and circumstances. Secondly, if there has been an innocent error by the taxpayer in claiming an expense, then there can be a reopening of the assessments by the Commissioner, going back three years. The third situation is where there has been fraud or evasion of taxation liability by a taxpayer. Of course, then the Commissioner has total power to reopen the assessments. Those are the three categories of circumstances which are set out in section 170 of the present Act.

This Bill seeks to change that by introducing a single test-that is, the return having been lodged, it is assumed that everything has not been cleared by the Commissioner and, therefore, he has a right under this Bill to go back and amend assessments for a period of up to four years in whatever circumstances. If there has been fraud or evasion, naturally the old principle applies-the Commissioner can open up the assessments as far back as he wishes to go. The changed situation applies to most companies. As the Minister has now pointed out, under clause 8 of the Bill this applies to all taxpayers, not just corporations. With the changes to the self-assessment system and the changes to the way in which the disclosure principles will apply, it seems to me that the effect of the law is that the Commissioner will now be able to attack the situation of any taxpayer where interest has been claimed in the past, up to four years, by virtue of the inclusion in this Bill of clause 8, which specifically denies deductions for interest payments in respect of taxation borrowings. That is the point which we are concerned about. Quite clearly, if the answer to the question that I am now raising with the Minister is yes, surely this is a backdoor method of reopening assessments for four years in respect of taxpayers in whatever category. By every stretch of imagination, it is something that would have to be regarded as an unintended consequence of the Government's Bill. I therefore seek the Minister's response to those points.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know whether Senator Messner was here, but I think I dealt with this matter about half an hour ago. The ideal situation is where, on any particular point which the taxpayer thinks there may be some doubt about, the Australian Taxation Office is approached early enough to get a ruling on it. I concede that that will not always happen. It may be that some assessments will be reopened by the Commissioner, presumably.
—For all taxpayers?
—No, not for all taxpayers-for some.
—You just admitted that it is for all taxpayers, individuals or companies.

—As I said before, I would expect the Commissioner, in circumstances where it is a marginal decision or a genuine error, to waive everything other than the payment of the tax once an assessment has been reopened. On the other hand, where there is a prima facie intention to get away with something a bit slick, I would expect the Commissioner to apply the penalty and interest. That is pretty well the way in which the system has operated in the past and the way in which it will operate in the future. We have spent more than two hours debating these amendments-and got what? Most of the points that have been raised are a re-run of a second reading debate. How much longer can it go on?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I just want to correct a feeling that may be prevalent in the Government's mind. We in the Opposition certainly are not against this system of full self-assessment. We acknowledge, and we have said, that it is a process which requires careful thought and certainly consultation with the taxpayers. In relation to this last part, and essential part, it has been acknowledged in all other systems that have changed to self-assessment that there has been this proper process of consultation. At best, we are told, it has occurred only partially. We have stressed that it requires this certainty and not reliance upon the Commissioner of Taxation, no matter how objectively he administers the law. All people who are associated with the administration of income tax should be aware-and we in the Opposition are aware-that self-assessment, properly administered, properly enacted, will greatly improve the efficiency of the administration and the collection of income tax.
—That is why we decided to go down that path three years ago.

—Yes. I thank the Minister for agreeing to catalogue for the Committee the processes by which this consultation will be achieved, and the way that it will be manifested to the people of Australia through taxation rulings, through changes to law or through other mechanisms. We and the profession understand that the Taxation Commissioner is reviewing the question of providing an avenue, by means of a remission of interest payable where an assessment is amended, to encourage people subject to the new self-assessment to try to lodge requests ahead of these returns. Can the Minister elaborate on how this will be achieved, given his previous statement that he did not think any changes to the present issuing of rulings would be necessary?

SPEECH.PARA: I would also like to raise another matter, to save me jumping up and down continually. With regard to the imposition of penalties, does the Government intend to go down the Canadian or the United States line, in that it will follow their system of penalties, particularly in situations of what have been referred to as honest mistakes? Is that the approach that the Commissioner intends to take in relation to the imposition of penalties under self-assessment?

TALK.START.PARA: —Sorry; I didn't hear the last part of the question. Can you repeat it, please?

—I think it is unreasonable that the taxpayer has not any idea of the basis, or even the philosophy, of the imposition of penalties under self-assessment. The Canadian system provides an avenue where there is some theoretical background as to how, and the circumstances in which, certain approaches will be taken by the Taxation Commissioner. Does the Commissioner intend to follow the Canadian example?
—I cannot specifically answer that, but I will guarantee to pass the question on to the Commissioner of Taxation. I think Senator Watson was quoting from the second reading speech.
—Where I asked you to respond.

—Yes. I understand from the officials that what is being considered-Senator Watson mentioned the line `by means of the remission of interest payable where an assessment is amended' under those circumstances where the taxpayer has lodged a request for a de facto ruling some time before-is a remission that is automatically granted, probably I suppose with the backing of legislation, if not legislation, then regulation anyway; whereas the Commissioner's discretion is exactly that: the Commissioner's discretion.

—I just wanted to ask the Minister whether or not he could tell us specifically what stage the review that we have referred to during the course of this debate and that was referred to in the press release cited has reached and when we might expect an outcome.

—I do not know. I mentioned this before when Senator Stone asked whether the Commissioner of Taxation's press statement of two days ago was the response. The answer is no; that is not the response. I am afraid I cannot tell Senator Bishop, or even give her a reasonably precise indication, of when it will be finished and conclusions announced.

—It has been suggested that there will be a form to replace, not necessarily by 100 per cent, the current assessment notice. Can the Minister advise us of the likely contents of such a form as it has been envisaged? At what stage would it normally be issued? If the Minister has trouble answering that question, he might like to take it on notice.
—I will take the question on notice. I am quite happy to do so if Senator Watson is satisfied with that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I return to the point that we were discussing, which Senator Bishop first raised in connection with clause 50 of the Bill. With respect to her question, the Minister responded-I think I have it right-that interest in respect of tax borrowings would be tax deductable under section 51 of the principal Act. Therefore, clause 50 of the Bill would have no effect in respect of those items which had been previously deducted and which may, by virtue of her argument, have been subject to the re-opening of assessments by the Commissioner of Taxation under the new amended provisions regarding self-assessment. I subsequently asked further questions about that, but I just want to be certain that I understand the Minister correctly.

SPEECH.PARA: Is it correct that, if clause 50 of this Bill is enacted, there is no possibility of assessments being raised under the new self-assessment procedures which are set down in the Bill in respect of interest claimed under section 69 for tax payments? I heard the Minister say that they would have been deductable not under clause 8 of this Bill but under section 51 of the Income Tax Assessment Act. Does the Minister see the point I am making? The Minister was saying, as I understand it, that because the interest has been claimed under section 51 there is no prospect of the assessments being re-opened.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not sure that I do understand Senator Messner. The advice that I have had before, which is still applicable, is that the last word on interest claims resides in section 51 of the existing Act. That is not affected by anything in this Bill. There is no amendment to section 51. Section 51 of the principal Act remains the last word on interest payments. I am now advised that the amendments to section 61 in clause 8 of this Bill apply only to expenditure made after 1 July 1989.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw the attention of the Minister to the Scrutiny of Bills Alert Digest No. 16, dated 22 November, in which the Scrutiny of Bills Committee states:

SPEECH.PARA: The effect of the amendment-
to an assessment-

is to authorise the Commissioner to amend determinations to decrease or increase an amount of credit for any reason within four years of the date of the original determination. The period was previously three years.

It is important to draw it to the Government's attention that the Committee regards a possible decrease of taxpayers' credit after four years rather than three as being one of considerable detriment to taxpayers. That view confirms, in a way, the general spirit of the points that the Liberal and National parties have been making during this debate as to exactly what the intention of the Government is in these amendments. Quite clearly on reading this Committee document, taxpayers are going to suffer a detriment. The Minister has just told me that clause 8 of the Bill will apply only from 1 July 1989, but there will still be some detriment because it will be possible for the Commissioner to re-open assessments back to at least 30 June 1989.

I believe that these points need to be made because it is not at all certain that we on this side of the chamber can conclude that this Bill does not have some ulterior purpose which has not yet been properly understood or divined by the Senate. As a result, I have to remain very much outside of those who would support this legislation because, quite apart from the general principles we have debated in the second reading stage about the new system of collection of corporate taxes, we now find that clause 8 will affect all taxpayers and not just corporations. That raises very significant questions about what the Government intends in respect of the self-assessment procedures as outlined in the Bill.

Similarly, Senator Bishop has raised her concern in respect of clause 50 of the Bill, which appears to have some retrospective effect. On top of all this, we have the very dubious press statement from the Commissioner of Taxation in respect of this situation, which entirely clouds the issue, as Senator Bishop pointed out, by taking a bob each way on the outcome. It is totally unsatisfactory for the Parliament to be asked to pass a Bill which is lacking in certainty. One of the prime principles of legislative practice, surely, is to ensure that the law has certainty. I believe that we in the Liberal and National parties have done our best this morning and this afternoon to draw out from the Government its intention in respect of these various clauses. But even the Minister would have to admit that there is very considerable doubt still remaining as to the exact effect of certain parts of the Bill which we have been discussing.

I think this Bill is a bad Bill. It ought to be opposed not just on the general grounds that we have raised at other times, but because it appears to have inherently faulty areas which are not consistent with the general understanding of the law. This opens very significantly the question as to whether we are putting into law a clause and a new principle which has not previously been accepted and which may very well have a retrospective effect.

Those things need more debate and more concentration of legal minds, in my view, before we proceed with this Bill. It is not in the best interests of the country that we proceed with this Bill until these questions are finally ironed out. I add that it is capable and competent for the Government to excise the relevant clauses of this Bill concerning self-assessment and clause 8, which covers the deductability of interest, without affecting the general thrust of its Budget measure, which was to provide for a new collection system for corporations. It has been made clear that the Bill has a wider effect: it does not just apply to corporations. It applies to individuals and other business entities. The Bill appears to go far further than was contemplated. As a result, it does not deserve the Opposition's support. I believe that the Government should act to remove those very questionable clauses from the Bill, with our support, and proceed with its Budget measure as it wishes.
Clauses agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have had a request that we now consider the remainder of the Bill. Is it the wish of the Committee to follow that course?
—That was done at the request of Senator Stone specifically and I would not want to undo that because he is not here at the moment to express an opinion-unless he has expressed one to his colleagues.
—Perhaps Senator Bishop can speak to clauses 43 and 49 by leave.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K. .

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-In speaking to clauses 43 and 49 of the Bill, I raise a matter brought to my attention by Senator Tambling, from the Northern Territory-a letter sent by Chief Minister Marshall Perron to the Treasurer (Mr Keating) concerning the superannuation contributions tax. I also refer to page 6 of the second reading speech presented by Minister Walsh. The first paragraph under the heading `Taxable contributions to superannuation funds' reads:

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill will also correct a technical deficiency in the superannuation tax provisions.

I presume that that is a euphemism for saying, `We got it wrong'. Marshall Perron's concern is this: he says in his letter to the Treasurer that he is writing to express his concern at the amendments being made, particularly to section 274 of the Income Tax Assessment Act, because of certain unintended consequences resulting from earlier amendments in June 1989. Mr Perron states:
In announcing the changes on 16 October 1989 you emphasised that these further amendments to Section 274 would not alter the intent of your original commitment outlined in a press release on . . .
The letter states `11 August 1988'. It continues:

At that time you stated that where a benefit paid by a concessionally taxed superannuation fund is financed by a one-off contribution from the employer when the employment ends, the fund, in conjunction with the employer, would be able to elect to have these payments treated as tax exempt contributions, with end benefits referable to such payments taxed at the 15/30 per cent scale (for retirement at age 55 or over). This provision, which was developed following consultation with the States and the Territory, is of particular importance to public sector schemes which provide employer-financed benefits on an unfunded basis.

Mr Perron states further that the amendments proposed in the Bill do not fully accord with the earlier commitment given by the Treasurer and do not suit the financial arrangements underpinning a number of public sector superannuation schemes. Specifically he states:

The proposed amendments appear to be predicated on the assumption that there will always be sufficient pre July 1988 unfunded liabilities to compensate for the removal of the exemption for the pre July 1983 component of benefits funded by `last minute' contributions. This is not a well founded proposition. The extent of pre July 1988 unfunded liabilities depends on the date a superannuation scheme commenced and whether any prior service is recognized for benefit purposes. Recently established schemes may have minor or no pre July 1988 unfunded liabilities although they may easily have members with a pre July 1983 component to their Eligible Service Period as a result of recognized employment prior to scheme membership or as a result of a rollover from another scheme. The blanket withdrawal of the tax exemption for the pre 1983 component of benefits is therefore considered inappropriate and unjustified, particularly, in the context of public sector schemes.
The final paragraph states:
I would urge you to review the amendments now before the Federal Parliament to ensure that they retain the full intention of your earlier commitment.

To the best of my knowledge, that letter has not been replied to. Will the Minister tell me what consideration has been given to the undertakings that were given by the Treasurer to the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory during the negotiations which took place between the Federal Government and the States and Territories?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am afraid that I know nothing about that letter. I will have to take the matter on notice.

SPEECH.PARA: Progress reported.

DEBATE.TITLE: MARINE NAVIGATION LEVY BILL 1989MARINE NAVIGATION LEVY COLLECTION BILL 1989

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 24 November, on motion by Senator Robert Ray:
That these Bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, the Senate is dealing with two companion Bills, the Marine Navigation Levy Bill 1989 and the Marine Navigation Levy Collection Bill 1989. The Opposition supports these Bills.

SPEECH.PARA: The Marine Navigation Levy Bill proposes to substitute a levy for the current light duties imposed on commercial ships, introduce a sliding scale of levy and transfer the authority to raise revenue from the Lighthouses Act 1911 to the levy Bill. Clause 3 of the Bill covers definitions, including the definitions for tonnage, necessary for the interpretation of clause 7 which deals with the amount of levy. The levy is to be imposed on commercial ships to fund the Commonwealth provision of navigational services and is covered by clause 6.

To date, light dues of 53c per net registered tonne per quarter have been imposed under the Lighthouses Act 1911. Under this Act, marine navigation aids are provided by the Commonwealth and are financed by their light dues. Since 1915 the light dues have been collected by the Australian Customs Service. At that stage they were levied at a rate of eight pence a net registered ton payable each three months. Clause 7 sets out the actual amount of levy to be paid. It has been calculated on a sliding scale following reference to the ship's tonnage. The scale is 63c for the first 5,000 tonnes; 53c for each tonne over 5,000 up to 20,000; 43c for 20,000 to 50,000 tonnes and 33c for each tonne over 50,000. As is clear from the scale, the levy reduces as the tonnage increases-the smaller vessels paying about 20 per cent more and larger vessels 20 per cent less. A vessel of 72,000 tonnes will pay $6,900 less per quarter and a 200-tonne coastal vessel will pay $20 more.

Since 1973 a system of cost recovery has been instituted. Prior to that the Government carried about 20 per cent of the cost which effectively represented a degree of assistance or subsidy to the industry. It also covered non-commercial users, such as the Government's own non-commercial ships, pleasure craft and the fishing industry. Under the new levy rate the above group remains excluded from the levy via the regulations, just as it was under the Lighthouses Act. Historically, light dues were based on earning capacity. Since 1983 the light dues have remained unchanged. The changes to the dues contained in this Bill have their origins in the Department of Transport and Communications investigation two years ago into a fairer way to institute cost recovery amongst those who benefited from the provision of navigational aids.

There are about 380 navigational aids around the coast of Australia which cost in the vicinity of $39m per year. Nearly one third of those are located in the Great Barrier Reef and Torres Strait areas. The cost of operating the aids has fallen over the past few years, mostly as a consequence of improved technology. With this in mind, clause 8 (2) provides that the rate cannot be increased by regulation more than 15 per cent per annum. I must comment that with the fall in maintenance costs I would have thought that a more realistic maximum level would have been in line with inflation, but perhaps this 15 per cent is a brief insight into what the Government thinks the inflation rate might be next year or the year after under its economic policies.

The companion Bill is the Marine Navigation Levy Collection Bill. The authority to raise the marine navigation levy was transferred from the Lighthouses Act 1911 to the levy Bill and this Bill to ensure that there were no constitutional problems following the High Court's decision on the Air Caledonie International case concerning the valid way of legislating to collect such levies and taxes. This Bill provides for the administration of the levy imposed by the levy Bill. The system itself, according to the Government, does not change with the transfer. The levy remains related to the commercial activity of the ship. The liability to pay the levy is covered by clause 6 and when the levy is payable, by clause 7. In terms of the payment, the levy is to be paid quarterly on the first day of each quarter for a regular coastal ship. Dependent on the circumstances, other ships are liable either on the day of arrival or the day of departure. Clause 7 (4) exempts ships from paying the levy when they call at an Australian port for shelter, repairs, to change crews or to seek medical assistance.

The power to make regulations is contained in clause 12. The items to be covered by regulation include those ships which are exempt for the purpose of clause 6 (1). These ships, which are exempt under the Lighthouses Act, will be the same and they include military ships, government ships other than those in commercial use, a ship under 24 metres in length and missionary and hospital ships.

I would just like to make the point that, according to the Government, this is one of the planks in the Government's reform of the waterfront-reform which I am sure you, Mr Deputy President, would agree is long overdue. Not long ago the Industries Assistance Commission (IAC) identified the fact that inefficiencies within our coastal shipping industries are costing the Australian economy up to $550m a year. Further, various investigations have estimated that the cost of coastal shipping is between 20 and 50 per cent above what it should be if the necessary reforms were instituted. The IAC in a report released recently noted:
Notwithstanding the important efficiency gains which should flow from the coastal shipping reforms, the nature and pace of change may be inadequate to address current inefficiencies.
It continued with a full appraisal of problems of the waterfront and in regard to coastal shipping it stated:
The inefficiencies of the waterfront and lack of competition in the provision of shipping services remain major impediments to a competitive Australian shipping industry.

I hope that the Government will turn its mind to the fundamental and very large cost penalties that are being imposed on Australian commerce and on the nation as a whole by the persistence with these gross inefficiencies on the waterfront. The Opposition supports these Bills and wishes then a speedy passage through the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very grateful to Senator MacGibbon for so succinctly putting the case for the passage of these Bills. He certainly convinced me and I will certainly support them. I believe that the whole chamber will be behind this package of legislation and I wish it a speedy passage.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a second time, and passed through their remaining stages without amendment or requests, or debate.
Sitting suspended from 12.56 to 2 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Leader of the Government in the Senate and Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce to his clarifying statement yesterday in which he tried to tidy up the bother he caused the Government with his honest comments at a news conference where he suggested that interest rates in Australia were likely to be higher than in the rest of the world until the end of the century. I ask the Minister to clarify that part of his clarifying statement in which he referred to the potential for interest rates to `fall substantially next year as a response to the current business cycle downturn' by telling the Senate, firstly, whether he is predicting that rates will fall next calendar year or next financial year; secondly, whether he believes, in line with his comments about the dismal 10-year outlook, that if they do come down they will most likely go up again some time later; and, thirdly, when the downturn is likely to occur and how long it is likely to last.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have repeatedly said in this chamber that I will not predict interest rate levels at any particular time. However, in terms of the current business cycle, as I have said on numerous occasions in the Senate, monetary policy will not be relaxed until such time as there is better control of demand in the Australian economy. I believe that the signals are such now that they are getting more persuasive than they were earlier. Last month we were talking about totally different signals being given by different indicators. In so far as the clarifying statement is concerned, it needs some clarifications even in the light of Senator Chaney's question. For example, Senator Chaney suggested that I said yesterday that interest rates would remain higher than interest rates in the rest of the world until the end of the century. I said no such thing. I quote from what I did say:

ANSWER.PARA: It is not going to be easy here in the next 5 or 10 years and I believe that relative to some other countries we will have relatively high interest rates for some time.

That is what I said. There were numerous reports of what I said, some accurate and some inaccurate. For example, the report in the Melbourne Sun News-Pictorial by a journalist who did not attend the press conference-and who did not even bother to look at the transcript, I would say-is extraordinary indeed.

TALK.START.PARA: —The 10-year hitch?

—Yes, that is right. I have just referred, for the benefit of clarifying Senator Chaney's understanding of it, to what I did say yesterday. It is not unusual, I suppose, to look at comparative periods of history. For example, throughout the 1970s interest rates in this country were relatively high compared to interest rates in some other countries, as I said yesterday. What I said yesterday was admirably summarised by my shadow ministerial counterpart this morning, Mr Howard, when he said:

ANSWER.PARA: I have said for a long time that interest rates are going to remain relatively high until we get on top of our overseas debt problem.
That is a very succinct summary of what I said yesterday. Mr Peacock, leading with his chin last night, sought to make some political capital out of this. Mr Howard said this morning:
Anybody who argues otherwise has no knowledge of the fundamentals of the Australian economy.
That is what we have been saying about Mr Peacock ever since he was appointed Leader of the Liberal Party, and I agree with that observation.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I note that the Minister is again being much more coy in the Senate than he chooses to be outside.
—You were more coy. You misrepresented me.
—The Minister can deny this quote if he wishes. He was reported this morning as having said:

QUESTION.PARA: But this does not mean that interest rates do not have the potential to fall substantially next year as a response to the current business cycle downturn.

Part of my question was to ask him what year he was talking about. Is he talking about the calendar year? Is he talking about the financial year? We are at least entitled to know what the statement he made yesterday means. I also ask whether interest rates will remain high until we get on top of our debt problem. In the Minister's view, does that confirm that for the next five or 10 years we will have a high interest rate regime in this country?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable senator is classically misquoting what I said and what I said in answer to his original question.
—Straight out of the Financial Review.
—I said:

ANSWER.PARA: . . . this does not mean that interest rates do not have the potential to fall . . . next year.
I said: `have the potential to fall'. What does that mean in the honourable senator's mind if he looks at the plain words of the English language?

TALK.START.PARA: —What year are you referring to?

—It does not matter-1990. I said `have the potential to fall next year'. They are pretty clear words. I am not saying that interest rates are going to fall. As I have said on numerous occasions in the Senate, when demand is sufficiently contained, monetary policy can be loosened, which will result in a fall in interest rates. That statement-`have the potential to fall next year'-is something which the honourable senator--
—Exactly what I read out.

—I know it is, but the honourable senator did not understand it, apparently. He is getting like his Leader-the Australian equivalent of President Reagan, who can mouth the words but not understand what they mean. That is what I said. In the second part of the question, Senator Chaney asked me whether interest rates in this country would be high for the rest of the century. I said that in the next five or 10 years they will be high relative to some other countries. That is a different point altogether.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Local Government. In light of the recent shocking events in Sydney and the apparent increase in attacks on elderly women, has anything been done to assist local councils in attempting to protect urban communities through planning and service delivery?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Local councils are very much aware of their responsibilities in regard to assisting and protecting their communities. They are involved in a wide range of planning and service delivery functions. Over recent years, many councils have increasingly become concerned about issues relating to crime prevention. While this obviously is seen as primarily a State and police matter, nevertheless councils have become aware of work that has gone on overseas and of ways in which in the local government sphere they, too, can become involved. Many councils have initiated and been involved in Neighbourhood Watch and safety house schemes. Under our local government development program this year, I was pleased to be able to fund a program which involves the Fairfield and Waverley councils in a pilot scheme to look at crime prevention in those urban areas. The work they are undertaking will provide a very useful guide to many other councils throughout the country which are concerned about crime, vandalism and other issues that are making many communities very unsafe, particularly for women but for all people.

ANSWER.PARA: In regard to the tragic series of attacks on elderly women in North Sydney recently, both Mosman and North Sydney councils are working to find ways to offer further protection to elderly women and to the communities generally. Mosman, as I am sure honourable senators will be aware from reports in the press, has offered escorts to elderly women so that they are not obliged to go out alone. North Sydney has taken the initiative of convening a meeting with senior citizens groups and they are working towards a major forum to look at this issue along with a number of other issues affecting elderly residents in the area. That will involve the police as well.

My office is currently working with both Mosman and North Sydney councils to produce a booklet aimed at providing practical ideas for women, councils and community organisations to bring together a range of measures which can offer greater security to women living or travelling alone. While the booklet which we are working on with those two councils will be particularly concerned with issues affecting the personal security of women, we believe that by bringing together a range of information and suggestions from councils around Australia the booklet will provide a great deal of information for everybody and, indeed, will offer protection to men and women-anybody who lives or travels alone. I look forward to the release of that booklet. It is a very important project and I commend North Sydney and Mosman councils on the work that they are trying to do.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister and Minister for Industrial Relations. I refer to the Minister's previous response to Senator Chaney in which he said that he thought the economic figures now were a good deal less strong than they were a month ago; I think he actually called them `very different signals'. Against that background I refer the Minister to today's Australian Bureau of Statistics figures showing very strong growth in full time employment last month, only slightly offset by a marginal decrease in part time employment-in other words, a very strong total employment growth-and also showing that the work force participation rate, that is, the propensity of people actually to take jobs, is at a record level. While increased employment is always welcome, I ask the Minister: First, how does he reconcile those figures with what he said a few moments ago in response to Senator Chaney; secondly, is the continuing strength of the labour market likely to delay interest rate relief even further?

—I saw those figures. Of course, employment is always a lagged indicator of economic activity. Employment starts to fall usually several months after demand, and it does not necessarily measure demand. Whereas many indicators such as retail turnover, for example, reflect demand pressures, the labour force figures also reflect increasing supply. If we in this country are to redress our balance of payments problems, we need to maintain production while reining in demand. I do not see anything particularly unusual in the November figures for employment being as they are.

—Mr President, I have a supplementary question. Is the Minister saying-and of course I note his linkage with the lag between falling demand on the one hand and rising employment on the other-that we are now already in that part of the business cycle in which productivity is already falling sharply? Is that likely to be the continued outlook for the months ahead?
—No, I am not saying that. While labour market figures are relevant to productivity, many other factors are too.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Has the Government congratulated the Dalai Lama on his receipt of the Nobel Peace Prize in Oslo on Sunday? What is the Government's current position regarding the problems in Tibet?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —When Mr Duffy was Acting Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade in my absence overseas, he sent a message of congratulations on behalf of the Australian Government when the Nobel Peace Prize award was announced. I am certainly happy to take this opportunity to add my own very sincere congratulations on this occasion. The Government considers that the award of the 1989 Nobel Peace Prize to the Dalai Lama was a very fitting recognition of his patient efforts to find a peaceful solution to the problem of Tibet.

ANSWER.PARA: The Australian Government's position on Tibet is well known. Australia acknowledges that Tibet is part of China; no country recognises Tibet as an independent state. At the same time, we consider it important that universally accepted standards of human rights are observed in Tibet, including the right of Tibetans to practise their cultural and religious traditions. We are particularly concerned about reports from Tibet of detention of people engaged in peaceful demonstrations, ill-treatment of prisoners and harsh sentences for dissidents. We have conveyed to the Chinese Government on a number of occasions our deep concern over the human rights situation in Tibet. Mr Hayden did so during his visit there some time ago. I have raised Australia's concerns with the Chinese Foreign Minister, Qian Qichen, on several occasions, most recently at the United Nations General Assembly in New York in October.

We have also made representations to the Chinese Government seeking the lifting of martial law in Lhasa and on behalf of Tibetan prisoners of conscience. We urge the Chinese Government and the Dalai Lama to continue efforts to establish a productive dialogue. It is clear that only this is the path to a genuine and lasting resolution of the Tibetan issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister representing the Minister for Veterans' Affairs seen a report in the New Scientist of 28 October 1989 entitled `New analysis links dioxin to cancer', which demonstrates the serious flaws in a study which was used by the Evatt Royal Commission on the Use and Effects of Chemical Agents on Australian Personnel in Vietnam as one of the major bases of its decision that Australian Vietnam veterans could not have been seriously affected by chemical defoliants used during the Vietnam war? Is the Minister further aware that the Ranch Hand study which was also used by the Evatt Royal Commission as a basis for its decision and recommendations has now been shown to have been seriously flawed? In view of this, in view of the vast bulk of scientific evidence which has emerged since the Evatt Royal Commission, and in view of the mishandling of information by the Evatt Royal Commission, will the Government reconsider its attitude to the findings of the Commission and give veterans and their families the benefit of the doubt if they have ill-health profiles consistent with the documented effects of exposure to agent orange?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator McLean for giving Mr Humphreys and me notice of the question. I am advised that the article in the New Scientist was about an explosion in 1953 in a chemical plant in West Germany. Although Justice Evatt considered studies of the effects of the explosion the article is not about the studies referred to in the Royal Commission report. The researcher referred to in the New Scientist article is disputing a 1985 report by a German industry association that is responsible for liability claims. Disputes over liability claims are to be expected.

ANSWER.PARA: The explosion was only one of several industrial accidents considered by the Evatt Royal Commission. The Commission studied reports on the 1953 explosion and many reports on other industrial accidents. Given that the discussion of the 1953 explosion occupied about six pages of the Royal Commission report, it is hard to see how this formed a major basis for Justice Evatt's conclusions. The Minister for Veterans' Affairs will investigate whether the new study is significant. However, the article is based on a paper presented at a symposium rather than a report published in a scientific journal and the matter could take some time to clarify.

Senator McLean also referred to the Ranch Hand study. This study was subjected to extensive review prior to its commencement. Nearly 100 government, academic and industry scientists have guided and contributed to the study. It is one of the authoritative studies on the possible health effects of phenoxy herbicides and dioxin. Recently developed blood tests have confirmed that Ranch Hand veterans had significant exposure to dioxin. In November 1988 the United States Congress made $3m available to the Ranch Hand study for the development of further blood testing. That is not the sort of commitment that is given to studies that are seriously flawed. Perhaps Senator McLean would like to take up these issues further directly with the Minister.

On the question of how Australian Vietnam veterans have been treated, the Minister would like to emphasise that the repatriation system is generous and the determining authorities are required to grant claims by Vietnam veterans unless they are satisfied beyond reasonable doubt that they have no relationship with Vietnam war service.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. In his statement Australia's Regional Security released yesterday, he stated in paragraph 4 of the introduction:

QUESTION.PARA: ``Protecting Australia's security'' means, in specifically military terms, having the capability to deter, and if necessary defeat, an aggressor . . .

He went on to define our own region as encompassing South East Asia, the South Pacific Forum countries and the eastern Indian Ocean. He then mentioned specific places-Myanmar and Indo-China, for example-as areas that coincide with the 1987 defence White Paper's identified region of primary strategic interest. A check of the defence White Paper reveals two zones: one of direct military interest, where Australia would expect to have capability of direct military action, as being Australia itself and proximate ocean areas including Indonesia, Papua New Guinea, New Zealand and other nearby countries of the south-west Pacific-constituting about 10 per cent of the Earth's surface; and a second wider zone of broader strategic interest to include South East Asia, Indo-China, the eastern Indian Ocean and the south-west Pacific-an area of approximately 20 per cent of the earth's surface. In relation to the first zone, Mr Beazley said, and I quote from the White Paper:
It required a force-in-being to defeat any challenge to our sovereignty--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. I thought Senator Vallentine was going to finish her quoting about 20 seconds ago and that I would let her go. But, really, it is an abuse of Question Time to put that amount of information. I think Senator Vallentine can assume that the Minister knows what was in the White Paper and she should just ask the question relating to it.
—I uphold the point of order. I think the question was far too long and was giving far too much information. I ask Senator Vallentine to ask her question.

—The question is: was paragraph 4 in the Minister's statement yesterday a deliberate lumping together of those two zones? Was this section cleared with, or written by, the Department of Defence? Does it signify a change in defence policy which would require a further massive increase in military capabilities to reach to the outer limits `of our own region', as he describes it in his statement?

—The area of primary strategic interest that I referred to in paragraph 4 of my statement yesterday coincides with the second and larger description in the defence White Paper. The areas are conterminous. I am not clear on what the fuss is about. There is some elaborate and complex conspiracy theory buried somewhere under the rhetoric of Senator Vallentine. I am afraid that I will have to wait for a supplementary question before I can determine what it is.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The point is that the Minister defined `our own region' as being an area where we would have specific military capability to deter and, if necessary, to defeat an aggressor. In the Minister's defence White Paper, the two zones clearly had different implications for defence capability. The first closer-in zone-the 10 per cent zone-was one where we would have direct military capability; the second was one where we would have an area of strategic interest and we would, of course, follow what was happening in the region, but that would not necessarily involve our having military capability to reach to the outer limits of that second zone.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —A glimmer of a light is beginning to come through the fog, Mr President. What Senator Vallentine is doing is mixing up a number of different considerations. In terms of referring to an ability to defeat an aggressor, what we are talking about is a capacity-and that is clear in the substance of the report later on, just as it is clear from the White Paper-to defeat an aggressor on Australian soil or within our maritime jurisdiction-the capacity to defer or defeat attacks on Australian territory in that sense.

ANSWER.PARA: The larger concept of security, which involves doing our best by the use of a variety of policy instruments, not just military ones but diplomatic ones and so on, means preserving, so far as we can, stability-positive security and strategic environment-in that larger region. It is in the latter sense that it is relevant to talk about the scope of this particular paper, just as it is relevant in that sense to talk, as the defence White Paper did, of an area of primary strategic interest. But that does not mean we are not talking about, or have any inclination to have, a capacity to exercise that military capability over the entire larger geographic area. That is a total confusion of two separate concepts.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Attorney-General concerned by the increasing tendency of political cartoonists to satirise senior members of the Government in the most unflattering way? Is he distressed, as I am sure most honourable senators are, at the particularly unfortunate reference in a cartoon in today's Australian Financial Review to the Leader of the Government in the Senate as `stumpy'?
—What do you reckon you are?

—That is why I am asking the question. I thank the honourable senator for his interjection. Can the Minister tell the Senate whether it is an offence under Commonwealth anti-discrimination legislation to mock a person on account of his or her physical stature-or lack of it? If so, what action will be taken and would the newspaper have a defence to any such action if it could establish that the Treasurer really does refer to Senator Button as `stumpy'?
—I think that there was one part of Senator Michael Baume's question that was in order; certainly not the part asking for the legal opinion.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, as I understand it, I cannot give that anyway in the Senate chamber. So the whole question is probably out of order. Quite clearly no-one would wish to interfere with the great skill and aptitude which Australian cartoonists have to portray us in our better and our worse moments. In fact, Australian cartoonists are, I think, universally recognised as being among the best, if not the leaders, in the world in their particular ability to caricature those of us who perform on the public stage. Naturally, we would prefer to have flattering rather than unflattering caricatures of our strengths and weaknesses.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the particular question of whether an offence has been committed in this particular instance, I think in these instances the best response is always to treat these matters with the humour which, I guess, the cartoonist was trying to engender in any case. I think there was a song that was popular a couple of years ago about short people, was there not? I cannot remember the name.

TALK.START.PARA: —Short People.

—Yes, Short People. I have a short memory for the song, or at least its title. I guess it is enjoying those sorts of songs and enjoying the cartoons that really enables us to deal with these differences between us as human beings.

—It is rather hard to ask a question after that last one from Senator Michael Baume. I am not as offended as he is about being ignored by the cartoonists. My question is directed to the Minister for Resources. Has his attention been drawn to reports of a statement by the Leader of the National Party which says that the Government has adopted a new quarantine policy which-I will quote it, because it would be unbelievable otherwise-`reverses the policy of the last 200 years'? Can the Minister advise honourable senators of the details of this new quarantine system and of the 200-year-old system to which Mr Blunt is so attached?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I saw in yesterday's Orange Central Western Daily newspaper a continuance of the campaign by Mr Blunt of shameless scaremongering in his untrue campaign to portray the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service as doing less than justice to the needs of this country. He said, or at least he was quoted as saying, in the newspaper, `We are relaxing quarantine standards in Australia'. That is just not true; we are not; we never have; we do not intend to. He said in the paper, `Changes to protocols'-he referred to fruit as being one of them-`places Australia at great risk'. This was said in a fruit growing area. He is obviously referring to fire blight and that is the context of the report. We have not signed a protocol on fire blight. For Mr Blunt to stump this country pretending we have is mischievous. He has said, as Senator McMullan has quoted in his question, that he supports essentially a no risk policy, that we have a minimum risk policy and that reverses the policy of the past 200 years.

ANSWER.PARA: Either Mr Blunt is deliberately misleading people or he just does not know what in fact the case is. There has never been a no risk policy in this country. There was never a no risk policy during those long Rip Van Winkle years in which the Liberal and National parties held government in this country. There was no policy of no risk then. There is no policy of no risk now. There is a minimum risk policy. To have a no risk policy would be to call the ocean surrounding Australia a moat, draw up the drawbridge, shoot anything that comes into our airspace or catch anything that comes into our waters. The only way that we could have no risk would be to admit no travellers and allow no interchange between Australia and any other country. That is entirely fallacious.

Mr Blunt, as a spokesman for a country party but with an urban base, obviously may not know what major rural organisations in Australia think. In 1988 the National Farmers Federation told the Lindsay quarantine review committee that it opposed a no risk policy because it would `prevent imports of necessary animal and plant material, disrupt trade and passenger traffic and encourage illegal traffic of potentially dangerous materials'.

I think the words from Mr Blunt in his continuing campaign as the Leader of the National Party have to be nailed once and for all. I have publicly warned Mr Blunt that if he continues this campaign he will bring Australia's exports into question by consuming countries overseas, and that will rebound badly on agricultural producers in this country. That remains the case. But it waxes odd and strange for Mr Blunt to make these allegations when, in the Economic Action Plan, the Opposition proposes to cut between $23m and $26m off the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service and at the same time trumpets that it will be more effective. The Quarantine and Inspection Service has been closely reviewed by this Government. It is a tight, lean and mean organisation that does not have any spare money. If the Opposition cuts $23m to $26m from its Budget it will be rendered ineffective and the quarantine protection that is available in Australia will be reduced.

Before I conclude my answer to Senator McMullan, I need to make one other comment. An article that appeared on 5 December this week in the Central Western Daily newspaper of Orange was headed `Fire blight big issue in the election'. Next to the article was a photograph of the Liberal candidate John Loneragan, with Ewen Cameron, David Hawker and Neil Andrew, saying that this was an election issue. I repeat in this chamber that the Government or the Quarantine Service has not signed any protocols about fire blight. To continue to try to turn this into an election issue is to promote the idea of the big lie.

This Government has published a discussion paper about how we could recognise areas in New Zealand which are free from disease, take imports from those areas and not use our quarantine laws as a non-tariff trade barrier. That is what we have done.

To turn that into an attack upon the Quarantine and Inspection Service is read in international newspapers by consumers of agricultural produce coming out of Australia in a way which is detrimental to our total trade effort. Yet, this John Loneragan, supported by the Liberal Party, intends to make this an election issue. If he does, it will be to the detriment of Australia. He is joined in that idiotic pursuit by Mrs Joanne Lewis, the National candidate for the seat, who is promoting this myth as well.

I conclude my answer by saying that the Quarantine and Inspection Service maintains an open stance, is available for consultation, acts according to the best technical advice and makes assessments after it has consulted with the affected organisations. We make those decisions so that the world trading community can see that we have a service that acts to protect Australia from exotic disease. It is not a non-tariff barrier. People who complain about greater competition should not complain that our wool is prevented from penetrating international markets, that our wheat equally is guarded against free market competition and that other rural products, including beef, are being so thwarted in free competition internationally. I think the conservative Opposition should pause, think about this campaign and stop it.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ROYAL AUSTRALIAN AIR FORCE: FLEET MAINTENANCE

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister representing the Minister for Defence will recall telling me on 28 November during the debate on the Appropriation Bills that the Minister for Defence had neither made nor announced a decision regarding a $20m contract for the maintenance of the Royal Australian Air Force's fleet of Hercules aircraft despite verbal advice on 20 November to Hawker de Havilland that the company's proposal to service the aircraft at its Townsville factory had been unsuccessful. Is the Minister aware that, in a facsimile message to Hawker de Havilland dated 24 October, the Department of Defence said that no debriefing would be conducted until a successful tenderer had been selected. Is the Minister aware that the company was verbally advised on 20 November by Miss D. Leak of the Department of Defence that Air New Zealand Ltd had been awarded the contract? That message was confirmed by fax. Is the Minister further aware that on 24 November a facsimile message from Miss Leak advised that the debriefing, which the Department said would not be held until after the selection of a tenderer, had been arranged for 4 December? Why, four days after the formal confirmation of the decision, did the Minister mislead the Senate by repeatedly claiming that no such decision had been reached or taken?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —As all honourable senators would appreciate, when one is representing a department that one does not administer, it would not be all that big a surprise that I have not read the faxes that might have gone between the Department of Defence, or some individual within it, and Hawker de Havilland. I relied upon the advice of officers who assured me that the company had not been advised of a decision and that the decision had not been made and, therefore, had not been announced. Certainly, I can reiterate that the decision had not been made then. That was checked that night with the Minister-there is no question about that. So, if an officer of the Department of Defence had advised, prior to an announcement being made, that the decision had been made, that officer would not have been correct. However, I find what Senator Boswell has said today alarming and I will make some further inquiries at the end of Question Time.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Can the Minister advise whether the contract has been let to Air New Zealand or not? He has been procrastinating over this over the last two weeks.

QUESTION.PARA: Senator Robert Ray interjecting-

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —I will resist all those temptations, Senator Ray. I am in a kind mode. On 28 November, which I think was the date Senator Boswell said he raised these matters in the Senate, I was able to confirm that up to that point no announcement had been made. I must confess that I have not inquired of the Minister as to whether or not an announcement has been made since but certainly I will let Senator Boswell know at the end of Question Time.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: DETENTION OF ILLEGAL IMMIGRANTS AS WITNESSES

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs inform the Senate what effects the decision of the High Court of Australia in the Park Oh Ho case will have?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —In the decision of the High Court in the Park Oh Ho case it was unanimously held that the detention of applicants was illegal. Custody was found to be unlawful for two reasons. The first was that the deportation orders were found to have been signed for an improper purpose, which was to maintain the prohibited non-citizen in custody to be a witness in a prosecution. Those deportation orders were therefore void from their inception. The Koreans were not deportees. The provision allowing for the custody of deportees could thus not be relied upon to authorise their detention. Secondly, custody pursuant to section 39 of the Immigration Act must be pending deportation. Custody for the purpose of keeping a person in Australia as a prosecution witness was found to be not pending deportation. On the other hand, the New South Wales Supreme Court has recently handed down a decision which stated that it would be a contempt of court to deport a person who was a witness subpoenaed to appear in a criminal prosecution. The court granted an injunction preventing the Department from executing the deportation order against that person.

ANSWER.PARA: These two decisions create difficulties for a departmental officer in cases where the deportee is a witness in a criminal prosecution and where there is a significant risk that that person will abscond. According to the Supreme Court decision, the department officers face the prospect of being held in contempt if they attempt deportation. However, according to the High Court, they also render the Commonwealth liable to civil claims for unlawful detention. Rather than maintaining custody, because of the risk of civil claims, the Department may be left with no choice but to release the deportee regardless of the risk of absconding.

The decision in the Park Oh Ho case has other implications. The possibility also exists that the Commonwealth may face actions for unlawful detention as a result of the deportation order subsequently being set aside by the Federal Court for other reasons, for example, for reasons of natural justice. In many cases it is appropriate to detain deportees prior to their deportation. It would be extremely difficult for custodial officers to predict whether, at some future time, the Federal Court may decide that an order is void. The Department also faces the dilemma that the custody, which was initially lawful as the purpose was pending deportation, may become unlawful if it is found that the purpose has changed. My Department is seeking further legal advice on these questions. It may be necessary to appeal the State Supreme Court case or amend the legislation in order to meet the legitimate State and Commonwealth needs.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications aware that in November Mr John Tusa, head of the British Broadcasting Corporation World Service, disclosed that its broadcasts to China in Mandarin were being deliberately jammed by the military authorities there? Are broadcasts by Radio Australia in Mandarin and Cantonese also subject to the same sort of interference? What, if anything, has been done to ensure that Radio Australia's broadcasts can be clearly heard in Beijing and Shanghai as well as in other parts of China?
—I will take that question on notice.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services aware of comments made by the New South Wales Minister for Health, Peter Collins-no relation-on the Australian Broadcasting Corporation PM program yesterday that Commonwealth officers may have been acting in a callous and cold-hearted manner in seeking to remove bodies from a cemetery in an effort to secure land required for the Badgerys Creek airport? These comments also prompted an extremely strong response on PM from the local parish priest. Can the Minister advise the Senate whether there is any truth in these allegations?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the statements made by Mr Peter Collins, which I have to characterise as being blatantly untrue. They in fact show the New South Wales Government's total lack of sensitivity on this issue in a crude attempt to score some political points. The acquisition of the three cemeteries within the airport site is being arranged as part of the Government's decision to acquire all properties within the airport's site boundaries.
