The first stage of the proposed airport development will not disturb the cemeteries located on the airport site. Development of the airport is proceeding in such a way as to avoid, as far as possible, intrusion into the cemeteries. However, the Catholic Church has nonetheless indicated that it wishes to move quickly to relocate the cemetery to a new site and has sought the Commonwealth's assistance to enable this to happen.

ANSWER.PARA: The parish priest, Father Evans, is of course concerned that the matter be treated with sensitivity. He has asked in particular that he handle all the discussions with relatives of the deceased and all necessary discussions and negotiations with the State Government. The Commonwealth has agreed to this request, accepting that he is better placed than anyone else to undertake these arrangements, given their personal, sensitive nature. Father Evans has indicated all along his desire to have the relocation take place with as little publicity as possible and is most concerned and annoyed that the New South Wales Government, through Mr Collins, appears to have ignored his wishes and instead has chosen to make a political issue of the matter. Father Evans has also expressed his appreciation for the sensitive way in which Commonwealth officials have dealt with the matter. Let me quote what he said on PM last night:

. . . they've been bending over backwards to be as understanding as possible, so much to the extent that in our agreement they've said that because I pastorally know the people and care for them, they've been quite happy to allow me to do the negotiations with the people.

In conclusion, in answer to Senator Collins's question about Mr Peter Collins, I think it is up to Mr Collins and the New South Wales Government to act in a little more dignified and compassionate way. The track record of the New South Wales Government is always to be the maverick, always to go to the press before it has proper negotiations with Ministers or anyone else. That is its style. Thank goodness it has only two years to go.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications. Following the recent revelations about the financial position of Aussat Pty Ltd, how does the Government justify maintaining a commitment to Aussat stage 2 when it is quite obvious that the demand for its satellite network is falling off? Does the Government agree that if Aussat and the Overseas Telecommunications Corporation (OTC) were amalgamated the potential losses in Aussat would be more than offset by the extension of Aussat's overseas market and a reduction in its capital costs? Where does the Government expect Aussat to find the millions of dollars needed to meet its increasing liabilities if telecommunications is not reformed in this way?

—Of course I am aware that the financial and regulatory positions of Aussat have been the subject of debate in a number of forums recently. However at this stage it is not fair to say that it is patently obvious that demand for the satellite is reducing.
—Aussat has lost Channel 10.
—Although there is speculation that one network is contemplating relocating its program distribution contract which is under review, I think it is premature--
—You have lost 10; that is known.
—Has that been announced?
—No, I have read it.

—Senator Alston has read that there is some speculation; what about curbing his racing hormones until such time as these things are in fact the subject of actual decision, which it is my understanding is not the case at the moment.
—I have read that as a statement.

—He has read it in the press, has he? That is presumably decisive then; that is good enough for Senator Alston. The Government is aware of Aussat's view that changes are needed in terms of both capitalisation and other areas of activity if it is to have a viable commercial future. As the Minister for Transport and Communications pointed out yesterday, the Government will review the structural relationship of the three carriers. That includes the ownership arrangements and the areas of activities which are currently designated for each of them. Such a review was foreshadowed at the time of my statement as Minister for Transport and Communications in May 1988. Part of the review would be an assessment of the likely future demand for satellite services in the light of whatever information is then properly to hand. The proposed amalgamation of Aussat and OTC is obviously one of a number of options that could be considered and no doubt it will be considered. The review in question will be completed by the middle of next year.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations aware that a $150m to $200m investment program by Mobil Oil Australia Ltd has been deferred and may be transferred to Singapore as a result of present and past industrial disruption at the company's Altona refinery in Victoria? Is he further aware that the 35-day-old strike at Altona, which we hope might be reaching a conclusion and which has already cost more than $10m in lost production and alternative purchases, is allegedly because of a risk from asbestos but that the site has been declared safe by State Government health inspectors? Is the Government concerned about the abuse of safety and health issues in industrial relations? Is the Minister aware that Mobil wants to reduce the number of unions at Altona from the current 14 to two or three in an effort to get a more sensible industrial relations climate? In view of the recent comments by the Treasurer about the desirability of reducing the number of unions per enterprise, what will the Government do to assist that process at Altona and in other areas?

—I think I answered a question about this a couple of weeks ago when Senator Chaney drew this dispute to my attention, I think at Question Time. I am aware that Mobil has announced its intention to postpone or defer the implementation of an investment decision until some time in the future because of this industrial dispute. Negotiations are taking place in Altona about this dispute; I know because I asked about it this morning. At present a very serious attempt is being made to resolve it.
—Common law proceedings?

—Yes. I am not able to make any judgment about whether there is an abuse of health and safety issues in any particular situation. If, as Senator Chaney says, the relevant Victorian Government authority has determined that it is a safe site, I hope that there will be no further abuse of that issue. One does not like abuse of issues or excuses in any industrial situation; that should not be done. Again, without knowing the details of the unions involved and so on, I, of course, support Mobil's objective to reduce the 14 unions on site to two or three unions, as any Minister in this Government would. I hope that this issue can be resolved as quickly as possible. That is commonsense. In most industrial sites, certainly most new industrial sites, agreements are being reached which provide for one union, or two unions at the most, on site. An alternative course is a place with a long industrial history, many different employers involved at that site and many different unions. The objective of reaching fewer unions is to be supported. I hope-I do not know-that that is a part of the negotiations which is being addressed positively by the trade unions.

—I thank the Minister for his reply. I wish to ask a supplementary question about the latter part of it in which the Minister said that he supports the objective of having fewer unions at workplaces. I think that objective would be broadly supported. I ask: is it not a fact that the existing legislative provisions for achieving that objective do not appear to be working? In light of the Treasurer's interest and the Leader of the Government in the Senate's interest in achieving this objective, which seems to be occurring only on new sites, as he said in his answer, does the Government have under consideration any legislative changes or other proposal which would facilitate achieving that highly desirable industrial objective?

—I do not want to be misinterpreted. I said that on new sites they had arrived at one union in many circumstances and that that was highly desirable. I did not wish to imply that on other sites progress has not been made in reducing the number of unions; in particular plants it has. I am unaware of whether there are any legislative proposals before the Government-they are not before me, clearly, as a member of the Government-or whether the Minister for Industrial Relations has any such proposals. I will try to find out and provide an answer to that part of the question.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. What is the assessment of the Australian Government of the degree of reform on human rights and other key questions in Romania-the only Eastern bloc country which appears to have resisted the process of renewal now sweeping eastern Europe? Does the Australian Government believe that Romania's Warsaw Pact partner, the Soviet Union, will take the view that the apparent lack of reforms in Romania is acceptable and sit idly by?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Government has certainly seen no evidence of an intention on the part of the Romanian authorities to institute the kind of fundamental reform that is now sweeping through the rest of eastern Europe, with the exception, I suppose, still of Albania. To the contrary, President Ceausescu recently confirmed that there would be no deviation from the kinds of what are, essentially, totalitarian policies that he has pursued to date. The Australian Government has been a consistent overt critic of the violations of human rights in Romania. The Government has conveyed these concerns on numerous occasions. Direct representations to the Romanian Government have been made by our Ambassador, who is based in Belgrade, to the Romanian Deputy Foreign Minister. In the United Nations Commission on Human Rights Australia recently co-sponsored the resolution which expressed concern at human rights abuses in Romania and appointed a special rapporteur to investigate the situation in Romania and, in particular, the campaign of forced assimilation of Romania's ethnic minorities.

ANSWER.PARA: This campaign increased in tempo in early 1988 with the decision to proceed with a program of so-called systematisation, calling for the demolition of over 7,000 villages to make way for so-called agro-industrial centres. Most of the villages affected are in Transylvania where the population is predominantly ethnic Hungarian. Australia shares Hungary's concerns over the Romanian Government's program of systematisation and the inherent human rights abuses that entails.

Coming to the last part of the question, the Soviet Union has also expressed concern at the situation in Romania but, in line with its commitment to allow the countries of eastern Europe to pursue their own policies, has not taken any direct action. We have no information or evidence to suggest that any such action might be imminent or likely.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. I refer to the meeting held between proponents of a lightweight coated paper mill at Boyer in Tasmania and the Minister, the Prime Minister and, I think, several of his other ministerial colleagues. I ask: As a result of this meeting, does the Government propose to make any further amendments to the Australian Heritage Commission Act to accommodate the concerns expressed by the proponents and by the industry in that meeting?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —I actually did not get to the meeting. I was in here on Estimates, I think, answering questions from Senator Michael Baume and Senator Newman. I missed the meeting, although I had seen Robert Bain a day earlier.
—We enjoyed your company.

—It was the thrill of the moment. I had a discussion with Mr Bain a few days earlier. The industry representatives had raised with me the problem that industry sees in being able to plan future investment. As they see it, there is a never ending increase to the National Estate and, that being the case, investment decisions for a lightweight coated paper mill are difficult. I indicated to Mr Bain-my understanding is that the Prime Minister indicated something similar-that I could understand the difficulty that industry was having. The best illustration of this is in the south-eastern forests of New South Wales. Senator Cook is going through the process of identifying prudent and feasible alternatives to logging in National Estate areas. Now we have discovered that there are some further nominations for areas which we were considering as prudent and feasible alternatives. If that process continues, obviously it will be difficult for Senator Cook to find any prudent and feasible alternatives.

ANSWER.PARA: In the south-eastern forests of New South Wales and Tasmania, there is a difficulty for industry in being able to plan proper decision-making. I do not favour, however, an amendment to legislation which would, in some way, impede the capacity of the Australian Heritage Commission to make a commitment on anything other than a scientific basis. If areas pass the scientific test, I do not believe that we should prevent their being entered on the Register. Rather, I think there needs to be from the Prime Minister, Senator Cook, me, Senator Button and whatever Ministers--

TALK.START.PARA: —And Mr Kerin.

—And Mr Kerin. We would need to make it very clear to Australia at large that just as the Salamanca agreement in Tasmania acknowledges that it is looking at the National Estate as it existed-I think it was a date in June of this year-certainly as far as resource decisions are concerned, we will not be able to find prudent and feasible alternatives if areas are continually added to the National Estate. That being the case, when it comes to forestry, we really are looking at those areas which are on the Register now.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for his answer. Is the Minister effectively confirming that he does not propose to recommend further changes to the Heritage Commission Act and that the arrangements which he will seek to put in place in order to secure some greater certainty for industry when making investment decisions will have to be done on a non-legislative basis?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —That is my view. I am not certain what the views of other Ministers are. I have not had an opportunity to canvass properly those views. The Prime Minister has indicated that he would like that done, but the Government will deal with it in the new year. My view is that it ought not to be handled by legislation. I think we have to make it clear that as far as the National Estate is concerned it does not mean a complete lock-up for ever. If every forest in Australia were listed on the National Estate, prudent and feasible alternatives would become an impossibility.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Resources. Is there any factual basis for the claims that the Federal Government policies are threatening the ability of mining and petroleum exploration companies to contribute to economic progress? Can the Minister advise honourable senators of Government policies which actually support the operations of these companies?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen a number of statements attributed to the Australian Mining Industry Council (AMIC) criticising the Government on several grounds. Inventively, AMIC has chosen Eureka Day, the anniversary of the insurrection at Ballarat with the Eureka Stockade, to act as a counterpoint to its announcements. This throws up very interesting mind images of major executives of leading mining houses in Australia identifying with raggedly and bearded miners at Ballarat. I do not know whether we should cast Hugh Morgan as Raffaello Carboni or Peter Lalor.

ANSWER.PARA: However, I understand that the motivation of the criticism of the Government is dissatisfaction with the Government's decision about Kakadu. But the criticism has gone much further than that. I applaud AMIC's commitment to the concept of sustainable development. But in arguing, as it does excessively, that areas of Australia are locked out of mining, it overstates its case quite dramatically. No more than five or 10 per cent of this country is closed off from mining and that is because of urban development, nature conservation and Army or Defence lands.

As well, AMIC criticises our economic policy in general terms. At least we have an economic policy to be criticised, unlike the Opposition. But the mining industry has been a massive beneficiary of deregulation, of structural adjustment, of the improved industrial relations climate, and of the micro-economic reform that the Hawke Government has instituted. Indeed, if we look at an index of mining performances we see that there has been a massive improvement in the export index for resources; massive improvements in foreign earnings for mineral exports; and company profits, comparing 1984-85 to 1989-90, have improved in the mining sector from $3,593m to $5,350m-an increase in 1988-89 of 14 per cent over the previous year.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday Senator Archer asked me a question about a directive issued by the Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) on the use of side-facing seats. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the answer that I now have.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Archer asked me a question on 6 December about a directive issued by the Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) regarding the use of side-facing seats and whether those used in the RAAF Hercules aircraft complied with that directive.
I have obtained the following information for Senator Archer.

In 1986 the CAA issued an airworthiness directive specifying that side facing seats must be fitted with a suitable occupant restraint system. This was in accordance with international practice and recognised that in the event of emergency deceleration or impact, occupants of these seats are at greater risk than occupants of forward or rear facing seats.
The restraint system would have to include features that protected occupants from the forces involved.

The recent amendment to that directive formalised an arrangement whereby, if the side-facing seat was not to be used during take-off or landing, a placard would be placed on the seat stating this prohibition. The owner would not then be faced with the cost of the upgraded restraint system. This covers the situation, for example, where the side-facing seat may be used only in flight as part of a lounge or sleeping arrangement.
RAAF aircraft are operated to military standards and are therefore not subject to the CAA directive.

Many of the Honourable Senators would have travelled in the RAAF Hercules recently and would know that the aircraft are fitted with seat belts, and that RAAF personnel take great care to ensure that each passenger's seat belt is securely fastened before the aircraft takes off.
As the CAA directive does not apply to the RAAF aircraft, there is no basis for the suggestion that there would be difficulties with insurance in the event of an accident.

While the Hercules aircraft obviously do not provide the level of comfort provided in airline aircraft, I am certain that there are a large number of people in the community, particularly those travelling for compassionate reasons, who are grateful to the RAAF for providing services during the disruption to the airline industry.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday Senator Calvert asked me a series of questions on the proposed air transport trials to Antarctica. I informed the Senate yesterday that the 1985 report, which had recommended against the use of air transport to the Antarctic, had investigated a different system from the one which is now proposed to be used. I can now confirm that. The 1985 report assessed a proposal based on the use of a compressed snow runway 25 kilometres inland from Casey. Last summer, a Royal Australian Air Force (RAAF) team inspected an area where it is possible to construct a combined ice and snow runway at a distance of about seven kilometres from Casey. This site has the advantage of allowing operational support from Casey. The RAAF team concluded, therefore, that air operations are feasible.

ANSWER.PARA: The United States of America decided to withdraw from the McMurdo-Casey flights for two reasons: first, the United States was concerned about the preparation of the skiway, which it felt was too rough and hard for ski-equipped aircraft-mind you, we are not proposing to use those-and, secondly, United States officials were unhappy that the flights were being used to carry people not directly involved in scientific research when the original purpose of the arrangement had been to provide mechanisms for short-term visits by scientists. In fact, politicians were the overwhelming percentage of passengers.

The cost of constructing a runway at Casey is estimated at $316,680. Given the proximity of the runway to Casey, the Casey doctor will provide medical services. Rescue services will be provided by the Casey search and rescue team. The 1985 report estimated that up to 30 per cent of flights might have to return due to deterioration of the weather after the flights commence. The Bureau of Meteorology advised that, on the basis of the procedures which it now proposes, the number of return flights due to a deterioration of the weather after a flight commences should be substantially less than 30 per cent and probably of the order of 10 per cent.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday Senator Tambling asked me a question concerning a party of Hong Kong travel agents visiting Kakadu. As I indicated yesterday, when one sets fees for Kakadu, Uluru, or anywhere else, they are expected to be met. The honourable senator will recall that, when it was decided to introduce park use fees at Kakadu at the commencement of this year, I reduced the fee to $5 per person from the $10 originally announced. In my media release of 18 November 1988 advising of this decision I indicated that the lower charges were aimed at softening the impact on the tourism industry. Given the relatively low park use fees charged and the magnificent attractions that Kakadu offers, it was not considered necessary at that time to provide for the waiver of these charges in special circumstances. Therefore, Professor Ovington, the Director of the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service (ANPWS), has no authority to waive the payment of charges which I have approved.

ANSWER.PARA: Regarding the recent visit by the party of Hong Kong travel agents, I am advised that the Darwin Tourist Promotion Association was able to give only a couple of days notice of the visit to the ANPWS. Professor Ovington was made aware of the visit and the request for waiver only the day before the visit. As there was inadequate time to refer the matter to me, the National Parks and Wildlife Service had no option but to advise that it could not agree to the request for waiver.

I recognise the present difficulties of the tourism industry in the Northern Territory and, naturally, I wish to assist in its recovery as much as possible. With this in mind I have asked the Director of the National Parks and Wildlife Service to make an assessment of the implications of waiving park use fees for bona fide travel agents on genuine familiarisation tours to Kakadu and Uluru national parks. In the light of this assessment I will make a decision on whether to authorise the Director to waive fees in such circumstances.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday I was asked a series of questions by Senator Short regarding the Buy Australian-Made campaign. I made some inquiries yesterday and I can inform the Senate that Senator Walsh, Mrs Kelly and the Prime Minister have never spoken to Bob Hogg or any other senior Labor figure about the awarding of the Australian-Made campaign to John Singleton Advertising Pty Ltd. I have their word. The Prime Minister has also assured me that he has never spoken to John Singleton about this contract at any time. Senator Short asked whether John Singleton had contacted the Prime Minister, members of the ministerial committee, or other mysterious Australian Labor Party members once he became aware that the evaluation committee had recommended against his agency and before he presented his revised submission to the ministerial committee.

ANSWER.PARA: My office contacted Mr Singleton yesterday to check the facts. He confirmed the statement that he had made on national television recently that he was totally unaware of what any evaluation committee had recommended until the matter was raised in the Senate last week. Appearing on the Today program with Senator Bishop on 29 November this year, John Singleton, when he was asked by Terry Willesee about the committee's recommendation, said:

Yeah I found yesterday that there was a committee who recommended, well I don't know whether it was unanimous, but they recommended the Luscombe campaign to the Ministers and the Ministers knocked it on the head.

I apologise to the Senate as I do not think I have done John Singleton's character justice. In relation to a supplementary question asked about some mysterious letter to `Neil' that appeared in the revised submission of John Singleton Advertising, there was a hint of some big conspiracy because it was sent on the Government Whip's facsimile machine. However, Senator Short's paranoia has got the better of him. The simple facts are that the letter of 21 May 1989 is from Mr Norm Spencer of the Advance Australia Foundation to Mr Neil O'Keefe, the Federal member for Burke. Neil O'Keefe contacted the Foundation in May seeking information on the success of the previous Australian-Made campaign. The reason he had done so was that he was moving a motion in Caucus the following week requesting the Government to renew the Australian-Made campaign and he wanted the information for that purpose.

In mid-August Neil O'Keefe appeared on Peter Couchman's television show praising the virtues of Australian-Made campaigns. He drew upon the information provided to him by Mr Spencer in that interview. Shortly after that program Mr Singleton rang Mr O'Keefe and asked for a copy of the figures Mr O'Keefe had used on the show about the success of the campaign. The figures were in the letter sent by Mr Spencer on 21 May and Mr O'Keefe saw no problem in forwarding John Singleton this information and subsequently faxed him the letter. He used the Government Whip's machine because his own machine was broken. At no stage did Mr Singleton attempt to solicit support from Mr O'Keefe for his campaign and at no stage did Mr O'Keefe ever raise this matter with any member of the ministerial committee. Those are the facts on this matter and I hope that Senator Short takes a few deep breaths and relaxes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson) in response to a Question without Notice asked by Senator Short on 6 December 1989, relating to the Buy Australian-Made Campaign.
I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 27 November 1989, Senator Sheil asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business, a question regarding Customs services on the Gold Coast. I have been provided with a response by Mr Jones which, because of the lengthy detail, I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard.

ANSWER.PARA: I will not be taking steps to reopen the customs office at Southport. Provision of quarantine services is a matter for consideration by my colleague the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy.

The decision to close the Gold Coast customs office in December 1988 was an administrative one, resulting from a review of all customs services to the Gold Coast region which indicated that operations could be better handled from Brisbane than the one-person Gold Coast office. Consideration for the needs of Customs' clients, both private and commercial, was foremost in the deliberations. It is a fact that the majority of customs matters at the Gold Coast have always been handled from Brisbane, and customs officers are always available to attend at the Gold Coast where personal attention is considered necessary. A toll-free 24 hour telephone service to the Brisbane customs office has been installed for local residents. The Collector of Customs for Queensland held discussions with interested organisations in the region, to explain the revised customs arrangements before the Gold Coast office was closed.
Concerning the particular allegation that the Gold Coast seaway is being used to import large quantities of drugs:

Such a claim was attributed to an officer of the Australian Federal Police Gold Coast Drugs Unit on the occasion of the opening of a new Australian Federal Police Gold Coast Headquarters, in articles appearing in the Gold Coast Bulletin and the Courier-Mail of 3 November 1989. Subsequent discussions between the Collector of Customs for Queensland and the Assistant Commissioner of the Australian Federal Police in Queensland confirm that both organisations are satisfied with the co-operative drug enforcement arrangements at the Gold Coast.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the President, I present the annual report of the Australian Audit Office for 1988-89.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

This is a very significant report. As it has just come into my hands, I have not had a chance to look at it properly. I will seek leave to continue my remarks at a later time. It is worth noting that in this report there is basically major disagreement between the Government and the Auditor-General about the Government's approach to his office and his effectiveness in auditing governmental bodies, particularly government business enterprises, and about the whole question of efficiency audits. It is worth noting, as the Auditor-General does in the overview, that the enormous amount of work done this year and the issues raised are against a background of continuing uncertainty over the audit mandate of the Australian Audit Office-that is an uncertainty generated by this Government, I believe; of continuing high levels of staff turnover-once again generated by difficulties created by the Government; of the evacuation from the head office in the Silverton Centre in Canberra at an hour's notice in January 1989-that, of course, emerged from the disastrous structural inadequacies of that building, which had to be evacuated; and of the intensive negotiations with staff associations associated with the introduction of the audit manager concept.

TALK.START.PARA: —Where do you think the Minister on duty is? Is he wandering around?

—I take Senator Puplick's point. One would think that a Minister would be sufficiently concerned about the Government's own Audit Office. The Audit Office has been contributing significantly to the capacity of this chamber to deal adequately with matters of a major concern that emerge out of departments and out of government business operations. This is largely due to the further refinement during the Budget session of the Auditor's practice of tabling separate reports on audits of significance-not only to the Executive, but also to the Parliament, the Public Service, the media, and the general public. The Auditor-General says in his report that this should further enhance the usefulness and timeliness of his reports.

SPEECH.PARA: However, there is one matter I draw the Senate's attention to: that is, the manner in which these reports are brought to this chamber. They are presented by the President to the chamber and it is only by someone getting up and getting the leave of the Senate that they can be addressed. The problem is that they are not distributed early in the day when papers are presented. In fact, I got this copy five minutes before I got to my feet. I have had to flip through it, looking for the matters that I knew would concern me. No doubt, I have missed many others; that is why shortly I shall seek leave to continue my remarks.

TALK.START.PARA: —The discerning listener would not have noticed that.

—I thank the honourable senator for his kind remark. Putting the report on the Notice Paper will not mean that it is debated in this session. It will be condemned to limbo, because we have a massive Notice Paper to deal with before we rise. Yet this is a report of major significance. It may well be that some of us who are concerned in this area-for example, Senator Bishop-may well decide that the only way to deal with this is on the adjournment, which will not appeal to many of our colleagues. This creates a real problem. The method of presentation is grossly inadequate.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to deal very speedily with some of the Auditor-General's responses to the Government's response to the recommendations of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts about how the Australian Audit Office should be conducted. On page 22 the Auditor-General says:
The Government's announcement concerning the Auditor-General's efficiency audit mandate is inconsistent.

We ought to stress that there is now clearly a lack of understanding by the Government on what the proper function of the Auditor-General should be. The Joint Committee of Public Accounts did an excellent job in setting up a series of recommendations which the Government has responded to inadequately and which, the Auditor-General has pointed out, are unsatisfactory. I am glad to see that Senator Bishop has at last been given her copy of this report. Maybe there are matters that she would like to raise at this stage. The Auditor-General says:

The Government accepts the JCPA's recommendation that the Auditor-General continue to have responsibility for efficiency audit but, in fact, reduces the efficiency auditing mandate by suggesting that in the ordinary course of events there is little to be gained by subjecting GBEs, whether they are companies or statutory authorities, to efficiency audits.

To me this is incredible. This Government is pushing those bodies into immune zones, protecting them more and more from examination by this Parliament. It seems to be a device, in many instances, to get rid of embarrassing matters from public scrutiny in this place. The Government's response to recommendations about the Auditor-General's involvement in efficiency audits seems to be going down that track. The Auditor-General notes:
This decision ignores:
the limited nature of the marketplace for GBEs
the inefficiencies that can exist within any profit-oriented private-sector business (the bottom line does not guarantee efficiency, even in the private sector)
the conflict that can arise between private- and public-sector objectives
the absence of the competitive pressure experienced in the private sector based on stock exchange listing and borrowing requirements
absence of choice by the public-sector shareholders-the taxpayers, and
the Parliament's right and role in a democratic society.

All these points are absolutely accurate. There is a special need for scrutiny in the area of these government business enterprises. The Government is clearly keen to diminish the Auditor-General's existing capacity to have efficiency audits in that area. I am very tempted to take notice of a remark by Senator Puplick that this is an example of government AIDS-auditor immune departmental stuff-ups. I regret to say that there is a fair amount of merit in that point. The Auditor-General goes on:

The AAO's approach has been to place the highest priority for efficiency audits in those areas of the public sector furthest from the discipline of the market, but it is an unwarranted step backwards to exclude GBEs from efficiency audits unless there is a Ministerial request. It is inconsistent with acceptance of other recommendations of the Committee and, in the light of recent events in some States, exposes Ministers to potential allegations of attempts to obscure the conduct of individual GBEs.
This step is against the trend both internationally and nationally, which has been to strengthen the Auditor-General's mandate, not weaken it.

That is the essence-this Government is seeking to weaken the mandate of the Auditor-General, and the Auditor-General is the person on whom we have been relying more and more for revelations, if you like, about what is really going on in the multibillion dollar business and other activities of the Government.

I would also like to briefly mention that the Auditor-General is very unhappy indeed about the Government's response to the report of the Public Accounts Committee concerning the resourcing levels of the Australian Audit Office, because the Government has indicated that the Committee's analysis of the resource issue left something to be desired. In fact, as I recall, it said that the Committee had made a simplistic sort of comparison between the number of government bodies audited by the Auditor-General and the level of Australian Audit Office staffing. The Auditor-General says that these comments by the Government cannot be allowed to stand without comment. He goes on:

Before commenting on each of the above points, it should be made clear that the Committee's recommendations concerning the funding of efficiency audits and the cycle of coverage were an attempt by the Committee to rectify an historical inadequacy in the legislation introducing the efficiency audit mandate.
He continues:
To concentrate on the level of funding proposed by the Committee rather than the principle of establishing some legislative quantum does a disservice to the Committee's report.

There are pages and pages of these matters of major concern which I simply do not have the time to go into at this stage, largely because I have not had the opportunity to examine this report in any great detail.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K. .

TALK.START.PARA: —My remarks will be brief on this occasion but I think it is important to place on the record some comments regarding the section in the annual report of the Auditor-General entitled `Communication with Parliamentary Committees'. Having been a member of both the working committee and the Public Accounts Committee itself, where we do have such close working relations with the Auditor-General, and having been part of the authorship of the report The Auditor-General: Ally of the People and Parliament, I take a particular interest in the way the Auditor-General reports.

SPEECH.PARA: Whilst I find it commendable that on pages 28, 29 and 30 the Auditor-General reports upon the various inquiries in which his office has been present and able to assist when necessary the Public Accounts Committee inquiry, I think it is necessary to say that we have been successful as a committee in ensuring that the presentation that the Auditor-General does provide to the Public Accounts Committee has, shall I say, been upgraded in recent times. The point I specifically wanted to raise is this: There is a stress placed on the need for the Auditor-General to have good communication with parliamentary committees and to acknowledge that his fundamental obligation is to see that full and proper information comes to the Parliament. It is therefore, I think, important to again state my disappointment in the report that the Auditor-General has furnished to the Parliament concerning his investigation of the Parliamentary Information Systems Office (PISO) within the Department of the Parliamentary Library.

I have spoken in the Parliament on this matter on a couple of occasions concerning the Estimates committees and the tabling of our report. As I said then, and I will say it again now, it was with a grave sense of disappointment that I found that the findings in the report, which was furnished, firstly, to the President, who then in turn furnished it to the Committee, who furnished it to the Parliament, did not substantiate the conclusions which the Auditor-General drew. Indeed, I have termed that report a whitewash. I have said that, if the Auditor-General cannot be that strong, independent linchpin between the operation of the public sector and the reporting to the Parliament, then the whole system collapses. Indeed, it did cause me to look at whether or not there was some avenue by which the Auditor-General's report could have been further scrutinised. I did indeed look to see whether the matter could have been referred to the Ombudsman, but, of course, the Ombudsman is precluded from investigating the Auditor-General. However, the Committee did come up with a recommendation on the whole matter concerning the creation of the illegal and secret $88,000 account that was set up and operated by officers of PISO. One of the beneficiaries of the operation of that account was a Mr Mullane, who subsequently wrote to members of Estimates Committee A admitting that he had lied to the Committee, quite frankly. Only days ago in this chamber the Chairman of that Committee said that he could never again believe what that particular man had to say.

It is a concern that, while this report looks to be a thorough workmanlike report, it draws attention to important matters such as the practice of government business enterprises being able to elect not to use the Auditor-General as the auditor but to go into the private sector when the Public Accounts Committee has recommended that the proper way to go is to have the Auditor-General as the auditor, who is then free to use private sector auditors by way of contract as a correct way of proceeding. Many important issues are raised in this report, and I would reflect upon Senator Michael Baume's remarks that it is simply not satisfactory to have a report of this importance in one's hands only as the report is presented to the Parliament and then be expected to have some sort of understanding of what is in it. It just will not do. I seek leave to continue my remarks because I particularly will want to read the report more thoroughly, and I know other members will wish to speak on it.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

TALK.START.PARA: —In view of the remarks made by Senator Michael Baume about the late delivery of this report, I should make it clear that the President arranges distribution of reports of the Auditor-General, the Reserve Bank of Australia, and so on, two hours before tabling, in the same manner as ministerial statements are given to leaders of the Opposition in advance of tabling under embargo. I have confirmed that this particular report was delivered to the office of the Leader of the Opposition at 1 p.m.-that is, more than two hours before tabling-and to some extent the problem of late delivery to Senator Michael Baume would appear to be an internal matter for the Opposition. Nevertheless, I will draw the attention of the President to Senator Baume's remarks, and the President might like to look at whether the arrangement of two hours before for a report of this nature is appropriate for debate in the Senate.

DEBATE.TITLE: THIRD COMMONWEALTH CONFERENCE ON DELEGATED LEGISLATION

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K. .

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Mr Deputy President, I had the honour the week before last to lead a delegation of senators and others to the Third Commonwealth Conference on Delegated Legislation, hosted by the United Kingdom Joint Committee on Statutory Instruments and held in London from 20 to 23 November. The Australian delegation consisted of me, in my capacity of Deputy Chairman of the Regulations and Ordinances Committee, Senator Patricia Giles, a member of the Regulations and Ordinances Committee and Chair of the Committee of Privileges, Senator Kay Patterson, a member of the Regulations and Ordinances Committee and Deputy Chairman of the Scrutiny of Bills Committee, and Senator Rosemary Crowley, a member and former Chair of the Scrutiny of Bills Committee. We were accompanied by Anne Lynch, Deputy Clerk of the Senate; Emeritus Professor Douglas Whalan, Legal Adviser to the Senate Regulations and Ordinances Committee; Mr Ken Jasper, MP, Chairman of the Subordinate Legislation Subcommittee of the Victorian Legal and Constitutional Committee, and Ms Pauline Ireland, Research Officer to the Victorian Legal and Constitutional Committee. The delegation will be presenting a full report to the Senate, including a transcript of the proceedings of the Conference, when such proceedings become available. The delegation considered, however, that I should make this statement to the Senate as soon as possible.

SPEECH.PARA: As with the previous conferences, held first in Australia in 1980 and second in Canada in 1983, this conference brought together representatives of a wide cross-section of Commonwealth countries. Delegates from a number of countries which had not been represented at the previous conferences attended the London conference. In particular, note was taken at that conference of the representation from Pakistan, the first Commonwealth-wide conference that country had attended since rejoining the Commonwealth. In all, 61 delegates attended from 17 countries.

As with previous conferences, the commonality of problems confronting all delegated legislation committees was evident. The resolutions agreed to unanimously at the conference give a brief indication of the matters which were discussed during the four days of the conference. I seek leave to have this incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The resolutions read as follows-
RESOLUTIONS OF THE CONFERENCE
1. That this Conference:

(a) expresses its deep regret at the death, on 30th March 1986, of Senator Alan Joseph Missen, Australia, Chairman of our first Commonwealth Conference on Delegated Legislation, hosted by Australia in 1980, and inaugural Chairman of the Commonwealth Delegated Legislation Committee; and

(b) places on record its appreciation of the crucial contribution made by the late Senator Missen to the establishment of this Commonwealth-wide institution, and to the enhancement of parliamentary democracy by emphasising the importance of scrutiny of all legislation to good government.
2. That a continuing coordinating Committee be appointed by the Conference to:
(a) arrange the next conference
(b) bring up to date the Comparative Study prepared in Canada.
3. That the Committee shall consist of representatives for each of the following geographical groups of delegations, each group electing its own representative on a one delegation one vote basis:
(a) Europe (Cyprus, U.K.)
(b) Asia (Maldives, Pakistan)
(c) Africa (Botswana, Tanzania, Zambia, Zimbabwe)-two representatives
(d) Americas (Belize, Canada)
(e) Caribbean (St. Lucia, Trinidad & Tobago)
(f) Pacific (Australia, New Zealand)

4. That the Committee shall appoint its own Chair and determine its own procedures; that the immediate past Chair (currently Hon. Perrin Beatty P.C., M.P., Canada) shall be entitled to be coopted ex-officio; and that the hosts of the next conference, if not already represented, shall be entitled to nominate a representative to be coopted.

5. That the United Kingdom will provide a secretariat for the Committee until the hosts of the next conference are identified; and that this function will be transferred to the hosts of the next conference.
6. That the next conference will be held in a jurisdiction willing to host it, not less than 3 years and if possible not more than 5 years after the current conference.
7. That the Conference authorises the United Kingdom delegation to circulate a record of its proceedings.

8. That the following issues, common to a number of Commonwealth countries, arose from the 3rd Commonwealth Conference on Delegated Legislation; and that therefore it would be a profitable exercise for each member country to examine its scrutiny procedures in relation to the issues set out below, and to be prepared to report to the next conference the results of such examination and, should modification or reform be deemed necessary, any progress made to achieve change.
The allowing of the executive takes power to amend or repeal primary legislation without further reference to Parliament (``Henry VIII Clauses'');
whether those responsible for scrutinizing delegated legislation have access to the best and most independent legal and technical advice;
whether the language of legislation, including delegated legislation, is accessible and comprehensible to the ordinary citizen;
the scrutiny of delegated powers contained in bills or proposed bills;
the weeding out of outdated, over-amended or inaccessible regulations, whether by ``sunset clauses'' or other means.
In preparation for the next conference, a survey of the information from each country should be collated, perhaps by the host country, and presented to the Fourth Conference.

(e) vacant
(f) Senator Bronwyn Bishop (Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —Significantly, the conference resolved that each member country would examine its own scrutiny procedure concerning the following issues: firstly, `Henry VIII clauses', whereby the Executive takes power to amend or repeal primary legislation without further reference to Parliament; secondly, whether those responsible for scrutinising delegated legislation have access to the best and most independent legal and technical advice; thirdly, whether the language of legislation, including delegated legislation, is accessible and comprehensible to the ordinary citizen; fourthly, the scrutiny of delegated powers contained in Bills or proposed Bills; and, fifthly, the weeding out of outdated, overamended or inaccessible regulations, whether by `sunset clauses' or other means.

SPEECH.PARA: It is well to note that extreme use of Henry VIII clauses, which is of relative insignificance at the Federal level in Australia because of our Regulations and Ordinances Committee and Scrutiny of Bills Committee, was of great concern to a number of our colleagues, particularly in Britain. The model of our Scrutiny of Bills Committee met with great enthusiasm from Lord Rippon from the United Kingdom, where there is no such equivalent. Many features of the Australian system, both at a Federal and State level, were the subject of some envy by our Commonwealth colleagues. The most important feature at Federal level, which has also been commented upon at previous conferences, is the capacity of either House to ensure that motions of disallowance, whether on behalf of the Regulations and Ordinances Committee or by any member of either House, are in fact dealt with. Some legislatures, notably Victoria and New Zealand, are moving in this direction; others are frustrated by their lack of capacity to ensure that their reports and recommendations for disallowance are debated and determined.

The problem of quasi-law, that is, guidelines, manuals, rulings and the like which can be given the force of law and are not subject to parliamentary scrutiny, met with considerable concern from delegates, who noted the growth of such practices. Discussion over the week ranged widely, as indicated by the subject matter of each session. The first session, on 20 November, was based on a paper commissioned by the second conference and prepared by the Parliament of Canada, entitled `Drafting and Scrutiny of Legislation in the Commonwealth: a Comparative Study'. As the first speaker on this paper I gave an account of the current operations of the Regulations and Ordinances Committee. As mentioned above, the question of quasi-law was one of such concern to the conference that it was the subject of a full discussion on 21 November following an address given by Professor Gabriele Ganz from Southampton University. Senator Patricia Giles delivered a paper which addressed this question.

On Wednesday, 22 November, under the general heading `Uses and Abuses of Delegated Powers', three papers were given. The first was by Mr Andrew Bennett, MP, of the United Kingdom, who spoke in general terms on the topic; the second by Mr Doug Graham, MP, of New Zealand who spoke to a paper on fees and charges, with particular reference to the use of delegated legislation to raise taxes without full parliamentary authority. The third paper, on the overuse of Henry VIII clauses, was given by the aforesaid Hon. Lord Rippon of Hexham, a former Secretary of State for the Environment, who, as I said earlier, drew specific attention to the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills as a model which might, with profit, be followed by other parliaments. It was therefore timely that the speaker at the next session on that day, Senator Rosemary Crowley, gave a paper on the scrutiny of enabling legislation, with particular reference to the operation of the Scrutiny of Bills Committee.

The afternoon session was devoted to discussion of court supervision of delegated legislation, the subject of a paper by Mr Louis Blom-Cooper, QC, from the United Kingdom, whose paper was supported by a contribution from Professor Douglas Whalan. This was followed by a panel discussion on relationships between executive government and the Parliament, with United Kingdom representatives from the Department of Education and Science and the Home Office, Parliamentary Counsel, and the Law Advocate's Department, together with Counsel to the Chairman of Committees of the House of Lords and Counsel to Mr Speaker. Indeed, we were privileged to have the opening ceremony of this conference conducted by both the Lord Chancellor and Mr Speaker.

On 23 November, Senator Kay Patterson delivered a paper on the review of existing regulations, which gave a succinct account of general scrutiny practices in the Australian States. Mr Ken Jasper, as a representative of the States, spoke of the practices in the Victorian legislature. The last paper delivered at the conference was by Professor St John Bates, Clerk of Tynwald, the Isle of Man. He examined different models of scrutiny, covering matters such as whether such scrutiny is best undertaken by a committee of members or by officials, and powers of committees in relation to delegated legislation. Anne Lynch made a contribution on behalf of the Australian delegation.

The conference proceedings concluded with a panel discussion of which I was privileged to be a member, the panellists having been selected in the course of the conference from the delegations. These panellists emphasised the importance of parliamentary scrutiny of the Executive and executive accountability to the Parliament. The conference concluded with a discussion of future proceedings and with agreement to the resolutions which I have had incorporated in Hansard. It is noteworthy that the first resolution of the conference was a recognition of the contribution made by the late Senator Alan Missen to the establishment of the conference and the enhancement of parliamentary democracy.

Mr Acting Deputy President, on behalf of the Australian delegation, I wish to thank you and the Senate for the support given to the delegation. This support was continued in London by Mr President's predecessor, His Excellency the Hon. Douglas McClelland, and Mrs McClelland, and the excellent staff at the Australian High Commission, to whom we express our appreciation. We wish also to place on record our sincere thanks to our hosts, the United Kingdom Committee on Statutory Instruments, for the splendid organisation of the conference, and the wonderful hospitality which we all enjoyed. As the brief outline of the program indicates, all delegates actively contributed, both through the presentation of papers and through their participation in the vigorous discussions that followed the presentation of the papers. There seems little doubt that the discussions were fruitful, and the Australian delegation looks forward to being represented at the next conference, which by resolution will be held within the next three to five years at a venue yet to be determined. I move:
That the Senate take note of the statement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to take a few moments to make some comments about the Third Commonwealth Conference on Delegated Legislation at which I was a member of the Australian Delegation. I add my support to the words of Senator Bishop and, in particular, thank the people who assisted us on this delegation. From Doug McClelland to the Chairperson of the Joint Statutory Instruments Committee, Mr Bob Cryer overseas; to Anne Lynch and Professor Whalan, who accompanied the delegation. In summary, I think the conference was very constructive and useful. It was also very enjoyable, but I understand that the rules of the game state that by and large that is not reported to the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: I would also like to support the motion commending the work done by the late Alan Missen. I had the pleasure and privilege of serving on the Scrutiny of Bills Committee at a time when he was a member. Indeed, I think Senator Tate was Chairman of that Committee at the time. I think this Parliament has acknowledged on a number of occasions Alan Missen's contribution to the protection of rights in Australia. I wish to add my own personal support to that motion. His interest in this area was never anything but utterly genuine and clearly very committed because it took a long time to persuade people in this place to move in the way of a Scrutiny of Bills Committee. If one considers to what extent that was driven by Alan Missen, I think we can all appreciate and benefit from the work he has done.

I made a few points at the conference which I would briefly like to refer to. I made three points in respect of the Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills. The first was that if we are talking about the protection of the rights of citizens-in other words, I suppose, the importance of remembering what a fragile flower democracy is-we should remember, from time to time, that that is, in fact, what the work of that Committee is about. It is too easy to get caught up in the substance of the work of a committee and forget what it was established for and what its business is. Its business is about the rights of citizens, and I felt it was very important to make a few points about those rights.

Most honourable senators will know that I keep a weather eye on things to do with women. I was particularly interested to check the history of the law relating to women. I found that, even though many of our Acts of Parliament state that `he' is taken to mean `she', that was the case if `she' was to carry a stick of dynamite but it was not the case if `she' wanted to fill out a ballot paper. Women were denied the right to vote despite a law which, theoretically, allowed them the right to vote. I was very pleased to see that there is now no doubt at all that women have equal rights to vote and stand for parliament under the Westminster system in the United Kingdom and under our own system here. Although I have been going around the world saying that New Zealand was the first country to give the vote to women-that was in 1893-I was advised by a gentleman from the Isle of Man, whose name I have forgotten, that the Isle of Man gave the vote to women in 1884.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a wonder you have not required them to change the name of the island.
—That piece of rotten humour belongs to Senator Puplick, and I will not waste a moment on it.
—But it was his best!

—Yes, that is true. This matter is important and particularly interesting. I cited the battle that women on this side of the chamber have had since 1983 to have Hansard record exactly what we say rather than correct it, as it did for some 18 months after I came here in 1983, into single sex, male language. Apparently, they were the guidelines under which Hansard operated and this seemed to me to conflict with the practice of taking down every word that was said in the chamber. I was delighted to find on my desk shortly after I returned a media release dated 22 November, which stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The Senate on Tuesday adopted a new set of standing orders-the rules which govern its proceedings-to replace those adopted in 1903 . . . Masculine pronouns-references to Senators and office-holders as ``he'' and ``him''-have been eliminated, a reflection of the presence of 17 women in the Senate.

The battle may have to continue and some of us will remain ever vigilant about all these things. However, for the record, I was pleased to see in England that women's rights are more guaranteed and more protected. But it is very important to know that sometimes we have to insist that the word `woman' be used in legislation, because in the past the interpretation of the law by judges has actually denied women the right to vote and denied them their rights under some legislation.

The next point we talked about, and Senator Bishop has referred to it, is the use of language that is understandable. If the work we are doing is devoted to allowing citizens the right of access to the law and the knowledge of how it affects their lives, it is important that citizens understand it. If these laws affect their lives, there must surely be, as a matter of basic right, understandable, clear English language within those laws. It is important that they understand what those laws say, particularly if they impinge on their lives. Sometimes a person says, `I am a law-abiding citizen and the law does not affect me very much'. Any examination of, for example, social security or health legislation, let alone tax legislation, will reveal that most law-abiding citizens are still affected by the law.

Partly by way of entertainment-certainly it got a good laugh in England, so I will risk it again in another chamber-I read a piece of legislation to illustrate that sometimes the law is not clear at all. The source of this appalling legislative prose is hopefully lost in the realms of time, although I understand Professor Whalan could give me its origin. I apologise to the Senate that I do not have it. Perhaps at a later time I will. It states:

In the Nuts (unground), (other than ground nuts) Order, the expression nuts shall have reference to such nuts, other than ground nuts, as would but for this amendment Order not qualify as nuts (unground) (other than ground nuts) by reason of their being nuts (unground).

I have read that quite often-it still causes much merriment-but I have no idea what it means. We made the point, and reinforced it with other examples, that law must be understandable, and I think that point was widely appreciated by all the people who attended the conference.

The last point I wish to make concerns the very constructive contribution by David Magang, who was recently elected as the Minister for Finance in Botswana. The aforementioned Professor St. John Bates, the Clerk of Tynwald of the Isle of Man, told us that the Parliament of the Isle of Man was the longest continuing parliament in the world. I am advised that it had its millennium in 1979, so it certainly has a claim for being somewhat aged. That parliament addresses the legal needs of the 70,000 residents of the Isle of Man. While we were talking about delegated legislation, the significant bits and pieces of regulations and ordinances and so on, the Minister for Finance from Botswana got up and asked why one would be bothered with delegated legislation in a country that has 70,000 people; why not just round them up and tell them? This was a particularly appropriate and succinct comment. It is open to misinterpretation, but I would certainly not want to make that meaning part of my contribution. The point that the Minister for Finance from Botswana raised is very pertinent and important. What do we mean by the `community' when we talk about citizens who are affected by our legislation, and what methods and mechanisms do we have for providing that information to our citizens and to our community?

Australia is trying to address that need for something like 17 million people. The population of the United Kingdom, while it is crowded more closely together, is much larger than that and I am quite sure that many people in London, let alone northern Scotland, are not at all aware of the legislation which affects them. The challenge of how we inform citizens is a very significant one and the point raised by the Minister for Finance from Botswana is very pertinent indeed. What we must do is ensure diversity in the way we provide that information to the community. What might be appropriate in the United Kingdom or Australia may be entirely inappropriate in the Maldives, Trinidad and Tobago, Pakistan or Botswana.

This is a very telling point for us to think about in terms of the rights of citizens-their right to know the ways in which they can have access to information. I sincerely hope that delegates from Botswana, which has very different methods of getting information to people in the community, will be considered as speakers at the next conference on delegated legislation because I believe that their contribution would be different, very pertinent and useful for the rest of the delegates from the Commonwealth countries.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support Senator Bishop's statement and wish to make a brief comment. I, too, was a member of the delegation which attended the Third Commonwealth Conference on Delegated Legislation. I would like to take this opportunity to thank those Senate staff members who assisted in preparing the delegation for the conference. In particular, I would like to put on record the delegation's appreciation of the Deputy Clerk, Miss Anne Lynch. I will let the Senate into a small secret and say that in a moment of tiredness and jet lag I actually referred to her as `Deputy Lynch'. She then became affectionately known to the delegation as deputy linchpin. That may be a nickname that will stick. Miss Lynch gave us enormous support and help and was ready at all hours-even in the middle of the night when we had a fire alarm-to assist us in many ways.

SPEECH.PARA: My thanks also go to Emeritus Professor Douglas Whalan, our legal adviser, for the role that he played in the conference and the advice and assistance he afforded the delegation. He was on hand to help. As we weeded out bits and pieces of our papers as they were dealt with throughout the Conference, I thought that some of the other people at the Conference got a little indigestion from overindulgence of the Australian pie of regulations, ordinances and scrutiny of Bills. I guess that that occurred because of our experience in the area. I hope that we did not dominate the Conference too much.

The issue of quasi laws that Senator Bishop raised came out at the Conference over and over again. Each of the legislatures was experiencing a proliferation of guidelines, directives, rulings and so on. Most, if not all, of the delegates expressed concern at this proliferation and the fact that they were being used increasingly instead of delegation in the form of regulations which are subject to parliamentary scrutiny. I take this opportunity to reiterate what I have said before in this chamber-that this Parliament should be mindful of the increasing use of quasi laws. We should set in place procedures for these to be subjected to scrutiny, to indexing and to publication so that citizens are aware of them and have ready access to them. It is something that we have talked about a number of times. I believe that we should continue to act to ensure that there are ways and means brought about to make sure that members of the public have access to legislation and to quasi laws.

I very much appreciated the opportunity to be part of what may have been-because of its makeup-an historic delegation. It was a privilege to share our experiences with other Commonwealth countries and also to learn from them. Despite the fact that we are quite a way down the track in the scrutiny of primary and secondary legislation, the Conference was a very timely reminder that there are always improvements to be made so that the rights of individuals and the elected parliament are properly protected.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Giles Sen P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to place on record a tribute to the officers of the Senate who prepared the papers for our meeting. My colleagues have probably covered most of the other matters that we would want to recognise in relation to the excellent hospitality, the splendid arrangements made for us, the quality of the Third Commonwealth Conference on Delegated Legislation generally and the degree to which we believe it contributed to the debate on delegated legislation and the scrutiny of legislation generally in the Commonwealth. I come back to the quality of our papers. These were prepared for us to use as a basis for discussion. On each occasion they were apt, comprehensive and ideal for the purpose.

SPEECH.PARA: I was particularly grateful to have the opportunity to deliver the paper on quasi legislation in Australia. I have been reminded continually since then of how important this is in the Australian context. Incidentally, my paper included an appendix with a catalogue of all the different types of quasi legislation that Peter O'Keeffe, an officer attached to the delegation, was able to identify. We came to a score of about 30 different types of quasi legislation. Amongst those, there were many different types of orders, for example, and numerous declarations, determinations, zoning plans, plans of management, principles, guides, guidelines, notices, proclamations, directions, instruments, rates of levy, et cetera. Last night during a public hearing of the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs I was very interested to hear Julian Disney of the Australian Council of Social Service refer to the proliferation of these `strange animals'. If one could carry the analogy a little further, I suppose that one might comment that it is time that many of these strange animals' tendency to reproduce was brought under control as far as our legislative procedures are concerned.

Wearing our privileges headgear, Anne Lynch and I were able to meet with the Clerk of the House of Commons. On the following day Anne was able to meet with the secretary of the privileges committee of the United Kingdom Parliament. We found these discussions to be of considerable interest and value to us. We have common concerns, despite the minor differences in our procedures. We were able to learn from each other and I think we have managed to secure a budding association to the mutual advantage of the United Kingdom committee on privileges and our own Senate Privileges Committee.

Like Senator Patterson, Senator Bishop and Senator Crowley, I thoroughly enjoyed the experience. I found it extremely rewarding and feel honoured to have had the opportunity to participate in what was a valuable experience and which was, and I will emphasise this for the benefit of Senator Tate, an historic delegation: the first ever all women delegation from this Parliament with, as our officer, Anne Lynch, the Deputy Clerk of the Senate. It is a pity that we cannot include in Hansard the photographic proof.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
