DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN FILM FINANCE CORPORATION PTY LTD

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 2 November, on motion by Senator Jenkins:
That the Senate take note of the paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —This report is the first which gives details of the operation of the Australian Film Finance Corporation Pty Ltd, the new body established by the Government to deal with the provision of finance for making Australian films. The Film Finance Corporation, in my judgment, has not served the industry as well as one would have hoped. One can see from page 9 of the annual report that two essential criteria are introduced by the Film Finance Corporation in deciding whether to fund and how much funding to provide for individual projects. The two essential criteria are noted in the report to be private sector participation and demonstration of market interest through presales and distribution agreements or commitments. This is a way of saying that the Film Finance Corporation has decided that the primary test of a film should be its acceptability in overseas markets. As a matter of cultural policy, I think that is quite reprehensible. It is a formula for the internationalisation of the Australian film industry in the worst sense of that term-that is to say, making films in Australia which are almost indistinguishable from films made anywhere else in the world rather than seeking to bring about a situation in which uniquely Australian films are promoted in international film markets. It is most regrettable that this tendency has occurred because it means, in effect, the production of lowest common denominator films rather than those which are genuinely innovative and exciting and genuinely reflect a unique Australian idiom.

SPEECH.PARA: Similarly, on page 13 of the report the Corporation indicates that it will now implement two new policies. It says that it will target proven industry performers and thus take a more pro-active approach within the industry. Secondly, it will seek to match talented but relatively inexperienced film-makers with experienced personnel in a number of supportive projects. The former of these, the targeting of proven industry performers, will in my judgment further erode the capacity of new young film-makers to get a start in the business. It will further discourage people from taking risks, being entrepreneurial, being exciting and being innovative in films. It will rather result, as have the funding policies of the Australia Council in recent years, in the same old people continuing to appear on the gravy train year after year.

I finally mention one thing which concerns me considerably, that is, the reference to the legal advisers and the legal work undertaken by Allen, Allen and Hemsley on behalf of the Corporation. That is a most distinguished firm of lawyers of whom I make no criticism. I regret, however, that the fee which has been established for the preparation of what are, in fact, word processed contracts is as high as it is. As I understand it, before a film-maker gets his grant he has to fork out $25,000 for a standard contract, which is simply a matter of the word processor spewing out the contract with the necessary particular details about the contracting party and the sum of money involved being written into the contract. For that the film-maker has to find $25,000 up-front to pay for the Corporation's legal expenses. I think that is absolutely outrageous. It is typical of the way in which the film business has fallen progressively into the hands of lawyers and accountants in the most negative sense. It is very unfortunate that these sorts of things occur. I intend to pursue, at some later stage, the question of the legal fees which are attached to the operations of the Film Finance Corporation and which are imposing a very significant and quite unnecessary up-front cost, particularly on small independent film producers throughout Australia.

There are a number of other reports in this group of papers to which I would like to have made reference but I believe that, with 92 reports on the Notice Paper, it would be better to try to constrain our remarks somewhat. Therefore, while I would like to have made reference to others, I will defer at this stage to my colleagues.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bjelke-Petersen Sen F.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.
I congratulate the Australian Tourist Commission on its annual report and the tremendous work it does in trying to promote Australia. In the Chairman's review of the report on page 6 he states:
Predominant among the highlights of 1988/89 was that Australia and ordinary Australians began to realise the huge potential of our tourism industry. The Bicentennial celebrations and World Expo 88-
which was held in Brisbane-
gave all Australians a new found sense of pride and a desire to share our good fortune with the rest of the world.

These two events-coming on top of the solid marketing base built up by the ATC over recent years-focused world wide attention on Australia and motivated thousands of people to travel here. For the first time, we attracted more than two million overseas visitors in a year.
1988/89 will also be remembered as the year Australia stopped riding on the sheep's back and leapt forward with tourism.
We are having a little trouble at the moment riding on the sheep's back, unfortunately. He continues:

International tourism generated a massive $6.5 billion in foreign exchange, surpassing wool as the nation's biggest export earner. It also continued to provide employment for more than 100,000 Australians.

The work of the Australian Tourist Commission includes working not only to increase the number of overseas visitors to Australia and to maximise the benefits to Australia from those tourists but also to monitor the environmental and social impact of tourism. However, if any monitoring needs to be done, it should be in the light of the current pilots dispute, which has forced the Australian Tourist Commission to slash drastically its estimate of the short-term future of Australia's tourist boom.

Last year the Commission was confidently predicting in its 1987-88 report that 2.7 million foreigners would travel to Australia for holidays in 1990, but I note in this report that it has had to change that figure downwards to 2.23 million visitors. There can be no doubt that this slashing of estimates is the result of current Government policies and the disreputable part it has played to prolong the current pilots dispute. As the report noted on page 44:

During the second half of 1988/89, Australia's tourism industry was hit by the inevitable post-Bicentennial slowdown . . . Despite this, the industry was expecting a strong turnaround in the last quarter of 1989, traditionally the busiest period of the year.

However . . . soon after the close of the period . . . all scheduled domestics flights (were grounded) . . . International tourists were forced to cope with restricted services, with many remote areas virtually inaccessible . . .
I know that far north Queensland has been having a very hard time because of this cut down in air services, and the same applies to the Northern Territory. The Chairman continues:

. . . It was apparent that Australia's reputation as a reliable tourist destination had been damaged in many overseas markets, particularly Japan and the United States. Any chance of a turnaround has been dashed.
In an indictment of the Government's failure to acknowledge that its actions in the current dispute have left much of the industry in tatters, the report said:
The dispute was one of the factors the ATC took into account when it drew up its visitor arrival targets for the next decade.

Certainly, the effects of the dispute as far as tourism is concerned cannot be underestimated. It is estimated that tourist receipts could be down by $3 billion if the dispute extends into next year. Twenty thousand casual and permanent jobs have already been lost in the hospitality industry. Major Japanese travel wholesalers have deleted Australia as a destination in their 1990 programs. Australia has been deleted from German travel programs and United States retailers have stopped selling Australia. These are very sad facts. I know that north Queensland tourist operators are very upset about the whole matter. They have recorded a fall from 76.4 per cent to 35.8 per cent in room occupancy rates.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I speak to the Australian Tourist Commission's annual report because during the debate on Appropriation Bill (No. 1) I asked Senator Richardson a series of questions which he simply did not answer. The questions go to the heart of the issues which Senator Bjelke-Petersen has just raised; that is, the impact of the pilots strike-or the dispute that does not exist, according to the the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke)-on tourism. As Senator Bjelke-Petersen pointed out, the report states that the dispute was one of the factors which the Australian Tourist Commission took into account when it drew up its visitor arrival targets for the next decade. These involve a substantial cut next year in the level of tourism from that of the previous year. It is the first overall cut in tourism that has taken place since 1982. These targets represent a 3.6 per cent reduction as against the continual rises in previous years-of 11.6 per cent last year, 25.2 per cent the year before, 25.8 per cent the year before, 19 per cent the year before that, and so on. Those rises have been reversed.

SPEECH.PARA: When I raised this issue with Senator Richardson he concentrated entirely on the increase in costs involved for tourists as a result of higher hotel prices among the leading first-class hotels in Australia. I simply do not know whether or not his criticism of those hotels was right, but it seemed to me to miss entirely the point that is made in the Tourist Commission's report. The Commission has conceded, without quantifying it, that the air pilots dispute-and, I might say, the Government's incompetent handling of it-has resulted in a reduction in expected targets of tourists.

We deserve to be told-I asked Senator Richardson but I did not get an answer-what the volume of reduction is in the number of tourists that the Tourist Commission now expects to get next year, by how much its target has been reduced, because of the airline pilots strike? This is a simple factual matter. The Parliament is entitled to know on what figures one of its bodies-an organisation paid for by the taxpayers-has based its views. What is the reduction? Perhaps Senator Tate, who is in the chamber, will be more reasonable than Senator Richardson and seek these figures from the Tourist Commission.

I draw his attention to a table on page 45 of the annual report. It reveals that total tourism for Australia in 1989 is forecast to be down by about 80,000 tourists overall and that from New Zealand there will be a 14 per cent fall; a one per cent fall from Japan; an 8 per cent fall from the United Kingdom and Ireland; a 15 per cent fall from the United States; and an 18 per cent fall from Canada. Once again I ask: Please may we have the courtesy of a reply to a simple factual question? By what amount has the Tourist Commission altered its target levels for next year because of the pilots strike?

In conclusion, I make one brief point. One sees the benefits of immigration in these tourism figures because the biggest single item after holidays that encourages people to come to Australia is to visit relatives. For about 20 per cent of tourists their main purpose in coming here is to visit relatives. That is one of the hidden benefits involved in a substantial and continuing immigration program. That is why the Japanese market is at risk. Only 1.6 per cent of visitors from Japan come here for that purpose; 83.1 per cent simply come here for a holiday. That is an area of great vulnerability unless we can get our internal airlines and our cost structure in order.

With Senator Hill, who is a member of the Council--

TALK.START.PARA: —Now retired.

—Senator Hill says that he has retired from the Council. However, I emphasise that it is not a Canberra institution; it is a very important national institution. I want to emphasise some of the important national roles that it plays. The report of the proceedings of the summit and of the National Library's role is incorporated in the 1988-89 annual report. Page 5 states, and I agree entirely:

SPEECH.PARA: The Summit made major advances towards the better development of the nation's library services in the interests of their users, and the unanimous agreement reached by delegates on all major issues discussed has set a new national agenda for improved cooperation and service.
At page 9 the report states:
. . . the resolutions have set a new agenda for the next 3-5 years and beyond, covering every sector of the library industry and all the major current issues.

I make those points not merely to say that the summit was important, which it was-I said that when I spoke to last year's report-but to highlight the fact that it is playing an important role in the development of libraries throughout Australia. There are all sorts of other examples one could draw of the service which the National Library provides to the industry. The summit is the example I use to make that point. It was an outstanding success and those involved should be congratulated.

The National Library operates beyond the normal boundaries of what would be regarded as the role of a library because it takes a broad view of its responsibilities. As an example of that I refer to the exhibitions reported in appendix 10 at pages 87 to 90. A series of impressive and important major exhibitions are visited by a large number of people. People from all around Australia visit them and it is a significant part of the tourist trade in Canberra. People from all around Australia visit the National Library and see the exhibitions. More importantly, as page 89 states, material is lent for exhibitions and is displayed all around Australia. As page 90 states, there are important travelling exhibitions.

I conclude by referring to the role of the National Library in the international library movement which is reported under the heading `International cooperation and coordination'. On another occasion I will seek to speak about the overall role of Australia's cultural exchanges with other countries. The National Library has made a substantial contribution in the Asia-Pacific region. It is developing a role as a regional centre. I know that its assistance to Indonesia is particularly welcomed by people in that country. It was a very valuable contribution. I take this opportunity of recording my appreciation, and I am sure that of everybody in Canberra and all honourable senators, to the staff of the National Library for the excellent work that it has done again in the last 12 months.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the motion that the Senate take note of the paper and seek leave to continue my remarks later.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.
On page 9 of the annual report of the Independent Air Fares Committee for 1988-89 there is a very interesting quotation. It reads:
Published statistics show that Ansett and Australian-
that is, Australian Airlines-

achieved very high passenger traffic growth and loan factors during the initial six months of 1988-89 . . . due to the Bicentennial celebrations, Expo 88 and the continued strong growth in international inbound tourism.

The impact of this report, of course, is for the financial year 1988-89. The quotation I have read out probably underpinned the various considerations that were made for that financial year with regard to air fares. What a different and sorry story the next report of the Independent Air Fares Committee will be. There will be no way that Ansett and Australian will be able to report or achieve high passenger traffic growth in a similar six-month period in the next financial year, because of the very sad and sorry saga of the current pilots strike or dispute, or whatever the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) wants to call it because he cannot solve it.

The principles that have been adopted by the Independent Air Fares Committee impact considerably on the economy of Australia, particularly over air traffic routes that have long distances or service the remote communities of Australia. All the principles that have been built up and adopted over such a long period will now have the rug pulled from under them. The impact on future air fares around Australia of the pilots strike/dispute will affect not only this current financial year but also many years to come. The role and function of this Committee will be crucial in ensuring that the Government is kept honest and that Australian Airlines and Ansett are also kept honest in the areas that must come under the very close and proper scrutiny of this Committee.

The report makes very clear that the capital investments of the companies are taken into account, as well as wages and salaries and associated on-costs, which represent some 33 per cent of trunk route airline costs, movements in other costs which are outside their direct control, such as fuel prices, fluctuations in foreign exchange rates and increases in government authority charges, which it is important also to settle.

It is interesting to note that the Independent Air Fares Committee in the 1988-89 financial year endorsed and supported a number of very special discount fare initiatives which, as its report very properly points out, enhanced the competitive environment of domestic air services, stimulated the growth of tourism in Australia and improved the overall viability of airline operations, resulting in benefits to the travelling public and the airlines.

This rebuilding and restructuring of the airline industry-or, as I have called it in other places and at other times, the perestroika of Ansett and Australian Airlines-that Mr Hawke is so intent upon is only necessary because we are now at about day 115 of this dispute, with its catastrophic effects on tourism, small business and the remote and regional parts of Australia. All of these consequences could well have been avoided had the Prime Minister shown more determination and gall to solve the problem in the very early days of the dispute.

It is pleasing to note that the Independent Air Fares Committee closely cooperates with the State and Northern Territory governments in reaching its determinations. Obviously, we will have to rely on the State governments and the Northern Territory Government to make submissions that will carefully isolate and insulate the effects of the strike, or the dispute, so that they are not portrayed as an automatic flow-on and consequence of the action and so that any costs the airlines might attribute to them are not passed on to the travelling public, particularly as all the effects have been occasioned by the lack of will and the impotence of the Prime Minister.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was very pleased this morning to get a telephone call from the office of the Minister for Defence, Mr Beazley, telling me that after my comments yesterday about the unavailability of the Arthur Young report, which was promised to this Parliament in October, the report would be made available to the Senate, to me and to Senator Newman today and that if there were any delay in it being made available today it would certainly be available by tomorrow. I am grateful for that but I hope that it is available today rather than tomorrow because we will not be here tomorrow. I hope that Mr Beazley's office will make every effort to ensure that it is provided this afternoon.

SPEECH.PARA: The new Anzac frigate project is a matter of major concern to New South Wales in general and to the Newcastle area in particular. The Government has given various undertakings that 40 per cent of the work will be done in New South Wales, and a large proportion of that in Newcastle, even though the contract was won by Amecon Ltd, which is headquartered in Victoria. At Senate Estimates committees I asked many questions seeking to get hard and fast guarantees from the Government that that work would be done in Newcastle. After all, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) wrote a letter saying that it would be available to Newcastle. But none of the contract material indicates any sort of commitment to that objective. At Senate Estimates committee hearings it was repeatedly stated by spokesmen for the Department of Defence that it was impossible to give that hard and fast guarantee.

That prompted me to ask a question in Senate Estimates, to which I have only recently received an answer, about what happened to the submarine contract. As I recall, the submarine contract also involved some undertakings that New South Wales would get a certain proportion of the contract. My recollection was right. I have received a reply from the Defence Department, saying:

Based on the contracts awarded to date by the Australian Submarine Corporation and excluding the construction facility being established in South Australia, the distribution of work by State is: Australian Capital Territory, one per cent; New South Wales, 24 per cent; South Australia, 60 per cent; Victoria, 7 per cent, and work not yet placed, 8 per cent.

I remind the Senate that this is very different indeed from the proper expectations that New South Wales had much earlier. During the project definition study, Australian Submarine Corporation advised that the likely distribution of work by State was as follows-and this is excluding the work to be done at the Australian construction facility; in other words, exactly the same criteria as the table I have just read out: New South Wales, 40 per cent; South Australia, 15 per cent; Victoria, 30 per cent; Queensland, 10 per cent; Western Australia, 3 per cent; and Tasmania, 2 per cent. The undertaking was that New South Wales would get 40 per cent of the work and, in fact, it is now getting 24 per cent of the work. In other words, undertakings from this Government to New South Wales are simply not worth the paper they are written on. That is why I have been pressing the Government for something better than simply a letter from the Prime Minister saying that the work will be done in New South Wales. Quite frankly, why should anyone believe the Prime Minister, of all people, a man renowned for breaking his promises?

The experience of the submarine contract indicates how uncertain the situation is for the people of Newcastle who have been inadequately represented in the Parliament in seeking to ensure that they get a fair deal. The local Labor members of parliament-and all of them in that region are Labor members-have simply failed to get anything worthwhile from this Government.

DEBATE.TITLE: DEPARTMENT OF IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

I want to raise a couple of matters with respect to the annual report of the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs. First, I want to congratulate the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Robert Ray) for not having proceeded with his original intention to grant Mrs Hilaly, the wife of Imam Al Hilaly of the Lakemba Mosque, permanent residence at a time different from consideration of her husband's application. I assume that the rumours that seem to be around Sydney at the moment that something may be done by 13 December when, apparently, some significant formal occasion is to take place, will not involve any action on that front.

I want to raise once again the question of what arrangements are being made to facilitate applications to migrate to Australia of those people who have left the Eastern bloc and who will be looking for some place to settle. There is no doubt that many skilled people who would make outstanding migrants for Australia may well find that the new freedom to move that has emerged with the destruction of the Berlin Wall will provide them with an opportunity to come to a place like Australia to start a new life. I first asked Senator Ray a question along these lines some time ago when East Germans were using the escape route via Hungary. When I asked him at that stage what arrangements had been made to facilitate applications by those people-I am not necessarily saying as refugees; I mean facilitating normal applications-he responded that there were no special arrangements. I do not think I am doing him an injustice. I hope that the Government will give consideration to fixing the situation. I really believe that there is an opportunity for a major contribution to be made to Australia's migration intake by a group of highly skilled people who would fit into Australian society without major disruption to it.

I say this in the context of a table on page 19 of the Department's annual report which indicates the top 10 source countries of birth. It is interesting to note just how the numbers appear to have changed substantially. For example, the United Kingdom and Ireland remain the major sources, with something like 19.3 per cent of the total intake. New Zealand is second with 16.2 per cent. But from then on, none of the traditional sources of migrants to Australia appear in the top 10; in other words, none of the northern or southern European countries.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is an emigration from Australia to Italy now.
—There has been some kind of emigration, almost, particularly of people who are retiring and taking their social security benefits with them to some southern European countries.
—Some are going back to better opportunities.

—That is a sound point. Because of the development of Europe under the new European Community rules and the new expansion there, some are going back to better opportunities because of the downturn in economic growth in Australia and the mismanagement of this economy.
—Some of them are first and second generation Australians, too.

—That is quite right; I agree with that. It seems to me that we have an opportunity to bolster our immigration from an area that would provide major benefit to us. Frankly, we do not seem to be doing it. I ask the Government to give serious consideration to it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K. .

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to the annual report of the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, I want to address that section dealing with local government and, in the short time that is available, particularly address three of the subheadings in the report dealing with financial assistance grants, Telecom and Australia Post rates, and rationalisation of administrative functions.

SPEECH.PARA: Specifically on the question of financial assistance grants, once again this year we saw the Government change the formula for making available general purpose grants to local government because the formula which has tied local government grants to State government general purpose grants would have meant that local government got even less than it did by way of the special Act that was brought in. It was interesting to hear Senator Reynolds say in a fairly recent debate that she believed that it was better for local government grants to be tied to State government grants because Tom Uren, under the Whitlam Government, had decided that that was the way it ought to go. I thought the idea that somehow we were still living under Whitlamesque principles in the local government area was, to say the least, quite peculiar.

Quite clearly, the function of the Government has been to try to make State and local governments together wear the collective pain of a screw-down of expenditure in the pubic sector. Local government, in particular, is being made to suffer for the failure of the Hawke-Keating economic policies. So, whilst in effect in the last Budget the Federal Government effectively increased its own general purpose grants by some 5.5 per cent, local governments and State governments had their share of general purpose grants reduced. This results in councils being forced either to put up rates or else cut services. This is so despite the promises by the Hawke Government that there would be no reduction in the payment in money terms from one year to the next. The Government promised that it would provide a financially stable base from which local government would be able to plan. Quite clearly, the way the Government is operating on an ad hoc basis from year to year, simply deciding to select a sum and then introduce special legislation to make that the general purpose grant to be then distributed via the States Grants Commission, is doing nothing to provide predictable funding for local government.
On the question of Telecom Australia and Australia Post rates, I read with interest the following words in the report:

During the year, considerable attention needed to be given to the equity problems which would have arisen among councils as a result of the Government's decision in May 1988 to recoup, from 1 July 1989, 90 per cent of the local government rates to be paid by Telecom and Australia Post.
It then goes on to say:
The decision was rescinded in April 1989 following the extensive consultation with local government representatives and the Grants Commission.

The fact that the Federal Government tried to claw back the equitable decision that both Australia Post and Telecom should be obliged to pay council rates and was ultimately defeated by the pressure of local government, and others who had the interests of local government at heart, is somewhat underplayed by the simple statement in the report that the decision was rescinded. Indeed, Senator Reynolds, on the same occasion that I mentioned before, chose to claim somehow that it was a success of the Government that it had managed to defeat its own policy. I found this line of reasoning quite quaint.

The question of the rationalisation of administrative functions is also one that is worthy of comment. It does start to address, and only start to address, the problem of how a service is best delivered to the public, at what level of government, the competition that occurs between those levels of government and, indeed, the absolute need to avoid not only duplication but also triplication. Clearly, there is need for a mechanism, which the Opposition has undertaken to provide in government, to determine the best level at which a particular service can be delivered and to ensure that, whichever level of government is determined to so deliver that service, it has the resources to do that which can be predictable and long term. The resources should not be cut off or determined from above.

TALK.START.PARA: —The report covers a subject that the Waste Watch Committee, when I was Chairman of it, dealt with in some depth. It was evident at that time that there was an inordinate proportion of Commonwealth public servants retiring because of so-called invalidity. In fact, this report, which shows a considerable improvement in that situation, nonetheless still reveals that of the pensions in force on 30 June this year 37,920 resulted from age or early age retirement and almost as many, 32,713, resulted from invalidity. I think it is worth noting also that invalidity retirements in the Australian Capital Territory-that is, in the Commonwealth Public Service here in Canberra-constitute only 0.4 per 100 but in South Australia, Victoria and Tasmania the rate ranges between 0.92 and 0.96, which is more than double the rate in the ACT.

SPEECH.PARA: I have been asking over many years why there is this continued disparity in invalidity rates between the various States. Is it because public servants in the ACT live a pure, healthy and good life and are well represented in this place or is it because there is a fiddle going on in invalidity which is costing Australian taxpayers multimillions of dollars? I draw attention to the fact that, for example, in Victoria there were 620 retirements in the latest year for invalidity and only 609 people retiring because of age. In other words, there were more invalidity retirements than age retirements, whereas in New South Wales there were 987 age retirements and only 530 invalidity retirements-a little over half. In the ACT, there is the same sort of situation. There were 551 retirements as a result of age and only 250 as a result of invalidity.

We have here a curious situation persisting; in particular, it can be seen from the nature of the invalidity retirements. In New South Wales last year 72 people retired as a result of neuroses and 186 retired in Victoria as a result of neuroses--

TALK.START.PARA: —I can understand it under a Labor government.

—Exactly, there we have a Labor State government. These are Federal public servants but they obviously are being driven mad by having a Labor government there. Is it not incredible that we have so many more Commonwealth public servants working in New South Wales-79,663-and only 67,109 working in Victoria but we have at least two and a half times the number of people retiring in Victoria from neuroses than in New South Wales? Without making any comment about it, I must say that more people suffering from neuroses seem to manage to retire in Queensland than in New South Wales but it is a matter of concern that some kind of racket seems to be taking place.

SPEECH.PARA: It is also interesting to note that the next biggest item concerns disorders of the spine, known as bad backs. However, the Government's activities seem to have diminished the volume of disability retirements on that score from the ludicrous levels that existed in previous years. But it has not yet conquered this neurosis question. I wonder whether this has something to do with deliberate departmental policy to try to get rid of people. In Victoria the number of retrenchments in the latest year was 1,900-many more than in New South Wales, where the comparable figure was 1,536. It seems that the organisation is using invalidity retirement as an excuse, as a way to get rid of people, when there are large retrenchment requirements in the Commonwealth Public Service. I think it is an improper use of the system. We are being ripped off either voluntarily or involuntarily. In either case it should stop.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: PROTECTION OF MOVABLE CULTURAL HERITAGE ACT

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

This report gives us the details of the operation of the Protection of Movable Cultural Heritage Act 1986, which was designed to prevent the export from Australia of cultural items which it is believed in the national interest should not leave this country, or only under certain circumstances. Interestingly enough, the Act needs to be read with one of the treaties which is listed as paper No. 97, which I think is now not on the list for today. The treaty, which was tabled the other day, the Convention on the Means of Prohibiting and Preventing the Illicit Import, Export and Transfer of Ownership of Cultural Property 1970, is a United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation convention to which we are in the process of becoming a party. I welcome that very much.

I wish to refer only to two matters regarding cultural heritage under this Act. The first is that the report, for the first time, gives us a comprehensive list of the specific applications made for export permits. I am glad that people will now have the opportunity to note the extent to which the major applicants are in fact galleries and libraries. The main purpose of the permit deals with the export or import of items to be shown to the public in these galleries. The report draws attention to the very significant work that our major galleries do in promoting the opportunity not only for Australians to see significant overseas works of art but also for sending significant Australian works of art to reciprocal galleries and museums, which gives us a far greater exposure to these matters.

As Senator Hill said yesterday in the debate on the statement by the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans), the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, and Australian foreign policy under this Government, has been quite negligent in failing to make effective promotional use of our unique cultural identity as part of Australia's foreign relations program. I take this opportunity to draw attention to the fact that in both the arts policy and foreign affairs policy documents issued by the Opposition we make a significant commitment to the upgrading of the cultural relations branch of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade.

During this year one notable decision was made-the refusal by the Minister for the Arts, Tourism and Territories (Mr Holding) to allow a John Glover painting, the Bath of Diana, to be exported from Australia. It had been purchased by an American citizen at auction in April 1989 for $1.76m, the highest price ever paid for an Australian painting. This painting was not permitted to be exported. Such a case demonstrates the precise reason that this Act was passed. I hope that it will make people aware that, if they are seeking to purchase works of art and cultural property in Australia, it is no longer simply an open market where things can be purchased and removed at will. I hope that people will understand that.

The other point to which I wish to make reference concerns the return of the Paracas mantle to Peru by Australia. It is interesting that this mantle was returned in October. It had been improperly acquired overseas and brought to Australia. It is a wrapping cloth, a mantle, from the Paracas culture in Peru, allegedly some 2,500 years old. We made a great fuss about the return of this mantle from the Australian National Gallery, despite the fact that on 26 September 1988 the Gallery issued a statement saying that there was a case of mistaken identity and that the mantle which had been identified was not the Paracas mantle. It took another 12 months or so to work out that it was the mantle originally referred to, and it has now been returned to the Peruvian Government. As I said in a debate about cultural policy quite recently, I believe that it is important that there be some mechanism for the return of goods which have been improperly looted from their original homelands. I am glad to see that the operation of this Act now facilitates that.

I commend all of those who have been working as advisers to the Minister on this piece of legislation. It is an important piece of legislation which had the active support of the Opposition when it was introduced in 1986. I am pleased to see the success that it has had to date.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: SMOKING AND TOBACCO PRODUCTS ADVERTISEMENTS (PROHIBITION) BILL 1989

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 31 August, on motion by Senator Powell:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Only 12 private members' Bills have passed through the Federal Parliament since Federation. This one, the Smoking and Tobacco Products Advertisements (Prohibition) Bill 1989, therefore deserves close parliamentary scrutiny, especially as the Government has foreshadowed some 22 amendments. It would be utterly cynical and insulting to the democratic process to gag or guillotine legislation without adequate time for debate. However, the Opposition is conscious of the limited time available for this general business debate and some unfounded accusations of stalling. For that reason I will speak on behalf of the Opposition and place on record some of our views and concerns. A coalition government was responsible for the partial ban on the advertising of tobacco products, which has operated in this country since 1976 by virtue of section 100 of the Broadcasting Act 1942. It is clear that such limitation on the traditional freedom to advertise legal products is widely supported in this country and it is not seriously proposed that the clock should be turned back in this regard.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill in question was introduced into the Senate on 31 August and it is fair to say that it then contained a range of provisions which were unacceptable to some of my colleagues, particularly those matters which could be broadly described as relating to the non-print area such as advertising on billboards and posters, in cinemas or on perimeter signs at sporting events. We were conscious of the furore surrounding the inept handling of the Motorcycle Grand Prix issue in Victoria by the Cain Government, which eventually saw the race transferred to New South Wales. We took the view then, and we still adhere to it, that those matters were clearly within the constitutional provinces of State governments and ought to be allowed to be determined individually by them. There was also a body of concern within our own ranks that, before any legislation to introduce a total prohibition on all forms of advertising, there would need to be powerful evidence available that advertising is a significant contributing factor in the decision to take up or continue smoking.

On the basis of these legitimate concerns the coalition parties established a committee headed by Dr Michael Wooldridge, which included among its ranks a prominent New South Wales cancer specialist and member of parliament, Dr Bob Woods. The committee's brief was to consider carefully all the issues associated with this vexed question and to report back in time for this debate to proceed on an informed and considered basis. The position remained thus until earlier this week when the Government decided to support our contention that non-print matters should not be the subject of Federal legislation. We will therefore be supporting the Government's proposed amendments in this regard. However, the Government also made it plain that it was determined to support the balance of the Australian Democrats' Bill to such an extent that the second reading stage will be concluded before today is out. The Opposition regrets this unseemly haste, which can only be motivated by the imminence of the next Federal election. The Parliament is presently scheduled to resume in the second half of February next year. No time would need to have been lost by allowing ample time for debate, as the 12-month delay before the Bill comes into effect could have been shortened to take account of any additional time required to enable the normal consideration and passage of the legislation.

This Bill will be passed by the Senate and we will certainly not be seeking to obstruct its passage or to filibuster during this debate, as some commentators have wrongly, and in some cases mischievously, speculated. We are anxious, however, that the debate should proceed and decisions should be taken on the basis of fact and information rather than being driven by mere rhetoric and emotion.

I think it is now increasingly being accepted by the community and even by some inveterate smokers in our own ranks that smoking is a thoroughly unhealthy and potentially lethal practice, which is now much more socially unacceptable than it was even five years ago. It is also widely understood in the community that there is a powerful volume of evidence which demonstrates beyond reasonable doubt the health hazards of cigarette smoking. I would expect that there would be few persons above the age of reason who would not be similarly aware of such dangers. This of course does not dissuade some from taking up smoking even if only for an experimental period.

The coalition parties are also aware of strong community concerns that government should, where possible, take effective action to discourage smoking, especially among the young. No serious person can gainsay the appalling loss of life occasioned by lung cancer, heart disease and a range of other respiratory and circulatory diseases. It is by now clear that statistical evidence demonstrates that cigarette smokers are much more likely to die of these diseases than non-smokers. It follows therefore that a responsible society, which, in many instances, is required to bear the financial burden, as well as the social trauma, of the associated medical and hospital treatment, may well consider a range of interventionist actions to discourage such behaviour.

However, it does not follow that the banning of all cigarette advertising will necessarily have such an effect. The case of Norway, which has banned all forms of cigarette advertising since 1975, is often cited in this context. However, the facts of the matter are that the decrease in teenage smoking in New South Wales over the last three years is far greater than for the last 10 years in Norway. Indeed, over the last decade tobacco consumption has dropped by some 7 per cent in Norway, whereas over the last decade in Australia we have seen a massive decrease of some 24 per cent. Cause and effect is therefore always a very contentious scientific conundrum. It is therefore understandable that the latest United States Surgeon-General's report published in January this year states:

There is no scientifically rigorous study available to the public that provides a definitive answer to the basic question of whether advertising and promotion increase the level of tobacco consumption.

It was because of our serious concern to explore all aspects of the issue, especially the significance of bans on advertising and the success of anti-smoking campaigns, especially the Quit campaign in Victoria and the activities of various State health promotion foundations, that we established a Party committee to carefully consider the evidence in this area. It would have been highly desirable, and remains so, for the committee to have been able to complete its inquiries and to have reported before this debate was concluded. But it would now seem that the passage of the Bill is to be governed by the Government's election timetable.

We wish to make it quite clear that we believe that exceptional circumstances should exist before a government imposes restrictions on the advertising of a product which it is legal to sell. Indeed there are some who regard this as a very powerful issue of principle, although we are aware that there are other potentially dangerous products, such as guns and prescription drugs, the advertising of which is severely circumscribed in the public interest. In particular, we do not see any logical connection between any ban on the advertising of cigarettes, which are likely to be harmful to health even in limited quantities, and any attempt to ban or restrict the advertising of alcohol or motor vehicles, which are quite safe when used in moderation. It is to be hoped in future that any government proposal which constitutes a fundamental intrusion on traditional freedoms and which raises fundamental questions as to censorship will be proceeded with only after adequate time for consultation and debate and will not be driven principally by electoral considerations.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to advise the Government's decision to move to ban the advertising of all tobacco products in the print media. To this end, today I will be moving amendments to the Smoking and Tobacco Products Advertisements (Prohibition) Bill 1989 introduced into the Parliament by Senator Powell, I think on 31 August this year, to give effect to a ban. The Bill as presented by the Australian Democrats also contains some drafting deficiencies which the Government has sought to rectify in the amendments I will be moving. The amendments will also ensure that the Bill conforms with current Commonwealth criminal law policy. Later in the committee stage I will refer to these matters in greater detail. The Government proposes that a ban would come into effect 12 months after the legislation receives royal assent.

SPEECH.PARA: There is strong expert opinion throughout Australia and internationally that recognises the need for a ban on tobacco advertising. As long ago as 1979, a World Health Organisation expert committee recommended total prohibition of all forms of tobacco advertising. In 1987, the Sixth World Conference on Smoking and Health recommended that all forms of tobacco advertising in all media be banned in all countries. The National Health and Medical Research Council in 1980 fully supported the World Health Organisation's recommendation that there be a total prohibition on all forms of tobacco advertising. Health Ministers, at their meeting in Melbourne last month, called for governments to move towards a complete ban on all advertising of tobacco products. The Australian Medical Association (AMA) is committed to achieving a reduction in smoking with the objective of reducing disease, disability and premature death related to smoking. The AMA has recognised as essential the need for Federal action at this point to prohibit print media advertising of tobacco products. Many other professional and community organisations are fully supportive of the Government's decision to ban tobacco advertising-organisations such as the Australian Cancer Society, the National Heart Foundation and the Australian Association for Adolescent Health. There is strong community support for a ban on print media tobacco advertising generally as well.

Surveys in Western Australia in mid-1989 showed that 72 per cent of those surveyed supported a ban on tobacco advertising. Surveys in South Australia in December 1988 found that 82 per cent of those surveyed approved a ban on advertising in newspapers and magazines. Surveys in New South Wales in July of last year found that 70 per cent of those surveyed approved a complete advertising ban. Surveys in Victoria in June 1987 showed that 63 per cent of those surveyed approved an advertising ban. These surveys also show that support for legislative restrictions on advertising is strong regardless of political persuasion; indeed, it can be said that all political parties equally oppose advertising of cigarettes and smoking. Therefore, it is not an issue that divides parliaments or political parties by ideology.

We, as Australian policy makers in the Senate today, cannot ignore the unanimous opinion being expressed by many of our leading professional bodies, and the strong public support on this issue. The need to ban tobacco advertising in the print media is based on the inescapable fact that tobacco is the major preventable cause of death and disease in Australia. Another significant fact is that there is no safe level or form of tobacco use.

In 1987 tobacco contributed to the deaths of 18,000 Australians. Seventy-one per cent of drug caused deaths in Australia are attributable to tobacco-related illnesses, including approximately 75 per cent of all cases of lung cancers. Tobacco smoke contains 43 known carcinogens. The more people smoke and the longer they smoke, the greater their chances are of developing lung cancer. Overall, smokers are 10 times more likely to die from lung cancer than are non-smokers, and heavy smokers are 15 to 25 times more at risk than non-smokers. If current trends persist, lung cancer will overtake breast cancer as the commonest malignancy amongst Australian women by the early 1990s. To give another example, 75 per cent of chronic bronchitis and emphysema is attributable to smoking. Almost all smokers of more than 20 cigarettes per day show some degree of emphysema. The chronic nature of these diseases means that those who develop them may continue to live for many years with various degrees of disability. At their worst, sufferers may be bed bound, dependent on home oxygen, or even require life support systems.

To continue with the examples, 25 per cent of ischaemic heart disease is related to tobacco consumption. Smokers have a two- to four-fold greater risk of suffering sudden heart attack than non-smokers. Cigarette smoking has also been linked with cancers of the oral cavity, oesophagus and stomach. In addition to the risk of these diseases, women who smoke are placing themselves at further risk of suffering from cancers of the cervix and from complications in pregnancy. Babies born to women who smoke are, on average, smaller. Smoking while breastfeeding is also harmful. More than 20 cigarettes a day will reduce milk supply and can cause gastro-intestinal problems for babies. Babies of parents who smoke are much more likely to have chest problems and bronchial complaints during the first years of life. Australians are generally aware that smoking is bad for their health and, indeed, smoking by the general population is gradually declining. For example, in 1976 40 per cent of males and 31 per cent of females smoked, while in 1986 33 per cent of males and 29 per cent of females smoked.

It is clear from these figures, however, that male rates of smoking are declining more rapidly than rates for women. This is a matter of great concern. Young women aged between 20 and 24 years have the highest smoking rate of all Australian adult smokers, with 41 per cent of women in this age group smoking. In addition young girls aged 12 to 15 years form the group with the greatest trend of experimentation and uptake of smoking. The smoking rates among blue-collar workers are also of concern. A study of smoking rates by occupational level shows that overall, for both sexes, blue-collar workers smoke more than white-collar workers.

The most recent Australian study on the costs of smoking to the Australian economy was undertaken in 1987 by the Western Australian Health Department. The study estimated that the total economic cost of smoking-related illness in Australia is in excess of $2.5 billion per annum. Honourable senators in this chamber who are concerned with micro-economic reform know that there is a clear case that considerable savings can be made, in terms of the micro-economy, through disease prevention. The Western Australian study, to which I have referred, took into account the direct medical expenses of treating smokers, and the loss of income and productivity of individuals disabled by smoking-related illness. This estimate is conservative and the real economic cost of smoking to the community is probably far in excess of this amount.

It is clear that the Government has a responsibility to act to discourage Australians from smoking. Particularly we wish to discourage young people from starting to smoke while acting to reduce the pressures on them to do so. The banning of tobacco advertising in the print media is an important step in our continuing strategy to lower the incidence of smoking in the community. I believe the Government has a commendable record for action in this regard. Many of the initiatives we have introduced were world firsts. As to our achievements, in 1976 a ban on the advertising of cigarettes on television and radio was introduced. The ban was extended in 1988 to all tobacco products. We have been instrumental in having rotating health warnings on cigarette packets. In 1987, a ban on smoking on domestic airline flights and commuter services commenced. In 1988, Qantas Airways Ltd commenced regular smoke-free flights to New Zealand. In 1988, a ban on smoking in all federally registered coaches was introduced, and during 1988 it was followed progressively by bans in State and Territory coaches and buses. In 1988, a ban on smoking in buildings occupied by the Australian Public Service was introduced. This has since been extended to all Commonwealth buildings. In 1988 the Commonwealth announced an agreement with the tobacco manufacturers to reduce the levels of tar and nicotine in cigarettes sold in Australia to among the lowest levels in the world. A ban on the supply of smokeless tobacco products intended for oral use was introduced this year. These measures have been coordinated with State government initiatives through the Ministerial Council on Drug Strategies (MCDS). The MCDS is currently developing a national health strategy on tobacco.

At this point I would like to address what we as a government perceive as a major problem with the Australian Democrats legislation as it stands; namely, that it does not recognise the division of powers between the Commonwealth and the States in Australia's federal system. The Government will move to amend this Bill effectively to ban the advertising of tobacco products in the print media Australia-wide. There is a clear role for the Commonwealth to impose such a ban as it is extremely doubtful that a State government could effectively impose or enforce such a ban in its State, given the national character of Australia's media industry. However, the Government considers that it is not appropriate that the Commonwealth legislate regarding the forms of tobacco advertising included in the Democrats Bill, such as billboards, hoardings and walls and audio or visual announcements, including in cinemas where the States have shown that they can effectively impose bans on tobacco advertising. The Government amendments to this Bill will delete those aspects of the Bill which seek to have the Commonwealth interfere in these areas.

Several States have already acted in relation to these matters, with the encouragement and support of the Commonwealth Government. In Victoria, legislation was introduced in 1987 to prohibit cinema advertising, outdoor advertising, including billboards and unsolicited leaflets covering cigarettes, competitions and the distribution of free samples. The legislation also established the Victorian Health Promotion Foundation, which is funded by a levy of 5 per cent on wholesale tobacco sales. It funds activity relating to the promotion of good health and the prevention and early detection of disease, provides grants for research and health promotion programs and provides sponsorship to sports and the arts.

In South Australia, the Tobacco Products Control Act 1988 established the Foundation South Australia which receives a proportion of money collected as tobacco merchant licences. Financial support from the fund is provided as grants or loans to sporting and cultural bodies for any sporting, recreational or cultural activities that contribute to health. In Western Australia-I interpolate here and pay tribute to the Burke Government's Minister for Health, Barry Hodge, who, in many respects, is a pioneer in this form of legislation-legislation similar to that in Victoria and South Australia has been introduced into the Parliament. New South Wales, Queensland and Tasmania have entered into voluntary arrangements with tobacco companies to restrict the marketing of tobacco products. The States and Territories have also continued to conduct a wide variety of `quit' campaigns all aimed at increasing awareness of the dangers of tobacco consumption and reducing smoking rates in the community.

I have already referred to the high rates of smoking and experimentation with smoking among respectively young women and teenage girls. Early next year, the Minister for Community Services and Health, Dr Blewett, will be launching a $2m national print and television media campaign targeting a reduction in smoking by young women. The campaign will target women in the 12 to 15 and 20 to 24 year age groups. The 12 to 15 year age group shows the greatest trend towards experimentation and uptake of smoking, and women in the 20 to 24 year age group have the highest smoking rates in Australia. The campaign strategy has been designed to complement anti-smoking activities already in place in the States and Territories. A number of States have run anti-smoking activities for several years and have well-developed school and community programs, as well as cessation services.

An anomaly exists in the advertising of tobacco products, which I have already said has been banned in the electronic media since 1976, but which has continued in the print media. The Government believes that the time has come to correct this anomaly. The Government will allow a 12-month period prior to the ban becoming law to allow the print and advertising industries a reasonable period of adjustment. If the experience of the banning of tobacco advertising on radio and television is an indicator, however, there should be little impact on industry of such a ban.

In 1988, expenditure by tobacco companies for all national advertising in Australia was estimated to be about $40m, of which approximately 58 per cent, or $27m, was spent in the metropolitan press and 25 per cent, or $10m, in magazines. This represents less than 2 per cent of all print media advertising expenditure which has been estimated at a total of $2.2 billion. The approximately $10m spent on tobacco advertising in magazines represents less than 5 per cent of the estimated $204m spent on all advertising in magazines. It is interesting to note, however, that about 60 per cent of tobacco advertising expenditure in magazines is in women's magazines.

The Government believes that there is sufficient evidence of a link between tobacco advertising and the uptake of smoking to justify our action in this matter. Advertising alters the way cigarettes are perceived. It changes the image of cigarettes from a harmful, addictive drug to symbols of wealth, glamour, success and healthy good looks. A major research study of children in New South Wales, reported in the international Journal of Epidemiology in 1983, found that children who approved of cigarette advertising were twice as likely to smoke as those who disapproved of such advertising. Generally, children who held favourable attitudes to smoking and cigarette advertising were at greater risk of adopting or maintaining smoking behaviour than those whose attitudes were more disapproving. This report went on to recommend that tobacco advertising be banned.

A 1980 survey of school children in Perth found that over 80 per cent of children considered that cigarette advertisements probably encourage children to take up smoking. The study also showed that there was a positive association between liking a particular advertising and the use of a particular brand. A 1980 survey of secondary school children in Sydney found a similar correlation between the most heavily advertised brands and the use of these brands. A recent study by the National Health and Medical Research Council, the major health advisory body to governments in Australia, suggested that attempts to prevent the uptake of smoking by children are unlikely to be effective while cigarette advertising is still permitted.

A number of countries have banned tobacco advertising, including Norway, Canada, Finland, Italy, Portugal, Singapore and Ireland. In Norway, a total ban on cigarette advertising has been in effect since 1974. Detailed research has shown substantial falls in smoking among adolescents since the ban was introduced. This positive trend was ascribed to legislation removing advertising which had created pressure on young people to smoke, to the special attention paid to smoking by girls, and to the change in general attitudes towards smoking and smoking behaviour among adults and young people.

The Government has decided that the time has now come in Australia to act to stop tobacco advertising in the print media. At this point may I congratulate those sections of the media who have been prepared to analyse critically the health issues relating to tobacco advertising and to voice their support for a government ban. Print media advertising is a national issue and one on which it is unlikely that any State or Territory could effectively deal with, acting alone.

In conclusion, there is ample evidence of a link between tobacco advertising and the uptake of smoking to justify a print media ban on strong public health grounds. I have gone through those grounds in some detail. It is imperative that the Government acts now to discourage Australians from smoking and, particularly, to reduce pressures on young people to take up smoking in the first place. While I commend the Australian Democrats' initiative, the Government will move the amendments that I have foreshadowed when we reach the committee stage. We support the second reading of this Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I thank Senator Alston, who spoke on behalf of the Opposition, and the Minister for Resources, Senator Cook, who spoke for the Government, for their contributions to this debate. Senator Alston outlined the concerns of the Opposition and informed us of the work of the committee which was established over the past few weeks to address those concerns. Senator Cook gave the Senate a most comprehensive and researched historical and scientific rundown.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Democrats believe that the passage of the Smoking and Tobacco Products Advertisements (Prohibition) Bill 1989, in its amended form, will be one of the most positive results of some 20 years of activism and hard work by health groups and anti-tobacco activists in our community. The peak bodies-in particular, the Australian Medical Association, the National Heart Foundation, the Australian Cancer Society, the Doctors Reform Society-as well as their constituent bodies, including many royal colleges in the health field, Action on Smoking and Health and a wide range of health and community groups, have, for many years, come in behind the legislation for which, as Senator Cook has said, the time does seem to have come.

At this point I emphasise that the Democrats see this piece of legislation as a result of the work of those groups. I want to add to the list that I have spoken about-it is by no means comprehensive; but we do not have time to be comprehensive about it-a former member of my staff, Mr Peter Allen, who has been a long time activist in these groups and who was instrumental in the original drawing up of this legislation. That work has been consistent, as I have said, for many years and that battle has been taken up in the Senate by the Australian Democrats since 1977.

I acknowledge the work of my colleagues, both present and former Democrat senators. Regrettably, most of their initiatives to this point have not received enough support in the Parliament for passage. Some individuals in the Parliament have been very public supporters of the kinds of initiatives which we have moved in this place, notably Senator Peter Baume and the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett), who is represented here by Senator Cook-but, regrettably, not enough to have had our initiatives made successful.

There has not been such a significant parliamentary initiative as this since the electronic advertising ban in 1976, a ban which, we should remember, was implemented under the Fraser coalition Government. In recent years, as Senator Cook has said, there has been a strengthening of public opinion, through increased knowledge and understanding of the realities of this situation, and that has led to the development of certain Government-related initiatives, which Senator Cook has outlined and which have been reflected in the wider community in an increase in the number of smoke-free areas in workplaces, in public places, in aircrafts, in restaurants and so on.

In that environment we have also seen the States acting. As Senator Cook has also outlined, my own State of Victoria has a proud record in this regard. I had the pleasure a couple of weeks ago of attending the second birthday celebration of the Victorian Health Promotion Foundation at which the Victorian Premier, John Cain, actually wished this legislation well. So I am sure he is very pleased with what is happening here today. In South Australia, too, the legislators have been pioneers to the extent that the States have been able to act. I was disturbed to read that in Western Australia State legislation has been brought forward but was actually blocked in the conservative upper House. I hope that the enlightenment of their Federal colleagues will prompt the Western Australian upper House to move on that legislation. Tasmania is drafting legislation. The change of government in Queensland has brought with it a commitment to like legislation, but there seems to be a major blockage in New South Wales.

Earlier this year, the Joint Parliamentary Committee on the National Crime Authority put down its report Drugs and Crime in Society. In that report there was a recommendation with regard to advertising bans on alcohol and tobacco. That Committee recommendation was dissented from by the coalition members of that Committee, who said: `We would support a ban on tobacco advertising, but we are not satisfied that a ban on the advertising of alcohol products is justified'. Senator Alston has reiterated that point here today. It was upon the release of the Joint Committee report that we decided that it would be timely-given the change of public opinion, the movement in the States and that report, which pointed to cross-party support for a ban at least on the advertising of cigarettes and tobacco products-to introduce into this place a piece of legislation which would enact such a ban. We announced our intention to do so in about May and this Bill was introduced on 31 August. We wanted to give time for consideration by both the Government and the Opposition.

I express at this point our disappointment that the Government has not been prepared to go all the way with the total provisions of the Australian Democrats Bill. In our view, it is important that national government takes a lead. We believe that the Government should, on this occasion, be prepared to use the corporations power across the board. However, the Government has not agreed with us. That position has also been taken by the Opposition. Therefore, we will be accepting the Government's amendments with reluctance and disappointment, because it is clear that we cannot always rely on the States to act as speedily as we would want them to.

However, there are positive signs and, as I say, a change of government in Queensland is the latest of those. I hope that the passage of this legislation will move the upper House in Western Australia and the New South Wales Government. I note that the Minister for Health in New South Wales has expressed his support for a ban on advertising tobacco products. I simply hope that this strengthens his arm against that of his less enlightened Premier. This is an obvious area, for all the reasons that Senator Cook has outlined, for action in national leadership. This is an action that requires all-party support. Tobacco use costs this country $2 1/2 billion and more on an annual basis. Every year in Australia 70,000 teenagers become regular smokers. Each day, more than 500 Australian school children smoke their first cigarette. Three-quarters of adults who smoke started smoking when they were adolescents. If our present smoking trends continue, over 2,500 boys and 159,000 girls who are under the age of 14 now will die before their time because they have smoked. The younger children start smoking, the more likely they are to die of smoking related diseases. There have been a great many other statistics and facts put down in this debate by Senator Cook. Conscious of the time of the Senate at this difficult time of year, I just ask the Senate to recall those. I believe that those facts have moved people on both sides of the chamber, including the committee which the Opposition has set up to investigate this issue.

In spite of our disappointment with the Government's restrictions on a ban, the print ban which will be in place with the passage of this Bill, as amended, will really be a major step forward. In fact, it is probably the most significant public health measure that has been taken by this Parliament for a very long time. It is preventive action. Preventive health measures are a matter of strong Australian Democrats policy. This is consistent with Government moves towards better health for the community. It is appropriate action for a coalition which made the last major step in this area under Malcolm Fraser. Therefore, as I said, we are accepting the Government's amendments to our Bill.

I, too, would like to commend those involved in the media on their performance, particularly in recent weeks, on this issue. I especially commend the print media and journalists in particular-not just the journalists, but also the other people involved. It was certainly a pleasure to read in the Melbourne Age this morning support for the moves that are to be made in this Parliament. After declaring an interest in revenue and expressing concerns about bans on any kind of advertising, the newspaper went on to say that this was a matter of principle rather than of profit. That really encapsulates the sort of approach that has been taken here today, one which we had hoped when we introduced the Bill in August would be taken eventually, and one which we commend. We urge upon the Senate a speedy passage for this Smoking and Tobacco Products Advertisements (Prohibition) Bill 1989.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
