TALK.START.PARA: —I have a question for the Minister for Resources (Senator Cook) with regard to the section of the Government's amendments which relates to the commencement; that is proposed clause 2, under amendment No. 1, which points out that the Act commences on the first day after the end of the period of 12 months beginning on the day on which it receives the royal assent. We believe it is important that royal assent should be sought as soon as possible; there should be no delay to this. Can the Minister enlighten us as to the Government's intentions on this score?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I appreciate the anxiety of Senator Powell on this matter. The anxiety would in the normal course arise from the fact, of course, that the House of Representatives has risen for all intents and purposes for the summer recess. I am not 100 per cent sure on this point but I do believe that the House of Representatives is to be recalled on 20 or 21 December and will have a very short sitting period. If that is the case, it would be the Government's intention to refer this Bill to the House, should it meet all stages in the Senate, and ask the House to deal with it. My normal expectation would be that it would do so within the time frame set for its sitting.

SPEECH.PARA: That then leaves open the question of how long it takes to get between the House and the Governor-General for royal assent. My advice on that is that it is a matter of routine printing time and there is no intention to delay that in any form, other than the normal holiday period observed in Australia over the Christmas-New Year period. So, I cannot put a definite time on when it might be given royal assent because there are too many presumptions of passage. But I can give an undertaking that it is the Government's intention to move as expeditiously as possible. Once the Bill is proclaimed, then that 12-month clock begins to tick before the effect of the legislation comes into force.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would just like to raise with the Minister for Resources (Senator Cook) the question of imported printed material, magazines and so on, not necessarily only those that are mailed to people but those that are American, British or European magazines that are sold on newsstands and may habitually carry in their country of origin advertisements for tobacco products and cigarette companies. Could he clarify the position, first of all, with regard to those magazines that are mailed directly from one country to a subscriber in Australia and, secondly, those magazines where the publisher is based in another country but the magazine is sold on the newsstands here?

—Amendment 12 provides that the ban would not apply to a print medium printed outside of Australia and not principally intended for distribution within Australia. `Not principally intended' I think are important words. This amendment moved by the Government replaces the existing clause 7 in the Bill that Senator Powell has moved, with this new clause. I go to clause 7 of the Bill and summarise what it does. That clause confers on the Minister of the day power to make a judgment with respect to this class of publication, and thus it would be a decision of the government of the day. The difference between what is proposed by Senator Powell and what the Government is proposing to do by way of amendment is that publications imported into Australia but not principally intended for distribution within Australia would be exempted from the advertising ban, and I think the important element is `not intended for distribution within Australia'.

—Without wanting to split hairs on that, I think that what the Minister said is pretty much correct. I just wonder whether there is any possibility that it could be interpreted to mean that a document, newspaper or magazine which is intended for distribution on a global basis would not be caught even if the bulk of the mailing found its way into Australia. Does the Minister regard that as being so?

—I have relied on citing, for my opinion, the words that are in our amendment-`not principally intended for distribution in Australia'. I decline to accept the implicit invitation in what Senator Alston has put to make a judgment about world publications because it may be that, were I to express myself on that, that would be too narrowly or too broadly, defining the meaning of the words `principally intended for distribution in Australia'. Since my remarks could be adduced for evidence in any court proceeding that may have to define that question, and for the other very good reason that I am not fully instructed on this point, I think it is wise for me to simply say `not principally' as I think that is the significant term in that section of the amendment.

—I am indebted to the Minister, and I think what we probably all agree on is that one cannot give a definitive interpretation on words such as those. But in terms of general principle, I presume what is intended is to avoid this being used as a loophole by simply printing offshore and then sending the stuff back.
—Yes.

—So as long as one cannot deduce an intention on the part of the corporation to somehow circumvent prohibitions by printing offshore, then the fact that the bulk of it might come back here would not necessarily be conclusive of an evil intent. Would that be a fair assessment?

—Let me hypothesise-a risky exercise, I admit, but let me try. If it were the Australian magazine for the Society for the Prevention of Outer Space, or some such thing, and printed in Hong Kong, it would clearly be for circulation in Australia and targeted at Australia, and therefore it would observe, and need to observe, I believe, the prohibitions in this Bill. It is possible to speculate about newspapers or magazines not principally intended for distribution in Australia but which are consumed by Australians or which are purchasable from Australia, and in those cases the prohibition would not apply.

—For example, if something like the Far Eastern Economic Review, which may or may not-I do not know-currently be printed in Australia for the Australian market, were to be then only printed in South East Asia, the fact that it was intended for general circulation throughout the region and then came back into Australia would not make it principally intended for distribution here, I would have thought, consistent with what the Minister said.

—I know insufficient about the Far Eastern Economic Review, its publication, marketing and target audience, to be able to make a judgment about it in relation to this provision. So, with all due respect to Senator Alston, I would decline to speculate about a specific magazine.

—I know the rednecks will go a long way, but I hope they do not want to ban outer space just yet. I think that creating a possible loophole is the matter that Senator Alston has drawn attention to. It is clear that this is what he means. Possibly, what the Minister is saying is that the words `principally intended for distribution or use in Australia' should be `not intended for distribution or use principally in Australia'. I think possibly the word `principally' is in the wrong place. It seems to me that that would give more clarity to the effect that both Senator Alston and the Minister are seeking.

—I caught the first part of Senator Coulter's comment. I too hope that there is no ban on outer space, but I am aware of groups like the Flat Earth Society and other such organisations and they, in our democracy, have a right to exist and consume their own literature as long as they do not put cigarette advertising into their publications, once this Bill is passed.
—The Society just lapsed in Queensland.

—I acknowledge Senator Macklin's interjection in the hope that it goes on the record. I think if the words `not principally' were excluded so that that provision read `intended for distribution in Australia', we might impose upon our Customs agents at the point of entry into Australia of overseas passengers or people bringing literature in from overseas an intolerable strain and an impossible law and one that would be observed in the breach. If that is the correction that Senator Coulter was suggesting might be considered by the Government, we would decline it.

-I do not wish to get involved in this matter of where the word `principally' should be. I agree with the Minister on the item. It seems to me that the Times of London is not printed principally for Australians but it should be available here, as should other newspapers and magazines. My question is with regard to amendment No. 18, in which the Government is seeking to change the penalty from $60,000 to $12,000. As the Minister will be aware, we have had quite a number of debates in this place over penalties. At various stages in the past we have even had promises from the Government that we would have a comprehensive and consistent policy with regard to penalties. That has not yet been forthcoming. I wonder what the Minister might be seeking to do in moving the penalty from $60,000 to $12,000? Presumably he is trying to link it to something else, but since there is not a consistent policy yet enunciated by the Government with regard to penalties, I wonder what precisely he is referring it to.
—I am advised that I am referring, by virtue of this amendment, to the modification of the terms of the proposed Bill to make it consistent with the Government's criminal law policy.
—You haven't got one in terms of penalty.

—In terms of penalties I am advised that this amendment would bring the Bill into consistency with existing practice. I am straying well out of my area in making this comment; but it may be that this has not been articulated sufficiently well in Senator Haines's view. My advice is that this amendment will in fact bring the Bill into conformity with that policy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: -I think the Minister is referring to a policy which, to my knowledge, does not exist. If it does exist, I think he ought to tell a number of the committees of this place, which are constantly having to grapple with the problem that there is no policy from the Government. It announced years ago that it would present a policy on penalties to the Parliament so that we could have consistency. One item in most of the laws we pass here, shoved down the back, is the whammy that if one breaks this law, this is what one gets. The penalties are currently all over the place. There is a most extraordinary range of penalties, many of which are not consistently updated. It was the Government's intention, certainly, to present a policy. By the way, this goes back to when Senator Gareth Evans was Attorney-General and he actually promised this, so it is a fair while ago now.

SPEECH.PARA: I have raised this matter at various stages and I have had promises from a whole variety of Ministers: `The thing is coming, hold your breath'. Luckily, we did not do that or we would have had a lot of problems. As this is now referring to the policy which I am glad to see is in existence but as yet is being kept under wraps, might it be possible for the Minister to talk to the Attorney-General and inform the Parliament that the Government in fact now has a policy? Could it actually table that policy? I am quite sure that Senator Alston, amongst others, would be absolutely fascinated by the fact that the Government at last has come up with a policy on penalties.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am now in a state of enhanced enlightenment about the policy. I must say that I am glad that Senator Macklin did not hold his breath from Senator Gareth Evans's day; although at least he would not have died from smoking if he had! The policy is based on determining a fine of a sufficiently harsh level which is appropriate to the offence. The fine is based on a determination of a figure of $12,000 as appropriate for a natural person. It is believed, and the policy dictates, that the appropriate penalty therefore for a corporation is five times that figure.
—I do not want to put the Minister for Resources (Senator Cook) through too many more mental gymnastics, but I would like him to explain--
—That was a Gilbert and Sullivan policy on penalties that he just enunciated.
—We always knew that the Government had a Gilbert and Sullivan policy on penalties.
—May the penalty fit the crime.

—I am about to find out whether in fact the penalty fits the crime in this case and to identify exactly what the crime is. The Minister is assuring us that $12,000 is sufficient for a breach rather than the $60,000 which was originally suggested. Can the Minister say on what sort of incident that $12,000 penalty is incurred? For example, if the Murdoch press decided to breach the Act by publishing a tobacco advertisement in every second copy of the Australian or the Adelaide News, does $12,000 apply as a one-off penalty for the entire edition or does it apply to each of the newspapers in which the advertisement appears?

—If I understand all of the questions raised by Senator Haines, and if I be tolerant of the element of burlesque that is creeping into this debate, the question is whether the publication of each individual copy is a separate offence or whether the publication of the whole output is the offence. The answer is that the publication of the whole output is the offence. There will not be separate offences for each particular copy of the same publication that is produced.
—It is not much of a disincentive.
—Frankly, I think it is a significant disincentive because not only will the publishing house be prosecuted and fined--
—Which they don't seek.
—Yes; I think that there is a significant disincentive there.

—On the face of it amendment No. 8 seems to proceed a bit beyond the original provisions of the Bill. Could the Minister enlighten the Committee as to whether it is intended that things such as tickets for sporting events would be covered by that prohibition and, perhaps, even annual reports and similar material which do not seem to be covered in the original Bill?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —This amendment contains three definitions. The definition which Senator Alston may be concerned about is that of print medium which states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . `print medium' means a newspaper, handbill, program, ticket or other printed document, but does not include a document displayed as a poster;

The passage of this amendment would prohibit cigarette advertising on anything defined as print media, although a question does arise. Let us take a non-tobacco example, the Fosters Melbourne Cup-if that is what it is called; not being a horse racing fan I am not entirely sure that that is what it is called, but I think I have seen some reference of that sort. Does something termed the Fosters Melbourne Cup or, to take another example, the Benson and Hedges Second Test, constitute advertising in terms of this Bill? My advice is that that, in itself, would not constitute advertising, but if the other side of a ticket bore an advertisement for a product, that would. Merely to call something the Benson and Hedges Second Test would not be an offence under this definition.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are saying that is a generic name, are you?
—Yes.
—I also asked a question in relation to annual reports. I further ask whether the Government takes the view that the provisions of amendment No. 8 go beyond the provisions of the original Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not believe that they do. Clause 3 of the original Bill sets out a series of interpretations as to advertisements, which then refers to clause 5. Clause 5 of the Australian Democrats' Bill includes a list of things which are explicitly not included in the amendment. Billboards and hoardings are two examples that crop up in the Democrats' Bill. My understanding is that the Government's proposed clause falls short of that and explicitly does not include the extent of the Democrats' proposed ban on advertising. Our amendment contains a more narrow drawing of the definition.

SPEECH.PARA: Having explained that point, I refer to my speech in the second reading debate in which, on behalf of the Government, I made a strong case for something to be done about these things, too. The reason why the Government thinks it is appropriate to go this far, but not as far as the Democrats' original Bill proposed to go, is to maintain the balance that is necessary in a federal system between what the States should do and what their rights and obligations are, and the rights and obligations of the Commonwealth. The Government's view is to encourage the States to take action in that area as appropriate, complementary action to that which we are taking here.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take it from that that, when a document displayed as a poster is specifically excluded, and billboards and hoardings are not, it is because the Government takes the view that they are clearly not the type of material with which it wants to deal. In other words, the overall philosophy is to draw a demarcation point between print and other material. I think the logic behind that is that there is some material that is distributed nationally-such as newspapers and magazines-which the Government would say needs to be dealt with on a national basis; whereas billboards, posters and hoardings can be dealt with by each State. If that is correct, I would have thought that either billboards and hoardings could have been tacked on so as not to be included in that definition of print medium, or else the explanation must be that it is so obvious that they could not possibly be included. Is it the latter?
—Yes, Senator Alston has accurately summed up the position.
—The only remaining matter concerns annual reports. Does the Minister have a view about them?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take it that the question on annual reports raised by Senator Alston is whether an annual report published by a company for distribution to its shareholders and those with an interest in its activities could contain an advertisement. I believe it would be an offence under these amendments if an annual report contained an explicit advertisement. However, naturally, the Rothmans company, for example, would produce its annual report in Australia. To support my view I turn to page 2 of the amendments moved by me which states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . `publish' does not include communicate to a person in the tobacco trade or in a tobacco product trade;

I understand that to mean quite clearly that, of course, participants in the tobacco trade-companies or businesses operating in the tobacco trade-can publish documents associated with their industry and trade, but those documents shall not include advertising of the product.

TALK.START.PARA: —If the term `publish' is not to include communication to a person in the trade, is the Government, therefore, taking the view that the circulating of the annual report is to persons not in the trade and, therefore, one goes back to the definition of `print medium', so that no annual report could contain anything other than, perhaps, the name of the company?

—It could also contain other matters appropriate to an annual report, but an annual report would not have on the front or back covers, or, interleaved somewhere between the two, an advertisement promoting the product.
—I presume the Minister's answer in relation to tickets to sporting events would apply equally to theatre tickets and programs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments agreed to.
Bill reported with amendments; report adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill (on motion by Senator Powell) read a third time.
Motion (by Senator Cook) agreed to.
That further consideration of General Business pursuant to Sessional Order be not further proceeded with.

DEBATE.TITLE: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT BILL (No. 4) 1989TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT BILL (No. 5) 1989INCOME TAX (INTERNATIONAL AGREEMENTS) AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1989

PROCTEXT.PARA: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT BILL (No. 5) 1989
Consideration resumed.
Clauses 36 to 42.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday during the second reading debate on the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5) 1989 there was quite some discussion by me and others on this side of the chamber with regard to the Government bringing forward a company tax proposal that is particularly relevant to clause 36. I want to raise the matter again. Honourable senators will be aware that until August of this year companies with a tax liability of $1,000 or more paid their tax in four instalments spread over the year following the income year. The Government decided that it would change that-we gather for the specific purpose of raising a one-off huge leap in revenue and, hence, in the size of the surplus.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government announced in the Budget that new arrangements would be made whereby the quarterly tax payments would be replaced by a new tax system. Under that new system all companies were required to pay 85 per cent of their notional tax in a single instalment due 15 days after the end of the income period relevant to them. For those companies that meant that 15 days after 30 June they were expected to produce 85 per cent of the tax that they owed to the Government, with the remaining 15 per cent being paid nine months later. The Government, presumably under pressure from business organisations and from businesses themselves or just simply because it had a sudden rush of blood to the head, decided that a little commonsense was in order and decided to change this requirement last month.

On 2 November Mr Keating announced the first of the changes that the Government was to make to this procedure which would have raised quite significantly the amount of tax that had to be paid to the Government before this new procedure came into effect. A little later-in fact, only quite recently-the Government went even further by increasing absolutely the threshold for the next financial year so that it increased a threshold that had gone from $1,000 to $20,000 by a further $380,000 and announced that the new threshold would be $400,000. That would apply for the coming transitional year only and, after that, it would drop back to $20,000 as the absolute limit. In another place the Opposition spokesperson on these matters said some extremely sensible things with regard to what this particular legislation was likely to do to small business and indicated that the Opposition would be moving an amendment that would increase the threshold below which the new proposal did not operate. On 22 November in the taxation legislation debate, Dr Hewson said:
In my earlier remarks I drew attention to our decision-
that is, the Opposition's decision-
to amend this Bill in a couple of important respects. In particular, I referred to the fact that I had announced our position by way of press release on this Bill before this debate got under way. I-
that is, Dr Hewson-

read into the record a second reading amendment to that effect which was designed to draw attention to two major deficiencies of the Bill. I foreshadowed that if time allowed, and we were not prevented by the guillotine, at the committee stage I would move the details of those amendments. In all seriousness, given the considerable plight of small business in current circumstances in Australia, I would strongly urge the Government to look at those second reading and committee stage amendments and if possible pick them up, particularly the amendment that relates to the increase in the threshold in which the new instalment arrangements will apply. We-
that is, the Opposition parties-

have identified that as consistent with roughly a taxable income of $200,000 per year or a tax payable amount of about $80,000 a year which is roughly four times the Government's threshold. I put it to the Government that there is an urgent need on the part of the small to medium sized business. I urge the Government to respond favourably to our initiative. To my mind this is the minimum immediate relief that is required in order to minimise the damage done by this Bill from the point of view of the small to medium size business sector. I seek to emphasise that it is the minimum immediate relief required.
He then went on to point out that the Opposition did not like the decision at all and also went on to discuss matters relating to the self-assessment part of this legislation.

The Australian Democrats said at the time that this amendment was moved some weeks ago that we would support it if it were moved as we, and members of the press who contacted me, assumed it would be moved in the Senate. Speaking on this Bill yesterday I made an incorrect assumption that this was a Bill that was not amendable by the Senate; that it was a Bill to which only a request for amendment could be made to the House of Representatives. I have been advised by our ever vigilant Clerks that this is not the case and that it is an amendable Bill. I think that it is worth while pointing out that the Government's amendment relating to the transitional year will certainly alleviate the problems facing small businesses which may well be forced to borrow money in order to meet the 85 per cent requirement for the next financial year. It will not, however, help those people who have to face up to that payment in subsequent financial years.

I do not know why the Government chose this particular figure of $400,000. I do not know why it brought it in for a transitional year only. The Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) might be able to tell me whether he assumes that that year will give small and medium businesses sufficient opportunity to save up, as it were, the money that they need to pay the 85 per cent requirement 28 days-which is the other amendment that the Government moved-after the end of their income year. If that is the assumption I would like to know on what evidence that assumption is based because in my experience and my discussions with small business proprietors they are certainly not anticipating a sufficient improvement in economic conditions in this country to make the 1991-92 financial year a better proposition for them than this financial year or the one after that-that is, the financial year just gone or the one that is about to end. It seems to me that all that the Government has done by moving this amendment, which has provided some relief for the 1990-91 financial year, is to move the burden 12 months down the track. It is for that reason that I think it is worthwhile that the Hewson amendment be moved in this place.

The House is coming back, as we all know, on the 20th and 21st of this month. It has other matters to deal with and I ask the Minister to consider seriously the fact that there will be no significant financial impact on the Government in the long term from the passage of this amendment, but it will certainly provide significant benefits for small businesses in both the short and the long term. If the Government wants to review it some time down the track when the economic circumstances of the country generally have improved, when small businesses' cash flow is not as tight as it is, when the capacity for lending institutions to lend the sort of money that would be required if large numbers of small businesses were forced to borrow were a little better, perhaps the figures could be reduced to the $20,000 that is currently in the legislation for financial years subsequent to the next one.

But in the meantime, with the Treasurer pointing out that he believes there is no end in sight to the situation of high interest rates-which in itself makes even worse the prospect of tens of thousands of small businesses being forced to borrow for that 85 per cent in the financial year after next-the Government cannot see its way clear to accepting the amendment that Dr Hewson moved in another place and to relieving small businesses; that is, those whose notional tax is $80,000 and whose profit, therefore, is in the region of $200,000. If Dr Hewson's amendment were adopted, small businesses would not be forced, within 28 days of the end of the financial year, to find 85 per cent of the tax owing to the Government. I would have thought that it would not make an enormous financial difference to the Government, and it would certainly stop at least some small businesses going to the wall and others from having to increase their debt burden in order to meet the requirements for payment under the Act. I move:
Page 23, clause 36, proposed paragraph 221au (1) (b), line 21, leave out ``$20,000'', insert ``$80,000''.

TALK.START.PARA: —For the purpose of the debate, can the Minister explain in detail what he regards as the extent of the transitionary arrangements?

—The transitionary arrangement is for one year. The Government is not going to accept the amendment Senator Haines has moved, for the reasons that I gave this morning. Senator Haines has the luxury of being able to drop in and out of the chamber when she feels like it. I have to stay here all the time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stone Sen J.O.

TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I must say that, while I am not normally noted for my sympathy with the Australian Democrats, the Minister's response on that point left a little to be desired in terms of courtesy. On speaking to the Democrats' amendment to clause 36, let me say that I saw this amendment for the first time at about a quarter past 10 this morning. To be quite fair, it is true that the possibility of such an amendment was foreshadowed yesterday morning by Senator Haines. In that sense, perhaps, Senator Haines could say that I had 24 hours in which to think about it.

SPEECH.PARA: One point that concerns me a little about the technical aspect of the amendment is that it is an amendment to a single clause to change the exemption limit for the continuing period of the Bill as distinct from the transitional year from $20,000 to $80,000. It is not clear to me that in such a complex Bill there would not be some consequentials of that, so to speak, elsewhere in the Bill, which may not have been attended to. I am not saying that there are, but in very complex tax legislation of this kind one often finds that when one alters something in one place one has to--

TALK.START.PARA: —We do not think so.
—The Minister says that he does not think so.
—But we will not guarantee it.

—He does not think so, but he will not guarantee it. I take whatever assurance from that that the Minister is disposed to give me, which is, by the sound of it, not a great deal. I therefore restate my feeling of some concern on that point. But let me come now to the substance, as distinct from the technicalities, of the amendment. I came into the chamber in the middle of Senator Haines's remarks, and I may not have fully comprehended them, but I think she was saying that this proposal is based upon the proposal that was put forward in the other place by Dr Hewson at one point of the debate before the Government had, in fact, decided to make the change in the threshold in respect of the transitional year which it subsequently did make and which is now incorporated in the Bill before us.

SPEECH.PARA: It is important to note that Senator Haines's amendment would put into the law on a continuing basis the increased threshold which the Opposition at one stage was talking about and which stimulated the Government to revise its views. That may very well be appropriate in the long run, but, as Dr Hewson said in his speech in the second reading debate in the House of Representatives, the Government having finally come to the party in relation to the transitional year in effect removed the immediate concern in respect of 1989-90 and 1990-91. Of course, before we come into 1991 there will be a change of government; we are quite confident of that. We have given an undertaking to review these proposals in their entirety at that stage. On the basis of that, the Opposition does not propose to support this amendment moved by the Democrats on the grounds that the immediate concern, in respect of the transitionary year, has already been attended to-admittedly belatedly-by the Government. So far as the post-transitional years are concerned, we propose to examine the whole situation in six months or so.
Amendment negatived.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek a further clarification from the Minister. I realise that the transitionary period is to be 12 months, but what range of income levels in regard to categories does he regard the transitionary period as applicable to?

—If I am wrong in this I will ask the officials to correct me afterwards. The transitionary period applies to tax liability of less than $400,000, which is a taxable income of approximately $1m. Any taxable income that falls below $1m in round figures is covered by the transitional arrangement.

—I was referring to the other arrangements that have been made in relation to the very small companies with a tax liability of $1,000 and under. Are they regarded as transitional or are they permanent?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Any company with a tax liability of less than $20,000 or a taxable income of around $50,000 is permanently exempt from the provision as the Bill currently stands.

SPEECH.PARA: Clauses agreed to.
Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8 p.m.
Remainder of Bill-by leave-taken together.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to continue the remarks I was making in the earlier part of the day concerning clauses 43 and 49 of the Bill which deal with superannuation contributions tax. I refer again to the letter from Marshall Perron, the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory, to the Treasurer (Mr Keating) concerning undertakings given by the Treasurer to the States and Territories. Mr Perron states in his letter that the amendments are in breach of the undertakings given. I said earlier that the last paragraph of Mr Perron's letter asks for a review of the amendments before they became law so that the earlier commitment may be honoured. Can the Minister say whether or not any review has taken place? What is his answer to the matters raised by Mr Perron?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Bishop raised this issue before lunch today. As I said at the time, it is a complicated matter. The officers have prepared a quick, tentative response, if you like, because they have not had the text of what Senator Bishop said and because it was a very long letter. I will read into the record their response based on their understanding of what Senator Bishop said. The special measure to provide an exemption from contributions taxed for certain last minute employer superannuation contributions is in recognition of the administrative arrangements of some superannuation schemes that operate on a partially or wholly unfunded basis. The measure is designed to provide the same tax treatment as if a benefit equal to the last minute contribution was paid direct to the member by the employer. The amendment to the measure proposed by this Bill is necessary to ensure that the measure is not used to avoid tax. I interpolate that the Government makes no apology for that.

SPEECH.PARA: It is significant that no complaint has been received from any State government or other public sector fund. That, of course, excludes the Northern Territory. Indeed, in discussions with Treasury officials the reaction to the amendment has been generally favourable. If a pre-July 1988 funding credit is not available for a particular member or members, the same result as that given by the exempting provision could be obtained by paying the last minute employer contributions direct to the fund member. In the majority of situations, the proposed amendment will not create difficulties for funds that want to take advantage of the measure. In the remaining cases, any difficulties may easily be overcome by a change in administrative practices. If Senator Bishop wants to look at the written response that I have just read into the record, she is quite welcome to do so.

TALK.START.PARA: —Two things occur to me as a result of that. The first is that the letter from the Chief Minister is dated 21 November. Secondly, can the Minister tell me whether the Treasurer (Mr Keating) or his Department has answered that letter? If not, why not?

—As far as I know, the letter has not been answered. The twenty-first of November was the date of dispatch, I presume, so we are now 16 days from the date of dispatch. As far as I know, it has not been answered. From my own experience, rarely are substantive letters answered in as short a period as that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K. .

TALK.START.PARA: —I bothered to get out a copy of the press release of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) of 11 August 1988 when these matters were dealt with. Mr Perron makes a point-and this is where the answer that the Minister has just given seems not to be satisfactory-in the penultimate paragraph, and I would be happy to make a copy of the letter available to the officials for them, perhaps, to comment on these specific issues. He says:

SPEECH.PARA: The proposed amendments appear to be predicated on the assumption that there will always be sufficient pre-July 1988 unfunded liabilities to compensate for the removal of the exemption of the pre-July 1983 component of benefits funded by last minute contributions. This is not a well founded proposition.

He is speaking for the Northern Territory, and I do not think it is relevant to say what other States may have concluded because the Territory could well be in a different position. Nonetheless, the undertaking was given specifically to the Northern Territory. He continues:

The extent of pre-July 1988 unfunded liabilities depends on the date a superannuation scheme commenced and whether any prior service is recognised for benefit purposes. Recently established schemes may have minor or no pre-July 1988 unfunded liabilities, although they may easily have members with a pre-July 1983 component to their eligible service period as a result of recognised employment prior to scheme membership or as a result of a roll-over from another scheme.

It seems to me that the Northern Territory may be in a singular situation in that it may have taken over superannuation commitments for previous Commonwealth public servants who have gone onto the payroll of the Northern Territory after its own change in status which, if my memory serves me correctly, would be post-1983. So it seems to me that they may be in a singular situation and they may well be entitled to special treatment. I do not see, quite frankly, why some special provision cannot be made for them.

TALK.START.PARA: —That may well be so. I frankly do not know. Nor can I recall all the complications surrounding the transfer of former Commonwealth superannuation scheme (CSS) members to the Northern Territory. But I will give an undertaking to take up the matter with the Treasurer (Mr Keating). In so far as it may affect the former CSS contributors, I suppose that I have some considerable interest and involvement in the matter as well. However, I will give that undertaking.
—I thank the Minister. I take it that the undertaking also will be given to require a reply to go to the Chief Minister as well as informing the Parliament.

—Yes. But I do know from my own experience-and when I say `from my own experience', that means correspondence that comes to the Department of Finance-that these matters are usually answered fairly promptly but it is certainly not unusual for issues that are substantial and a bit complicated to take a considerable time. So I will give the honourable senator an undertaking for a reply but I do not feel that I am able to put any date on it.

—Whereas the Minister may feel it is not practical to amend a Bill for a specific example, it may be that the Northern Territory could be compensated through an adjustment of the grant that is made to it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Northern Territory got what I regard as a considerable concession in the last Budget when it got about $30m for electricity supplies which had been subsidised by the Commonwealth for a decade or so. By this financial year that guarantee had run out, but the Commonwealth provided about $30m as a one-off further payment. Therefore, the Northern Territory has received a number of concessions but that does not affect the undertaking I gave that the Government will look at this particular issue.
