SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stone Sen J.O.

TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Bill before the Senate is the States Grants (General Purposes) Bill. It puts in place arrangements for the provision of general purpose assistance grants to the States and the Northern Territory for the 1989 financial year, consistent with the decisions taken at the May 1989 Premiers Conference and Loan Council meeting. I point out that this is no minor piece of legislation. It authorises funding totalling $13,135m, which is about 15 per cent of estimated total Commonwealth Budget outlays this financial year. It is a very large financial provision. In his second reading speech, the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) noted:

SPEECH.PARA: General purpose payments to the States and the Northern Territory are estimated to decline by around 3 per cent in real terms in 1989-90.

He then went on to laud the Government's record on fiscal restraint and to call on the States to share the burden. I do not know which is the more interesting-the Government's pomposity in that regard or its sheer gall in thus suggesting that it is the States, so to speak, which have to reef in their spending sails in order to match the asserted performance of the Government. The fact is that as opposed to a 3 per cent real reduction for general purpose payments to the States this year the growth in total outlays from the Budget-excluding asset sales-will be a small increase of about 0.1 of one per cent. Nevertheless, it is an increase. As a matter of fact, because that total figure actually incorporates the 3 per cent real decrease in payments to the States comprising about 15 per cent of the Budget, the actual growth in payments for the Commonwealth's own purposes, of course, is higher than 0.1 per cent. I have not actually done the calculation, but it would be something of the order of half of one per cent, I suppose.

In Budget Paper No. 1, Table 3, headed `Summary of Major Measures by Function', sets out the total expenditure cutting exercise which has been incorporated into the Budget figuring. The spending cut in assistance to other governments is 47 per cent of the total-nearly half of the total expenditure reduction. That calculation does not take account of the various cuts in specific purpose payments to the States which are littered throughout the other functional areas of the Budget. I have to add that this is no one-off occurrence. This year's figures, in fact, continue the story of recent years: a disproportionate cut in payments to the States compared with the Commonwealth's own purpose spending. The Treasurer (Mr Keating) has adopted the comparatively easier task of attacking the State Premiers, rather than his Cabinet colleagues, for a major share in the expenditure savings in the past several years. Payments to the States and local government, as a proportion of total Commonwealth outlays, have fallen, in round figures, from over 20 per cent of the total Budget outlays to around 15 per cent since the Hawke-Keating Government came to power.

I have to say that I personally do not object to cuts in the finance being made available by the Commonwealth to the States but I do object to the kind of cant and hypocrisy we have had from the Treasurer and, indeed, the Government generally about its own efforts in cutting spending when in fact, as I have said, the larger part of that achievement has been directed to cutting the funds made available to States rather than cutting the spending of Commonwealth Ministers themselves.

I might also say, in passing, that what the Treasurer unaccountably fails to mention in talking about the Budget surplus is the contribution of taxation increases to that process. I take one example-a particularly outrageous one-over the life of the Hawke-Keating Government, since it came to office late in 1983. Indirect taxation revenues have increased by 200 per cent-they now stand at approximately three times their level of 6 1/2 years ago. That, of course, has increased at a much faster rate. It has been triple the inflation rate over that particular period. It has also been estimated that, using November 1982 tax scales as a base, bracket creep has contributed during that time some $13.5 billion in additional, cumulative revenue over and above all the so-called tax cuts during the life of the present Government. The coalition, I should say in passing, has given an unequivocal commitment to forgo the increase in revenue because of bracket creep. I ask in passing whether the Government has yet given such a commitment. The answer is no. That, in fact, would be real fiscal discipline that the Treasurer simply could not match.

The comments I have made do not mean that the coalition does not recognise the need for State governments also to undertake major structural reform and to pare back their expenditures. Our Economic Action Plan proposes to reduce general purpose payments by $300m during the first year of a Peacock-Blunt government. That would represent 2.3 per cent of those payments. As we note in the Economic Action Plan document, some States could do more, to take one example, to take advantage of the larger savings which can be expected from competitive tendering for many services if those services were to be contracted out to the private sector rather than continuing to be performed in the public sector.

TALK.START.PARA: —If you take the lowest bid.
—I am not quite sure of the thrust of that intervention.
—I am not sure Queensland ever took the lowest bid.

—I am sorry that the Minister is interjecting along those lines because I regard that as a rather frivolous contribution to the debate and one which is less than worthy of the Minister. It is obvious that on occasions the lowest bid is not taken, for good reason. One of the Minister's colleagues in recent days has tried to explain that in this place in Question Time. I do not propose to spend further time on that digression.

SPEECH.PARA: On the same point about contracting out, the Business Council of Australia has indicated that, using what it describes as conservative assumptions, contracting out of a variety of functions at the State government level could save such governments up to $600m on an Australia-wide basis. That is the Business Council's calculation. We have no means of checking that independently but, on the basis of the data it puts down, the estimate seems to be not unreasonable, if conservative. Contracting-out exercises undertaken in the State of New South Wales by the Greiner-Murray Government would confirm that that global Australia-wide figure is an underestimate.

The point I am making to the Senate is that there are very large savings in getting a lot of the functions which are presently performed in the government sector outside to be performed in the private sector. People who have some profit motive get things done more efficiently and more cheaply, providing the same level of service. The key difference between our approach in this area of payments to States and that of this Government is that the $300m cut in general purpose payments to the States which is proposed by the coalition in its Economic Action Plan is merely part of a total program of spending cuts of $2,700m. It is only about 11 per cent of the total cuts, whereas these reductions which the Minister referred to in his second reading speech-perhaps I should not say `boasted about'-total about half of the cuts in the Budget this year.

Let me turn to other aspects of the legislation before the Senate. One part of the Bill provides for the payment of $310.5m in interest-free capital grants to the States and the Northern Territory. That is the same amount as was provided last year as grants under the States (Works and Housing) Assistance Act 1988 and it is to be distributed on the same basis as was laid down in that Bill last year. In a departure from recent years, the arrangements that are proposed for this year do not provide for concessional loans for public housing. Those loans are being replaced by additional grants under the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement. These changes in administrative arrangements per se are not opposed by the coalition and therefore I do not propose to spend any further time on them. But the money for public housing brings to mind the devastation caused by the Hawke Government to the Australian dream of private home ownership through high interest rates and the capital gains tax.

But the story may not end there. The Melbourne Herald report of 9 November this year noted that the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) executive recently endorsed a proposal that houses of over $1m in value should attract the capital gains tax. I suppose the general reaction of most people in the community if they were told that houses over $1m should attract the capital gains tax would be something of a yawn. I can almost see Senator Ray confirming my speculation. But, of course, the question really is whether, if such a measure were introduced, it would be the thin end of the wedge and would lead in due course to an extension of that proposal to houses of a value much lower than $1m.

We all know that one of the major distortions created by the Government's capital gains tax, under which a capital gain on a taxpayer's principal private residence is exempt, is that it has diverted enormous amounts of money into the housing sector, which, although perhaps it is not a fair way of describing it, most people regard as a non-productive sector of the economy. That is perhaps not a fair term, but many people regard it as so when compared with, say, manufacturing industry or some other obvious industry. They see the housing sector as being more akin to a consumption area than a production area.

The fact that we now have a capital gains tax with this exclusion of the principal private residence is one of the principal causes of the outrageous increase in housing prices which was earlier experienced in Sydney and Melbourne, although that house of financial cards is perhaps now crumbling under the impact of the Treasurer's crushingly high interest rates. Of course, the only solution to that is either effectively to remove the capital gains tax altogether-that is the solution that the coalition proposes in the Economic Action Plan-or to include the principal private residence in the capital gains tax net. In other words, I am saying that there are only two ways of removing the distortion: one is to get rid of the capital gains tax as such so that the exclusion no longer arises; the other is to get rid of the exclusion by including the principal private residence in the capital gains tax net. Of course, the Government has not indicated that it will do that. But, as I have said, the ACTU has recently indicated that private residences of a value of more than $1m should no longer qualify for the exclusion; in other words, that the capital gains tax should apply on the sale of such residences. Once that first step is taken, I predict that it would be only a matter of time before the capital gains tax would be applied to houses of a lower value than $1m. After all, we should all remember the solemn promise of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in 1983 that he would not introduce a capital gains tax at all. He said, `There will be no capital gains tax'.

The final issue I raise in regard to this Bill harks back to a concern with equivalent legislation last year, the States Grants (General Revenue) Bill 1988. In the course of debate in the Senate on last year's legislation, I focused my remarks on clause 7 of that Bill which, I remind the Senate, stated:

. . . if, in the opinion of the Treasurer, the global borrowing limit for the State has been exceeded, the Treasurer may reduce payment due to the State under this Act by an amount equal to, or less than, the amount that the Treasurer determines to be the amount of the excess.

That clause gave two clear messages. First, it laid to rest any doubt that the so-called global borrowing limits program, which was begun in 1984, was not the voluntary arrangement that the Commonwealth Government had always claimed it was. Secondly, the clause showed how vindictive-I think I said this at the time-the Hawke-Keating Labor Government would be to State governments of a different political hue; that clause was, of course, aimed directly at Queensland and at no other State. Despite all the outrageous misuse of taxpayers' money in States such as Western Australia, Victoria and, prior to the present New South Wales Government, in New South Wales, despite various deals such as the collapse of Rothwells Ltd and the whole murky Western Australia Incorporated system, and despite for that matter in Victoria, the Victorian Economic Development Corporation scandal and the suspect decisions of the former Deputy Premier Fordham-in other words, the deals of Labor governments-no action was taken or proposed to be taken by this Labor Government against the governments in those States. However, last year when Queensland baulked at having its borrowing limits cut by one-third-itself a totally vindictive decision-the Treasurer maliciously changed the longstanding legislative forms to get back at it.

I raise this issue because the Minister for Justice himself raised it in his second reading speech on this Bill. In that speech he noted that no equivalent to clause 7 from last year was included this year. He went on to say:

. . . should any State in the future fail to commit itself to the global limits or fail to use its best endeavours to observe them, the Government would be prepared to propose the reintroduction of the provision to this or future legislation.

One should really read the words `any State' as `any non-Labor State'. Today there is only one such State in the Commonwealth. Under those circumstances, New South Wales should beware. But the others, including now the new Government of Queensland, can go on with their outrageous financial practices and be totally free from any fear of retribution from this Commonwealth Treasurer. I move the following amendment to the motion for a second reading, which has been circulated in my name:
At end of motion, add ``but the Senate notes that:

(a) the Hawke/Keating Government's prospective 1989-90 Budget surplus is mostly based on increased taxation, while nearly 50 per cent of any expenditure cuts come from reduced payments to State and local Government alone;
(b) the Government has been found wanting in bearing its proper share of expenditure restraint by cutting its own direct expenditure; and
(c) this typifies the mismanagement of taxpayers' funds shown by Labor Party governments around Australia, both State and Federal''.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The States Grants (General Purposes) Bill is a standard piece of legislation brought forward by the Government that deals essentially with legislation arising out of the Premiers Conference negotiations. It is indicative of this Government's set of priorities that over the years we have seen significant cuts to States grants-both general purposes and other forms of States grants. In part, this is due to the fact that the Government has gone on a surplus achievement binge for some reason that many of us have found difficult to understand. This Government has decided that its major priority in life is to appease and to please international financiers by getting the largest possible domestic surplus that it can. This is achieved in two major ways: one of course is by cutting grants to the States; the other is by decreasing expenditure in the health, housing, welfare and education areas.

SPEECH.PARA: We have had a major problem with this Government, certainly since 1984 when it was elected for its second term, in that it has turned away from its major areas of support; that is, ordinary families, ordinary Australians-people that the Government liked to call the workers when it was in opposition-and, in particular, those people on some form of welfare. In turning away from them, the Government has denied them many of the benefits that it argued strongly for when it was in opposition. For example, I can recall in 1982 when the then Fraser Government moved what was widely known at the time as the `wives of strikers' legislation. At that stage the then Liberal-National Party coalition Government was attempting to prevent the wives of men who were out on strike from having access to the unemployment benefit and certain other benefits generally available under the social security legislation. That piece of legislation was greeted with horror, not just by the Australian Democrats but also by the Australian Labor Party that was then in opposition, and for good reason. Essentially, it was an attack on the victim; it was an attack on a group of people who were not responsible for the strike taking place and who were going to be further penalised in many ways and, of course, that included not just the wives of the men who were on strike but also the children.

So, at that stage, the Government was quite clearly linked ideologically to the less well-off in the community and it stayed ideologically linked to those people through its first term in office. It introduced the capital gains tax legislation on the grounds that that was necessary in order to make the tax system more equitable; it introduced the fringe benefits tax legislation on the grounds that that was necessary to prevent a situation in which some people on high incomes were not paying tax while others on similar sorts of incomes had to pay tax; and generally, in its first term in office, it showed itself as genuinely being a government for economic reform. That went downhill very quickly after it won office again in 1984.

Since then, the Government's economic strategy has been based very much on the mythology of the benefits of a large domestic surplus-the argument being, of course, that, if the Government has a large surplus, it is regarded as being a good economic manager. Certainly this may sometimes be correct if the surplus is properly acquired. But, in the case of this Government, since 1984 the surplus has been acquired by slashing expenditure in those very vulnerable areas of health, education, housing and welfare and doing it, in many cases, by cutting grants to the States. In this it has been supported by the Opposition which, over the years, has been quite happy to agree to this Government doing things like delaying consumer price index increases to age pensioners; discounting ex-service and ex-defence personnel increases in pensions; abolishing Austudy payments to 15-year-olds in low income families; and taking 45-year-old women off the class B widows' pension once their youngest child turned 16 and telling them that, if they could not go out and get a job, they were to go onto the unemployment benefit. The damage that that did to the self-esteem of those women as well as to their disposable incomes is probably incalculable.

But the Government did that at the behest of a big business community that argued that the Government needed a surplus and that it needed to cut expenditure. That big business sector was busy propounding the myth in Australia that this country was a welfare state and that anyone in receipt of pensions and benefits was a bludger. Of course, that view was most recently expressed by the President of the Liberal Party of Australia, John Elliott. The implication behind all of that was that the only money spent by governments should go to the well-off because they were the ones who were being productive and the theory of the trickle-down effect still had some validity.

So it is hardly any surprise at all to note that the distribution of income in Australia has become particularly distorted over the last five or six years-sufficiently distorted to put us near the bottom of the list of Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) countries when it comes to equity of income access. And this is something which a Labor government-or at least a government which likes to call itself a Labor government-should not be proud of.

Given this disproportionate distribution of income revealed in a recent university survey from New South Wales, I think two things need to be said. The first is that it is hardly surprising, given that disproportionate distribution of income, that living standards in Australia are low in comparison to most other OECD member countries. The second thing that needs to be said concerns the misleading myths to the contrary-the belief that we are somehow living off the fat of the land in Australia, that we are better off in wages than anywhere else, and that that is, of course, impeding our productivity. These sorts of myths are prevailing to such an extent in the community that the Government is able to get away with its swinging attitude, if you like, to middle and low income earners.

Australians are missing out on the lot, if European and United States figures are taken into account. Far from being a welfare state, as common mythology would have it in this country, Australia spends less as a percentage of gross domestic product on housing and social security payments than any other industrialised country, including Japan and countries such as the United States and the United Kingdom. That is partly due to the fact that, unlike America and Britain, for example, the Australian Government provides no assistance to people buying their own homes. Both of those countries do, as do many other countries. Instead, Australia reserves the tax deduction for investors. As I have already said, that is partly due to the frenzy of cuts to the States' capital grants funds and welfare payments of one sort or another.

It is worth noting, I think, that Australia is also well behind most European countries when it comes to employer contributions to pension or superannuation funds. The employers complained bitterly when part of the recent wages deal included a contribution on their part to their employees' superannuation funds and their retirement benefits, but this is standard practice in many other countries around the world. It is not regarded as part of a socialist conspiracy or an attempt to beat employers into the ground or make them non-profitable. It is simply a part of the wages system put off until retirement. It is no wonder that most European countries in particular have a far better social welfare system, a far better post-retirement income system and, indeed, a far better unemployment benefit system than Australia does.

These things have been in place in most European countries for the last 40 or more years. They are well established and considered to be an integral part of the benefits that go to workers. Furthermore, I think it is worth noting that we are among the lowest taxed nations in the Western world. I think those people who still find this hard to come to terms with ought to have a look at current issues paper No. 5, recently released by the Legislative Research Service of the Federal Parliamentary Library. It goes into some considerable detail with regard to Australia's living standards and our position in world markets with regard to taxation, hours worked and so on.

According to this paper, Australia's working hours were the fortieth highest of the group of 52 countries looked at. They are similar to, or slightly higher than, those of most of western Europe and slightly less than those of North America and the Swiss cities. In Tokyo and the developing countries the hours worked were higher again than Australia's, with Hong Kong reporting hours worked as 50 per cent higher than Sydney's. Nevertheless, Australia's working hours were very similar to, and in some cases slightly higher than, most of those in western Europe. To argue that we are not productive in this country because our working hours are not long enough is to ignore the fact that some of our major trading partners in western Europe-countries like West Germany-do not work significantly longer hours. For example, West German workers in the car industry work a 38 1/2-hour week in comparison to Australians in the car industry working a 30-hour week.

The report on living standards from the Parliamentary Library points out that there is also nothing for us to be concerned about as far as being excessively taxed is concerned. The before-tax hourly incomes of people in Sydney were towards the lower ranking of European standards-lower than London, Vienna and Milan and slightly, but not significantly, higher than places like Paris, Dublin and Athens. They were also considerably lower than the incomes of people in Tokyo and North America and most of the northern European cities. As far as before-tax hourly incomes are concerned we are not doing too badly. A similar situation applies to Australia's major city rankings with regard to after-tax incomes.

The offsetting benefit to Australians for having a lower wages and tax system is that we also have a lower cost of living. It needs to be remembered that the pilots are not the only people in this country who could go overseas and get significantly better salaries-almost every worker could find another country where they would get a better deal in wages and benefits. However, they would also face a significantly higher cost of living. The living costs for Sydney are relatively low-lower than all other cities in developed countries except Los Angeles and Athens; equal to those of Luxembourg; well under half those of Tokyo; and just over half those of Scandinavian and Swiss cities, with the levels of other European and North American cities being just above those of Sydney.

The Union Bank of Switzerland data shows relatively lower living costs and thus a relatively higher purchasing power for Sydney than the OECD data shows for Australia generally. Nevertheless, the figures, by and large, are compatible. In terms of before-tax incomes, after adjusting for living costs, Los Angeles was clearly the highest and approaching double that of Sydney.

Australia is not a country where there has been a wages blow-out to make us non-competitive in comparison with our major trading partners. Australia is not a country with a significantly higher taxation system than those of our major trading partners. It is about time that some of that mythology was knocked on the head. Simply looking at comparable figures from other OECD countries indicates that we are not the welfare state, the highly taxed state, or the workers' paradise that many people here would have us believe in arguing that we need to lower the tax system and lower wages or, at least, keep them thoroughly pegged in order to become competitive.

As I said earlier, one of the major problems has been the Government's cutting of States grants. Apart from the fact that this places an additional revenue or loan raising burden on State governments, it also reflects a strange ordering of priorities in some areas by the Federal Government. Housing is one of those particular areas where the Federal Government's priorities seem to have been blown out of the water-certainly since it won office for the second time in 1984. This is particularly true when one considers the likely damage done to South Australia-just to take one example-by the new Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement. Health and education are two other areas where the States have suffered with regard to capital grants funding.

This means that State governments are starved of funds for capital works. Therefore, they face the choice of letting maintenance or rebuilding programs for hospitals and schools run down, or raising the necessary additional funds through loans-generally foreign-borrowed, which does nothing to help our general foreign debt problem. Their last option is raising the additional money through excises, charges and levies that lie within the power of State governments. No State government likes doing that, particularly in the run-up to an election, so the option that they tend to opt for is simply letting the buildings deteriorate and hoping that sooner or later either they will be able to raise the money somehow or a benign Federal government will increase their share of the States grants.

In the area of housing, however, it has meant that the Government has shown a clear ideological change of heart in the last few years. It has chosen quite deliberately to direct its funding assistance not to those people who are on low incomes and who desperately need subsidies in order to rent or to buy, but to those people whose incomes are sufficiently high for them to be able to afford to invest in the housing market and to rent out to somebody else. So the Government has chosen to go the route of negative gearing, to subsidise investors rather than to assist those in need of affordable and appropriate housing actually to have access specifically in those areas. The negative gearing expenditure has won out over States housing grants type of expenditure.

To make matters worse in the housing area, Australia has not yet seen fit to adopt two practices which are common overseas and which the Australian Democrats have been pushing for the last eight years; namely, the Australian Government still provides no incentive to save so that there is a reasonably large pool of low interest investment money available inside the country, and it provides no assistance at all to individuals, couples or families who are wanting to buy their own home. In that latter area in particular we are out of step with virtually all other OECD or comparable countries. If we look at the figures of those countries that provide interest on loans for home purchase or improvements, we find that Australia now is very much out of step. Austria, Belgium, Canada, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Japan, Luxembourg, the Netherlands-even New Zealand, on the figures that I have available to me-Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, the United Kingdom and the United States of America all provide some form of tax deductability for the interest that is being paid on mortgages that people have taken out to buy their own home.

Australia is out of step with almost every other comparable country in the world, in that it provides no direct assistance to ordinary families, ordinary individuals in Australia buying their own home. That assistance is, yet again, set aside only for those people who are investing in the housing market. The theory there is that those people will invest in sufficient numbers in housing and in units that they wish to rent out to provide a significantly large pool to keep rental down and to provide the sort of variety of accommodation and rent prices that people need to be adequately housed in Australia. In fact, that is not the case. Even with the negative gearing capacity, interest rates are so high in Australia at the moment that most investors in the market are not providing the sort of housing that is needed by people on low incomes.

To make matters worse, we have just seen pass through this place a bizarre piece of legislation, put forward by the Government and supported by the Opposition, that would mean that people who are on unemployment benefit, who are living in an area where rental is relatively high and who move to an area where rental is relatively low and who find themselves inadvertently also in an area where unemployment is high will no longer be eligible for unemployment benefit-will, in fact, be penalised additionally for chasing the low rental market and finding themselves, not by choice but by simple economic fact, in an area where unemployment is traditionally high. This is particularly true in a State such as South Australia where the pockets of high unemployment also happen to be the pockets where rental is low.

So we have failed to follow the experience of other countries with a high regard for home ownership; we have failed to assist ordinary Australians to buy and to keep living in their own homes. As far as the former case is concerned-that is, the need to provide some incentive for people to save-again we have failed to look around the rest of the world to see what has worked. We have failed to learn, for example, from Japan's spectacular success in acquiring low cost investment funds through encouraging savings by their residents, by not taxing for a long time any of the interest that was earned, and in more recent years by applying a tax of only 20 per cent to that interest. A number of countries around the world guarantee the first $500, $600 or $700-in some countries it is as high as $1,000-that people earn on interest on savings. That encourages people to put more money in lending institutions that can then be made available at reasonable interest rates for investment.

It is time that Australia used some of its considerable surplus by allowing a tax break in either or both of those areas. Maybe if we did that we would find that such dramatic effects would not be caused to States such as South Australia when the Government decides that it will cut its housing funding or its general purpose States grants and force those States into the position of either increasing their borrowings or increasing their own revenue raising or-possibly the worst of all the alternatives-reducing their services to education, health care, housing and that part of the welfare budget which lies in their jurisdiction. Until governments recognise that a surplus is of precious little use unless it is being directed to maintaining the living standards of all Australians, until we stop spending $2 billion on giving tax cuts to big businesses and making up the difference by cutting pensions back further, by taking Austudy away from youngsters who cannot afford to stay at school as a consequence of losing that money, by other draconian measures from cuts in States grants through to attacking 45-year-old women on the class B widows' pension, I do not think that we will be able to regard ourselves as a civilised society or this Government as worthy of the name of being a Labor government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K. .

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to this amendment in relation to the States Grants (General Purposes) Bill 1989 moved by Senator Stone, one is reminded of the hypocrisy, the poor rhetoric and the downright misleading statements that are made by this Government in claiming that it is somehow attempting to provide sound financial management for the Commonwealth whilst at the same time it is penalising and suppressing States and local government in order that it can crow about having been able to deliver a surplus.

SPEECH.PARA: If one takes a look at the New South Wales case set out in a document that was put to the Premiers Conference and Loan Council in May this year, I think the following statistics speak for themselves. Specifically, in the six years to 1988-89 in real terms Commonwealth spending on its own functions has increased by 22.3 per cent compared with an increase of 7.7 per cent in State own purpose spending. Commonwealth payments to the States fell by 2.2 per cent. Commonwealth revenue increased by 30.7 per cent whilst State revenue increased by 20 per cent. In fact, the Hawke Government this year is to receive at least $12 billion in revenue from new taxes and tax increases it has introduced since it came to power. The State global borrowing limits fell by 48 per cent compared with a rise of 125 per cent for the Commonwealth. In addition, State governments will receive only 29 per cent of total income tax and other taxes collected by the Commonwealth compared with some 39 per cent in 1982-83. Had the Commonwealth Government over the last six years applied the same restraint to its own expenditure to that imposed on the States, it would face a surplus of over $15 billion in 1988-89 instead of the one that it anticipated. Following the Loan Council meeting, the Treasurer (Mr Keating) put out his own press release on 18 May. He said that the key decisions taken at the Loan Council were that there would be:

a net reduction from the forward estimates in financial assistance grants to the States of $550 million; a $1 billion reduction in the State authorities' global borrowing limits compared with the 1988-89 limit; a reduction of $1150 million in the Commonwealth authorities' global borrowing limit; revised payment arrangements for the Australian Capital Territory, with $23 million to be made into a Trust Account with a view to providing transitional assistance to the ACT.

The Treasurer put out a statement saying that these things had been agreed to but, in fact, the proposal to limit global borrowings was made by Premier Greiner. He put it on the basis that there was a need for the Commonwealth to give attention to fiscal policy and not simply to monetary policy. It was the persistence of the New South Wales Government and Premier Greiner in pushing the equity of this case that resulted in the cutback to global borrowings announced in the Treasurer's press release. The cutback in loans to government authorities resulted in something of a crisis for Qantas Airways Ltd, which wanted to borrow far more to refurbish its fleet. This just creates further pressure and gives a further basis to the argument that Qantas ought to be privatised in order that it can properly manage its own affairs.

The Government is very proud to say, and Mr Keating frequently boasts, that the Commonwealth Government does not borrow. But that is misleading, as are so many other statements that the Treasurer makes, because authorities borrow. He says that the State governments are borrowing, but this is under the agreement that they are entitled to borrow up to 22 per cent of the global limit overseas. A fiction is used in order that they may do it. Under the Financial Agreement of 1927 only the Commonwealth is entitled to borrow, but by setting up the State treasury corporations, which have been accepted by the Federal Government, they are able to raise those borrowings. Again, the Commonwealth is totally misleading in what it has to say.

In the second reading speech, the Minister said that the current estimate of general purpose funding for the States and the Northern Territory is some $13 billion, or about 15 per cent of estimated Commonwealth Budget outlays for 1989-90. If one looks at some of the rhetoric that went on at the time of the Loan Council meeting, one finds that the Commonwealth Government attempted to penalise the Liberal-National coalition Government of New South Wales. The Federal Government tried to say that, because receipts were up from conveyancing receipts that had come by way of stamp duty, somehow this ought to be offset against the receipts that New South Wales could expect. Hand in hand with that, this Government is pursuing a monetary policy which is designed to create a downturn in activity, particularly in the property market, which it would have known, if those policies were to have an input at all, would have resulted in a lessening of revenue to the New South Wales Government.

More and more over the years the system of federalism in this country has become somewhat undermined. We are the most highly centralised democracy in the world. The Federal Government, the Commonwealth, collects something like 75 per cent of all revenue and yet it accounts for only 50 per cent of public sector outlays, which makes for a considerable vertical imbalance in Australian fiscal federalism.

The crowing that the Government goes on with in saying that it is being responsible, is cutting back on expenditure and is producing surpluses denies the fact that what it is really doing is making the States and local government bear the pain. The Government cuts back on the share of revenue that they have and says, `You will have to raise revenue from other areas'. Then, when a government such as the New South Wales Government does exactly that, it has the hide to say, `Well, you'll need less revenue from the Commonwealth Government simply because you have exercised your own sovereign rights and have used your ability to raise levies'-for instance, the levy for environmental or road purposes that applies in New South Wales where there is an honesty about the Government that the Federal Government simply does not have. The Minister for Justice (Senator Tate), in his second reading speech, stated:

General purpose payments to the States and the Northern Territory are estimated to decline by around 3 per cent in real terms . . . While the real reduction in general purpose funding is less marked than in 1989-90, it will add to the effect of the significant reductions in payments to the States and global borrowing limits of recent years.

The fact of the matter is that while the Government has been squeezing State governments in particular, but also local government, it has effectively increased its own general purpose grants by some 5.5 per cent. The proposals put forward to the Loan Council by the State Government were equitable. It said that if the Commonwealth's own general purpose grant was to increase by 5.5 per cent, grants to the States should increase by the same amount. But clearly that message fell on deaf ears. However, New South Wales and Premier Greiner were successful in having global borrowings reduced by $2.5 billion.

The second reading amendment condemns the Government for its deception and points out that the Budget surplus is mostly based on increased taxation, while nearly 50 per cent of any expenditure cuts come from reduced payments to the States and local government; that the Government has been found wanting in bearing its proper share of expenditure restraint by cutting its own direct expenditure; and that this typifies the mismanagement of taxpayers' funds shown by Australian Labor Party governments around Australia, both State and Federal. The motion makes the point that the Government has made the decision to rely entirely upon monetary policy; that it will not attack the real problems that the country faces; that the Treasurer somehow takes pleasure in making State governments suffer and wear the opprobrium of the electorate at large because when they cut services or have to raise additional money by way of levy to carry out significant tasks that need to be remedied due to the mismanagement by a previous Labor government, they are doubly penalised by the Commonwealth's saying, `You can raise this money, therefore, we will deduct it from you'.

In the whole area of federalism, generally the Government is totally centralist. It has no regard nor concern for the need of the people of Australia, who value their federal system, to have an equitable system of sharing the taxes that are raised. The policies outlined in the Opposition's Economic Action Plan will mean that Australia will finally get some good sense of government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government, of course, opposes the second reading amendment. It is bizarre in terms of the falsity of the claims that are there made about the absence of fiscal effort by the Government. When we came to office, it will be recalled that we were confronting a punitive deficit of well over $9 billion. We have turned that around over the course of our less than seven years in office to a surplus something like $9 billion. That has not been achieved by taxation increases, as the amendment would claim. It has been achieved by a long, hard slog on the expenditure outlay side.

SPEECH.PARA: The discipline that this Government has achieved in expenditure outlay reduction has been remarked upon worldwide and is the subject of very considerable admiration. It is a record unmatched anywhere, I think, in the world in recent years. For this shoddy, squalid little claim to be made by the Opposition purely for point scoring purposes is not something that moves me to reply for a longer period than is necessary to scotch it. I have made it clear that the Government opposes the second reading amendment. We commend the Bill to the Senate.
Amendment agreed to.
Original question, as amended, resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Committee does not insist on the amendment made by the Senate to which the House of Representatives has insisted on disagreeing.
