TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —Apropos the remarks of the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans), I do not think it is at all perfectly clear as to why the Government is continuing to insist on disagreeing with the amendment that has now been insisted upon twice by this chamber. The Minister was good enough to say that he would not want to waste the time of the Committee by telling us again all the reasons why the Government proposes to continue to disagree with the amendment twice recorded, but I for one would like to hear why the Government is continuing to resist the amendment that has been put by the chamber twice now. So I yield to the Minister.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am always happy to oblige Senator Stone, even if it is relentlessly tedious. The situation is this: the Bill is before this chamber for the third time and this is the second request from the House of Representatives that the Committee not insist on this amendment to the Bill. The Government has previously detailed its reasons. Those reasons have not changed. The arguments put forward by the Opposition have not persuaded the Government to change its mind. The Government does not accept the Opposition's argument that because the bodies that will gain from the amendment are public bodies they should be given the benefit of the use of public funds. As was indicated at the time the Committee agreed to the amendment, government outlays to public hospitals, public benevolent institutions and public universities are appropriately provided by means of outlays which are subject to review and compared with competing demands for Commonwealth funds in the budgetary process, not by way of the use of funds that are prepayments of income tax by employees intended to be paid to the Commonwealth.

SPEECH.PARA: The Budget measure does no more than seek to overcome the deferral of tax payments by closer matching of remittances to collections. It should be remembered that we are not talking about the remitters' money in this instance. It is necessary to realise that the Budget measure is part of the Government's strategy aimed at eventually reducing the administrative burden placed on small businesses by the tax instalment deduction system by moving small employers which comprise the majority of remitters to a system that would require less frequent remit- tances than at present. The Government aims to continue with this strategy, despite the obstacle placed in its way by the Opposition parties by this amendment. The strategy should not be interfered with by making adjustments on the fringe, otherwise the system will become an administrative jungle.

The amendment previously moved by the Opposition would effectively condone the backdoor financing of public institutions with Commonwealth funds through the use of extended retention of tax instalment deductions made from the salary and wages of their employees. This is just not acceptable to the Government. I further remind the Opposition that this is a budgetary Bill with significant revenue implications. The amendment which is being insisted upon here would reduce the revenue in the 1989-90 year by $50m. I again urge, as has been done by speakers before me, that the Opposition reconsider its position for the reasons I have spelt out.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister might be good enough to explain in what manner he intends to give relief to the small businesses and small taxpayers that he is referring to as part of a program. This is news to us. We have not heard of the program. Perhaps the Minister might care to assist the Committee because if it is attractive enough, you never know what we might do in the near future. At least he owes us the courtesy of explaining what is in the Government's mind with respect to how the relief will be given to the needy taxpayers of Australia.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have nothing more to add to what I said. I will spell it out again. The strategy is aimed at eventually reducing the administrative burden being placed on small businesses by the tax instalment deduction system by moving small employers to a system that would require less frequent remittances than at present. I have nothing more to add.

—We are interested in the system to which the Minister keeps referring because he has referred to a program that will `eventually' be introduced, one that is down the track. Are we talking about 10 years or next week? The Minister owes us the courtesy of telling us what the system of giving relief to small taxpayers is. We might then reconsider our position.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wonder whether it is possible for a Minister who knows something about the legislation to be in the chamber. I have no wish to be particularly rude to Senator Evans who in his own particular areas is exceedingly competent, but he is not familiar with these waters.
—I wouldn't go over the top.

—I am not getting too enthusiastic; it is all right. The Minister is not familiar with this area and we have suddenly been told that hospitals, tertiary institutions and benevolent institutions will be asked to pay tax twice monthly instead of monthly in order to provide some mythical and hitherto unmentioned benefit to Australia's small businesses. It would be jolly nice if we knew what all this was about.

SPEECH.PARA: It would be equally nice if somebody who knew what they were doing could explain it. It is very unfair to the Minister to hand him two sheets of paper which he reads out in good faith and then gets questioned on. Even this particular Minister will not be able to talk his way out of this one since he does not have the information at his fingertips. If we could get a Minister in here who knew something about tax, instead of a Minister who knows something about lots of other countries, it would be particularly helpful. But until we are given some very strong reason for backing off on this, I think the Opposition parties and the Australian Democrats have every right to stick with an amendment that has been passed twice in this place and is aimed at preventing some deficit financed and otherwise strapped-for-cash organisations in this country from having to face that additional tax payment each month.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why don't you report progress?
—We have not made any yet.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —There is not much progress to report, Mr Chairman. Senator Haines is perfectly right. I knew nothing about the Bill, including the name of it, when I walked into the chamber. The difficulty is that Senator Walsh is not well; he has gone home. It is a matter of just doing the best we can under the circumstances. I hope that the Committee will bear with me. I do have an adviser here who knows considerably more about it than I do.
—I think you will get across it in a couple of minutes.

—You are all heart, Senator. All I am able to say about the particular system that is exercising Senator Watson, in respect of which he is seeking further information, is that it is partly foreshadowed in the second reading speech or elsewhere publicly that smaller employers may be moved to quarterly remittance instead of monthly remittance. That is about 200,000 employers, or half of the number of remitters. That is the order of magnitude we are talking about. The change in question is part of the redevelopment of computer systems and it may occur within the next couple of years. That is as precise as we can be. That is the context in which the matter that I put on the record before--
—How small is `small'?

—Small enough to satisfy the result that 200,000 employers or about half the number of remitters would get in. I do know what that means in terms of income and so on of people concerned, but presumably, with Senator Watson's indefatigable in-depth knowledge of the shape of small business in this country, we would appreciate just what type--
—We would need time to consider it.
—Okay.
—It is not unattractive.
—I am delighted to hear that it is not unattractive.
—It is still not terribly meaningful.
—What does Senator Haines want to know about it, apart from just having a general whinge as she did previously? What does she need to know about the Bill?

—What the Australian Democrats would really like to know is what sort of definition of business the Government is using. Are they businesses in a particular area? Is it a particular income level that they need to have to qualify, a la the last Bill that we were dealing with? What does this word `may' really mean? The Minister has told us that they may get some benefit some years down the track if they are in areas of small business but he is not quite sure which sorts or when. The only suggestion that I think we can make, if the Minister who does know what is going on in this is absent, is for us to report progress and to deal with this Bill again when we return on Monday.
—Order! Senator Haines, were you moving to report progress?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stone Sen J.O.

TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to move that motion. I will explain why. I understand the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade has told us that Senator Walsh has taken ill again and has had to go home. I am sorry to hear that, but I think in these circumstances it would have been appropriate for the Government to have moved to amend the order of business before the Senate tonight so as to bring on other business, instead of this particularly difficult matter. Indeed, for that matter Government business, order of the day No. 4, is no less technical. Nevertheless, we could have made some progress on it by way of a second reading debate. It would, I think, have been more sensible for the Government to do that to allow us to make some progress on Government business, order of the day No. 4, the sales tax Bills, than to have this ludicrous situation where questions are being addressed to the Minister which clearly he is not competent to deal with. I do not say that pejoratively but I think that puts the Committee in a very difficult, and almost unworthy, situation. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That progress be reported.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not resist that. I have no desire to obstruct the process of the Senate. Obviously I am not able to assist in the way that honourable senators seem to want to be assisted on this matter. I am delighted to hear that there is some willingness to engage in genuine debate--
—Order! There is no debate allowed on the question of whether to report progress.

DEBATE.TITLE: SALES TAX (EXEMPTIONS AND CLASSIFICATIONS) AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1989SALES TAX (EXEMPTIONS AND CLASSIFICATIONS) (COMPUTER PROGRAMS) AMENDMENT BILL 1989SALES TAX LAWS (COMPUTER PROGRAMS) AMENDMENT BILL 1989

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 21 November, on motion by Senator Bolkus:
That these Bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stone Sen J.O.

TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating cognately the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1989, the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) (Computer Programs) Amendment Bill 1989 and the Sales Tax Laws (Computer Programs) Amendment Bill 1989. The coalition does not oppose these three Bills being debated today. However, I foreshadow that I will be moving a second reading amendment which expresses our reservations about the way the Government has dramatically increased the revenue from the wholesale sales tax by over 200 per cent within the life of the present Government. In addition, Senator Messner, on behalf of the Opposition, will move a committee stage amendment to one of the computer sales tax Bills.

SPEECH.PARA: I propose to divide my remarks into two parts, dealing first with the second and third Bills, those which deal with the application of sales tax to computer software. In a direct sense these Bills follow upon an announcement by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) on 22 December last year. The result of that announcement was that all computer software would be exempt from sales tax but that the inputs to the production of software would remain subject to sales tax. As I think we all know, that kind of division between the product itself and the inputs to it almost invariably leads to anomalous situations. One of those, as I have already indicated, will be the subject of an amendment by my colleague Senator Messner, who has just joined me, at a later point in the proceedings.

The inputs to the production of software include computer hardware, discs, tapes and other material used in producing software. However, if one examines the background to this legislation, it becomes obvious that yet another taxation area has been subjected to continued messing around over the last few years. In theory it has always been the case, I understand, that computer software services were not taxed. Only the manufacture of a product for multiple users would be taxed. However, the perennial problem arose apparently, whereby, in a draft ruling dated May 1988, the Australian Taxation Office appeared to reinterpret Government legislation so that effectively the provision of computer services, as well as the manufacture of goods, would be taxed.

To its credit, the Government responded to the dismay which that ruling generated by announcing in last year's Budget that it would introduce legislation to clarify and confirm the Government's original intentions. Unfortunately, when that legislation was introduced last year it was still found to be ambiguous. The software industry remained genuinely concerned that the changes introduced in the 1988 legislation would inevitably result in a Taxation Office ruling that would once again encroach on the area of computer software services. As a result the Opposition moved committee stage amendments to that 1988 legislation seeking to define clearly what a computer program was for the purpose of sales tax. We attempted to do that in the House of Representatives last year. Naturally enough, the Government, which is both arrogant and stubborn, defeated those amendments. Nevertheless, having defeated the amendments, the Government then-I suppose as a result of that process-was forced to examine its handiwork a little more closely than it had done when the legislation was drawn up, and it totally withdrew that 1988 legislation. This is another ignominious example of a government which talks first and thinks later-or in that case legislated first and thought later.

As I have said, the coalition does not oppose these two Bills, or the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Amendment Bill (No. 2) that I will deal with in a moment. We understand that the software industry is broadly satisfied with the Government's legislation. But coalition senators and members have received representations from some companies within the software industry suggesting that an anomaly will now be created by this legislation which in other respects is thought to be broadly satisfactory.

It appears that the Government's legislation is drafted in such a way that computer software will not be subject to sales tax `except where the only computer programs embodied in the goods are embodied in microchips'. It has come to our attention that such a definition, while no doubt designed to prevent an unnecessary loophole in the taxation provisions, does in fact remove the exemption for a small but nonetheless legitimate segment of the computer software market. I understand, and I have had demonstrated to me, that a number of products exist which could be termed educational games for children which, because they rely on a plug-in apparatus which contains a microchip, rather than, say, a floppy disc, to transport computer software information, will be subject to rather than exempt from sales tax. Some such educational games are available on the market in two models: one model incorporates a floppy disc and the other a plug-in apparatus containing a microchip. Under the Government's proposal the software sold in the first case would be exempt from sales tax and the software sold in the second case would be subject to sales tax. That is a fairly clear anomaly. Sales tax is not meant to distort the productive process between one form of technology and another. If it does produce that outcome, as it clearly would in this case, it is an anomalous situation that ought to be rectified.

The Opposition's amendment, which Senator Messner will deal with at the committee stage, seeks to alter the definitions contained in the Sales Tax Laws (Computer Programs) Amendment Bill to avoid that anomaly. We hope that the Government will support our amendment. But, as I have said previously, apart from that amendment the coalition will not oppose these two Bills. But we do oppose and strongly criticise the delay, the confusion and the indecision-and, I have to say, the bumbling-of the Government in this area over the past nearly two years. This has simply added to what is already a very complex administration in this area, to high compliance costs and slow appeal processes which typify the wholesale sales tax laws. It comes on top of over 3,500 pages of complex and often enigmatic general taxation legislation. For too long the Hawke-Keating Government has used the words `taxation reform' as a euphemism for `increased taxation burden'. I now move my amendment to the motion that the Bill be read a second time:

At end of motion, add: ``, but the Senate deplores the Hawke/Keating Government's economic irresponsibility in increasing sales tax revenue by 200 per cent in an ad hoc and distortionary fashion since it came to power''.

I now turn briefly to the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Amendment Bill (No. 2), which makes four substantive changes to the state of the sales tax laws: namely, the exemption of certain paper products from sales tax; the exemption of the range of goods which are exempt from sales tax where those goods are for use by a subcontractor exclusively in carrying out activities on behalf of manufacturers; an increase in the small manufacturer exemption thresholds; and, finally, the provision that flavoured milk drinks that contain at least 90 per cent milk will now be subject to tax at the concessional rate of 10 per cent. The coalition supports all of those changes. Indeed, we particularly welcome the moves to increase the small manufacturer exemption threshold. The small business community has been greatly neglected by this Government and the fact that it is being at least somewhat recognised in this piece of legislation can only indicate that an election is in the offing. A similar motivation can be seen behind the decision to allow a sales tax exemption for goods manufactured from recycled paper. The truth is that the coalition parties made that decision well before the August Budget.
To draw my remarks to a close, because I do not want to take up the time of the Senate unduly--

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!

—I am glad to hear the Minister's applause. He is making his comment out of his place, so perhaps I should not recognise it. The exemptions and concessions contained in the three Bills provide some fractional relief from the general burden of indirect taxation, and as such they are to be welcomed. Yet, as I noted before, the bottom line is that sales tax revenue under this Government has increased by 200 per cent during the not quite seven years. Indeed, I understand that the Treasurer has boasted-this story may be apocryphal but it has a ring of truth about it-that these days he actually raises more revenue from the wholesale sales tax and indirect taxes generally than he would if he had introduced a broad-based consumption tax in 1985, as he was trying to do at the time before he was knocked off by the Australian Council of Trade Unions and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). However that may be, as the coalition has made clear since our initial statement on taxation policy, I think in May of last year, we are committed to reforming this ramshackle indirect tax system and to removing the anomalies and inequities which presently abound.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —In contributing to this sales tax debate, I wish first to comment on the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Amendment Bill (No. 2) and to speak on the exemption of certain paper products from sales tax. I understand that this portion of the Bill is included to give effect to the Government's environmental statement of 20 July 1989, in which an undertaking was made to exempt goods that were made out of wholly recycled paper. The wording of the Bill indicates that the Government has moved away from products made from wholly recycled paper to goods in which all the paper has been manufactured from recycled paper. There is a subtle distinction.

SPEECH.PARA: As has already been pointed out, the wording of the Bill leaves it open to interpretation and it could be taken to mean that the exemption applies to goods made only partially, and not wholly, of recycled paper. I would be grateful if the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) could comment on this aspect of interpretation when he responds to the second reading debate. We will certainly be looking for clarification on this point.

Also in the Government's environmental statement is an undertaking to `extend the exempting of any other recycled paper products'. I think the first thing the Government needs to do is to define `recycled paper'. Again I ask for the Minister's comment on that. I suggest that, in assisting him in this regard, there are two acceptable definitions of recycled paper. One definition of recycled paper is: paper produced from wastepaper which has already been broken down to form the pulp from which the recycled paper is made. In effect, all paper has a component of recycled paper as per this definition because, after all, paper mills recycle all their broken paper waste which occurs in the process of making and winding the paper. This could prove rather a major loophole in the legislation unless this term is clarified. So people around Australia will really be able to drive chariots through this loophole as it is presently defined. I think it is up to the Government, having been alerted to this problem, to define this term appropriately.

A second definition of recycled paper is: waste paper which, without breaking it down to pulp form, is actually recycled into another product. There are many examples of recycled paper as per the second definition. For instance, the Higgins Trading Co. Pty Ltd is involved in an operation which converts printers waste paper into packaging paper for use in butchers shops and other food outlets. The recycling process used in this instance is to take the outer damaged layers of printers reels and the small amount left as butt reels, sheet the paper, removing any damage, and package it for distribution. This wastepaper from many small printers has been in the past dumped. Other products which have been produced from wastepaper include things such as insulation and egg cartons. There are many ideas on the drawing board but there is a lack of incentive to get them up and running.

The thrust of the Government's environmental statement was to utilise better the existing materials in preference to damaging or depleting scarce and environmentally valuable resources. If this Government were really serious about its environmental endeavours it would, as a matter of priority, examine whether it could extend the exemption to other recycled paper products, such as the sheet paper produced by Higgins. If this Government were also serious about encouraging the use of recycled paper it would ensure that the Federal contract was awarded to a company which would service photo- copying machines that used recycled paper. Presently, repairs to photocopiers are not covered under contract if recycled paper is used in them.

Also of note is the lack of incentive to takeaway food and beverage vendors to change to containers made from recycled paper. Their containers are currently taxed at 10 per cent under item 17 in the third schedule. Again, if this Government were fair dinkum-and this is the fifth point that I make-it would give takeaway food operators, who must be one of the country's major paper container consumers, an incentive to become environmentally conscious and serve up their hamburgers, chicken pieces, chicken nuggets, fish and chips, pizzas, et cetera in containers made from wastepaper. A similar argument could be extended to those takeaway food vendors who use chlorofluorocarbon-free containers. Why not exempt them also from the 10 per cent sales tax as another incentive?

I think it is also of interest to note that item No. 96 formerly provided for the exemption of goods of a kind used to wrap up or secure goods for marketing or delivery-namely, wrapping material or bags consisting of paper and single-faced corrugated fibre board. Perhaps the Government should consider reintroducing this exemption, or including those items mentioned above if they are made from recycled paper.

I now go on to the Sales Tax Laws (Computer Programs) Amendment Bill 1989. This Bill has been introduced to give effect to the announcement by the Treasurer, Mr Keating, that sales tax liability for all computer software other than firmware would be removed. Perhaps I should explain the computer industry jargon. Software refers only to computer programs which, because they are not goods as such, have not been subject to sales tax. There was an unsuccessful attempt by this Government to tax them previously. Firmware is typically permanently built into the computer and embodies such items as silicon-based microchips designed to regulate the operating performance of computers or other machines such as motor vehicles. To help the Senate I will illustrate this by virtue of a small board which I have with me in the Senate tonight.

The intention of the Bill is to separate the sales tax on software from the sales tax on firmware. Under the present situation, the sale value of tangible carrying media for programs such as floppy discs or cartridges includes the value of the program when calculating the amount of sales tax payable on those goods. Let us assume for a moment that there are only two types of firmware in the world for carrying media for software or programs. One is this floppy disc, exhibit A, and the other is this cartridge, exhibit B. Typically, floppy discs are placed in a drive shaft, as we all know, to activate the program, whereas the cartridge is plugged into a port, usually at the back of the visual display unit.

Both pieces of firmware are frequently used as a source of portable storage within the marketplace. This is important because this is the anomaly that the Government's Bill does not pick up. The Minister should not be too smart about it. It is a real anomaly. Senator Messner has an amendment to pick up this anomaly, which the Government has failed to recognise despite the repeated representations that have been made to it. It is worth at least $1m to the industry. If the Minister listens, hopefully he will agree with this amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —If you shut up I will tell you that we agree with you.

—For example, the computer educational game entitled Memory Manor is available in the marketplace in cartridge form or on floppy disc. There are two alternatives. Both are manufactured for use on a Commodore 64 home computer, with identical software which produces exactly the same program on the screen. In other words, there are two mechanisms for producing a program on the screen. This Government has forgotten about one of them, and that is the purpose of our amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: In legislating to remove the sales tax liability for all computer software, what the Bill has, in effect, done is remove the sales tax on the program stored on the floppy disc. However, it has failed to remove the sales tax liability for the identical program stored in a cartridge. It is not the whole of it; it is just part of it. The inconsistency arises in the wording of the Bill, in which the firmware is described as software embodied in a microchip. This is where the Government went wrong, because the cartridge consists of a microchip mounted onto a board with input-output connections encased in some form of plastic housing. It is considered firmware and thus is taxable, which is quite wrong.

TALK.START.PARA: —Outrageous.

—It is quite outrageous. The effect of this inconsistency on the marketplace-this is the practicality of where the Government went wrong-would be to alter the retail price so that instead of both units being sold for $29.95, it is estimated there would be a price difference of up to 20 per cent, or $6. It might not seem a lot, but if one sells a lot of products it is important, particularly for Australian manufacturers. The flow-on effect of this price difference will be a move by the market away from the cartridge towards the floppy disc. The placement of a tariff concession to include duty on the import of all cartridge based software-
—I raise a point of order. Is it in order for the honourable senator to keep on firing bullets when the enemy has surrendered and is waving a white flag?
—Senator Evans, while I am sure you have conveyed your message to Senator Watson, there is no point of order.

—Maybe the Minister will take the extra few minutes to reconsider matters concerning the previous Bill, because if that happens I think we will be all very happy at the conclusion of this evening's debate. Through the introduction of the duty, the local cartridge manufacturing industry has been able to grow to the extent that local demand now fully justifies the costs of local production. After all, this is an industry that Barry Jones was talking about-the sunrise industries.

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very pleased to hear that they are changing. Had it not changed, this industry could well have quickly been a sunset industry. In addition to local demand, the export of cartridges is expected to begin during the next six months, and this is positive news because it will help the balance of payments. It is important to spell out the benefits of acknowledging what the Opposition has done for the balance of payments. This is a major breakthrough. An estimated 250,000 units will be exported in the first year, building up to 600,000 units in the second year. This is an important industry; it is a sunrise industry; it is a technologically advanced industry, and Australian people are at the forefront. The exclusion of cartridge-based software from this Bill would no doubt ultimately result in the death of this local manufacturing industry but, as a result of the impression we have made on the Minister tonight, the Government will agree to our amendment, and I welcome that. My colleague Senator Messner will be moving an amendment to secure the Government's agreement.

SPEECH.PARA: On another matter concerning general sales tax, the Ombudsman has drawn the attention of the Commissioner of Taxation to several problems which became evident in the course of his handling of complaints about sales tax. The Ombudsman was concerned that, with an audit crackdown on sales tax imminent, these problems could mean that audit activity would have unfair results, especially with regard to penalties. The most significant problems are, firstly, the uncertainty about key provisions of the sales tax legislation giving rise to confusion both within and outside the Australian Taxation Office and to disputation. Only last week we were advised that small to medium sized companies find it necessary to employ someone full-time just to handle sales tax issues. Secondly, there is the disadvantage to taxpayers because of the requirement to assess for themselves which goods are taxable and at what rate, leading to difficulties in the absence of an efficient inquiry system, in establishing correct liability for particular transactions. Thirdly, there is the absence of regular monitoring of sales tax returns by the Taxation Office so that taxpayers' errors are not detected in time to prevent significant arrears of sales tax which continue to accrue until detection. Lastly, unfortunately, there is inconsistent advice and decisions from regional offices which may put some manufacturers at a significant competitive disadvantage. There are also difficulties in obtaining refunds of overpaid sales tax.

While major changes to the administration of sales tax announced by the Commissioner following a sales tax review last year could alleviate some of the problems, the Bill before us contains sufficient ambiguities with regard to the term `recycled paper'. I would be grateful if the Minister could respond in depth to the issues that I have raised and enunciated very clearly here tonight in order to overcome the loopholes in the legislation that is now before the Parliament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think I am capable of responding in depth to a contribution as learned, extensive and comprehensive, and expressed with as much passion and charm, as Senator Watson's has been. I think we can satisfy him on the main thrust and substance of his speech, which was about the computer cartridge issue. I think it would have been in breach of the Geneva Convention had he continued to pursue his assault any further under the circumstances of the agreement that we are trying to signal to him. We will make that clear in the committee stage.

SPEECH.PARA: On the other matters, all I can promise to Senator Watson is to ensure that his remarks are taken on board by the Government. They will not persuade us to any further amendment of the legislation at this stage, but in the further consideration and development of sales tax legislation we will, no doubt, give his remarks the consideration they deserve.

The Government rejects the second reading amendment not because we contest the arithmetic, but because the description of `ad hoc' as the way in which we have gone about our compilation of sales tax legislation and revenue gathering we regard as a slur on the dignity of the profession. It is not something that we can accept standing up. We will have to accept it lying down, I think, given the reality of numbers in this place, but I would not wish my silence to be taken as any form of consent to the obviously grotesque claim that is here being made.
Amendment agreed to.
Original question, as amended, resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: SALES TAX (EXEMPTIONS AND CLASSIFICATIONS) AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1989
The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 4, after paragraph 3 (d), add the following new paragraph:
``(e) by inserting after item 123a the following item:

`123aa. (1) Goods, not covered by any other item in this Schedule, for use as special aids, and not for sale for that purpose, by people with physical or intellectual disabilities, in respect of whom a medical practitioner or a qualified or registered occupational therapist has certified that the use of the goods as special aids is necessary, in such cases or circumstances, and subject to such conditions, as are prescribed.
`(2) Parts for goods covered by sub-item (1) Nos. 1 to 9' ''.

As honourable senators will realise, this particular amendment is not new; indeed, it goes back quite a long way now. I have persisted by moving this amendment every time that we have come to exemptions and classifications. Every time we discuss this issue, it becomes more and more urgent. I would like to take some of the Committee's time to explain why it is now becoming so much more urgent that we deal with this matter.

In recent years there has been an upsurge of goods being developed for disabled people. Under the sales tax provisions, if the goods are developed and sold for disabled people, they are exempt from sales tax; but as honourable senators will realise, any such goods tend to be of a fairly costly nature. The reason for that is obvious: the market is an extremely small one, a highly specialised one, and hence the return for a manufactured good has to be very high indeed, to cover not only the cost of manufacture but also the cost of development.

Typically, items of this kind tend to come from the mum and dad class of company-very small and usually handling one or two products. The goods that I am talking about do not fall into that area. They are goods of a quite different nature. They are goods that are dealing with a general item. I have given examples before, such as computers, which I will return to shortly, but there are quite a number of others. For example, I would like to refer to a letter with regard to some other such items. The letter states:

All paraplegics above T6 and all with tetraplegia experience difficulties with temperature control. This includes people with diseases of the nervous system caused by accident, polio, spina bifida or diseases such as multiple sclerosis. For these people an air-conditioned system is essential rather than a luxury item. It is estimated that there are about 5,000 people with this need. The annual cost of tax revenue forgone would be about $30,000. Tax on air-conditioners is currently 10 per cent. This assumes a 25-year life span for each air-conditioner.

I suppose that people would feel it rather odd that when we are debating a Bill covering such a massive revenue raising exercise-Senator Stone set out in the speech he made in the second reading debate the enormous amounts of money that are raised-I would want to refer to something costing $30,000. The odd thing is that I have had to go on talking about these incredibly small amounts year in, year out. I am talking about general goods; not specially designed goods, but general purpose goods that, as I say in my amendment, `a medical practitioner or a qualified registered occupational therapist has certified that the use of the goods as special aids is necessary, in such cases or circum- stances'.

For example, there are quite a number of items available on the market that are of use to people with low vision. They are general items; they all carry sales tax. Yet it is possible that for this particular item-estimates have been made by the Australian National Council of and for the Blind which indicate that there are 3,500 people for whom these particular aids might be able to be prescribed every year-the revenue lost is in the vicinity of $54,000. The sales tax on most of the devices that I am talking about is charged at 20 per cent although a few are subject to 30 per cent sales tax. Again, this is a matter of hardly any significance whatsoever for the revenue.

There are reclining chairs specifically designed for no other purpose than comfort which are extremely useful for people with specific arthritic conditions. The body of people who are most competent in this area estimate that of the order of 7,000 people in Australia might be able to buy that piece of furniture and make use of it for their particular arthritic condition. The annual cost to revenue of that proposition is $20,000. The sales tax on the furniture is 10 per cent. I freely admit that I am not talking about large sums of money, I am talking about very small amounts of money indeed. But the extraordinary thing is that these small amounts of money are extremely important to most of the people with these types of conditions. We are all very much aware that the annual average income of people with the disabilities that I have just mentioned is amongst the lowest of any group in Australia. Hence, not to have to pay 10 or 20 per cent of the cost of specifically designed items is of extreme significance to them.

I have not heard anybody in any of the debates that we have had on this issue over the years suggest that anybody in the community wants sales tax raised on these items. In fact, people are quite happy to forgo the sales tax. Last year I gave an example of such a person with a disability who was trying to purchase a computer. The retailer happily gave up his profit, which was more than the 15 per cent of sales tax that was to be paid. He did not want to make a profit by selling that item to that person, and he was happy to forgo it. That shows that in the normal commercial world people are not interested in making money out of selling such items to disabled people; yet the Government is still persisting.

We have heard a myriad of excuses as to why such items can be exempt from sales tax, most of them, quite frankly, of a paternalistic kind. One of the usual excuses given is that the Department of Finance knows better with regard to this item. I am not asking the Department or anybody else to take my word for it. I have used a mechanism, the exemption of sales tax, that is already in the Act with regard to other items. For example, I draw attention to very large capital cost items-specially modified cars. The basic car is available to everybody. If a car goes through an identical process-in fact, the words are identical in the Act-the sales tax can be removed. I am not looking at a new method; I am not looking at a new exercise. I am looking at an extension of a current exercise.

Of all things, an exemption applies to people who have wigs prescribed. Sales tax is removed for that specific purpose. I will contrast the treatment of that item in the legislation with the following: I was very privileged a few weeks ago to be in the United States of America where I was following up this issue, in which, as honourable senators know, I have had a longstanding interest. I was visiting a number of commercial firms in the United States that deal with computers and disabled people. The most extraordinary things are now possible that one would not have thought possible at all. I will give two examples of that. The first is that of a woman who from birth was blind and deaf and also had quite severe multiple sclerosis. In our community still, unfortunately, the normal expectations of such a person would be very low. However, that woman was running a million dollar company. She was the managing director. She was able to do that via computers. The other person I went to see was a computer software writer. Although he was totally blind he was writing computer programs for the United States space program. Most honourable senators, even with their sight, would find writing a computer program mind-boggling, but he was writing sophisticated computer programs totally blind.

It is often felt in our community that disability disqualified a person from earning a decent living and making his or her way in our society. It is almost as if to say, `If you are disabled you can go out and weave baskets'. With new technology, these people are able to confront the world and in most cases, if they wish to do so and if they have support initially, they are able to earn a living and perform activities that most of us would think they could not possibly do.

I had the good fortune to spend a number of days with the managing directors of various companies in the United States. They were selling ordinary goods which in Australia have a sales tax on them. Under our social security system we do provide a range of support, but in the United States the situation is much more difficult. However, in the United States there is no sales tax on these items and in Australia there is. I discovered this extraordinary situation while I was in the United States. It is possible, under a provision similar to the one we are considering, for these goods to be exempt from various types of local, State and Federal taxes.

What is more, two years ago the United States Congress passed an almost identical motion to the amendment before us. The United States legislation actually mandates that all Federal employees be assisted. It is even better than our proposal because, when general goods are available, they have to be provided within Federal departments so that departments are able to employ a reason- able percentage of people with physical and mental disabilities. It is extraordinary that the United States, with the complexity of its legislative involvement, is able to confront this when we in Australia have not even been able to approach it sensibly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Amendments similar to that to which Senator Macklin spoke have been moved four or five times previously during Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Bill debates in this chamber. They have been moved regularly by the Australian Dem- ocrats and opposed just as regularly by Liberal, Labor and National Party senators, until last year when finally they decided that they would send the matter off to a committee. I understand that the question of whether or not this sort of equipment is likely to have its sales tax removed is now before the new Industry Commission.

SPEECH.PARA: As I said earlier tonight, I am very disappointed that the Australian Labor Party, in government, has moved so far from its roots-so far from the issues that it supported loudly and long in opposition. I recall that in 1981, when the Fraser Government introduced nine sales tax exemptions and classifications Bills that imposed, I think, about a 2 per cent sales tax on a wide range of materials, the Democrats were attacked viciously-not just by the Government, which was understandable, but also by the Labor Party Opposition. The Government, of course, attacked us for meddling in its revenue raising capacity. The Labor Opposition attacked us because we were not prepared to oppose all nine sales tax exemptions and classifications Bills outright but chose to amend those Bills in order to remove certain select items from the tax. It was a small tax. It was 2 or 2.5 per cent-at the moment I forget offhand what it was. What we did, successfully in the long run, was to amend that legislation so that food, clothing, building materials, educational materials and so on were exempt.

It concerned me at the time that no journalist bothered to ask any member of the Labor Party, front or back bench, that I am aware of, why in 1981 in opposition it was opposing sales tax measures that imposed a small tax on things like gold-plated cutlery. That item was in that legislation. It was one of those things about which Labor Party members in opposition in 1981 publicly expressed their outrage. They attacked the Fraser Government for daring to impose a sales tax of that sort on an item of that kind. No-one criticised them for it and presumably they could not see anything odd in it themselves.

It bothers me that a party that in 1981 opposed the imposition of a 2 per cent sales tax on gold-plated cutlery is now opposing and has for several years in government opposed the removal of a much higher sales tax than 2 per cent on computer equipment that has been adopted for use by disabled people. One wonders how far the Labor Party has come in the last eight years that it can change so violently from opposing, in 1981, a couple of per cent on gold-plated cutlery to now opposing the removal of a much higher tax on computer equipment that may be the only thing, after it has been adapted for use, that gives a child with a disability even a fighting chance to get through the education system and into the work force.

This is the same political party which in last year's Budget announced and then some months later, in November, moved and got through the Senate, an amendment that removed the sales tax-I think it was 10 per cent-from private planes. Just where are the Government's priorities in that little list? No 2 per cent tax on gold-plated cutlery in 1981, and no 10 per cent tax on private planes in 1988, but it was quite prepared to see a tax of, I think, 20 per cent on computer equipment even after it has been adapted for use by a disabled child.

The Government says that it does not think that sales tax exemptions are the right way to direct assistance to disabled people. That may well be true but, as Senator Macklin has already pointed out, the Government already offers a range of sales tax exemptions and assistance in other areas for people with disabilities. Cars, wigs, hearing aids, special glasses and an assortment of other things all qualify for sales tax exemption. If the Government is using the argument that it does not think sales tax exemptions are the right way to direct assistance to disabled people, why are the exemptions retained on those items? The worst of it is that, having claimed that this is not the right way to go, the Government has not offered us any other way to go.

If assistance to people with disabilities is not appropriately provided through sales tax assistance as either the only way or one way of making them a little more able to operate in society, what does the Government suggest instead and when will it offer it? We have not heard what are the best ways of providing assistance to people with disabilities other than through the sales tax system. It is time that we did. It is a bit like Senator Evans's contribution of an hour ago or thereabouts when he announced that the money that the Government was going to save by getting public hospitals, tertiary institutions and benevolent organisations to pay tax twice a month instead of once a month was possibly going to be used some years down the track to help some unspecified small business groups by allowing them to pay tax quarterly instead of monthly. We are getting into cloud-cuckoo-land when this is the sort of offering that we get from the Minister in response to the criticism of legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —He has retired hurt.
—I wish that were true. I rather suspect that it is almost impossible to make that particular Minister retire hurt or any other way.
—Put him in the sin bin.

—The sin bin is not large enough to cope. In any event, we are facing a problem that is similarly peculiar to the offering that we had from the Minister. The other problem is that this is not even an astronomical sum of money that we are talking about. The cost of passing this amendment is not going to make a pin-sized dent in the precious $9 billion surplus that the Government is so proud of racking up.
—A trumped up $9 billion, though.

—Trumped up or otherwise, the Government keeps trumpeting about it. It is not much good a family having a very large bank balance if its children are starving to death. It seems to me that if by devious means-mostly by cutting expenditure in the welfare, health, housing and education areas, as Senator Evans himself proudly acknowledged-we have managed to acquire a $9 billion surplus, maybe we could spend a total amount of $100,000 in providing a sales tax exemption to those families who are concerned enough about their child's access to education to have computer equipment. We are not talking about hundreds of dollars worth of computer equipment; we are talking in the realm of thousands. The equipment would be adapted for use by that child to give him or her at least some sort of running start in the society that he or she will move into. The Government's response to the argument that these kids need a fair go and that their families need a bit of assistance is to say, `Well, yes, maybe; but what if it's used by somebody in the family who isn't handicapped?'. So what! Big deal if that is what happens!
—They do with cars.
—People can certainly make use of a car that has been adapted for use by a disabled person, even if that use is made only by a passenger.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Peter Baume interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think they would care what they were called, quite frankly, if this amendment got through. Given the choice between a correct label and no assistance, and an incorrect label and a bit of assistance, I think they would wear the incorrect label. It is a silly move by this Government not to care enough about the people that it argues it supports to move persistently-Budget after Budget-to take sales tax off things like private planes and refuse to remove it from a piece of equipment that could make all the difference between a child with a disability moving up through the education system to fulfil its complete intellectual capacity and then get out into the work force.

SPEECH.PARA: To put forward arguments about the time not being right, the sort of assistance not being appropriate, the cost being too great, the fact that somebody else in the family might use it and give that person an unfair advantage over somebody in another family which has had to pay the full tax is simply not only ludicrous but begs the whole question. Are we, as a civilised society, prepared to do all we can to give people with disabilities a reasonable chance or are we not? That is basically what it boils down to. I say this to the Australian Labor Party, the same party, by and large, that in 1981 objected violently, loudly and long to the Fraser Government putting a 2 per cent sales tax on gold plated cutlery and that last year made a 10 per cent sales tax cut on private planes: why does it not offer the same benefit to those families that are bringing up, amongst other children, a child with a disability and allow them a tax exemption on the computer equipment that they buy after it has been adapted specifically for the use of that child? There is no reason, financial or other, that I can see that a government with a $9 billion surplus cannot see its way clear to providing at least that much assistance to families of that kind.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Haines has made a very impassioned speech which, on the face of it, might seem to be persuasive. However, there is a difference between being in opposition, and being a minority in opposition, and being in government. The amendment that the honourable senator has been referring to is currently being considered by the Industries Assistance Commission in a general reference on assistance to the disabled. The Australian Taxation Office advises that the particular amendment is wide open to abuse. The Government, therefore, could not agree to this amendment, even though it would agree with the spirit of the amendment. Anyone listening to Senator Haines's speech and Senator Macklin's speech would not disagree with the general sentiments, the general spirit, of what they are arguing. But government has a responsibility when we are advised that it could be wide open to abuse.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government's view is that it would be sensible to await the outcome of the Industries Assistance Commission review rather than to make an ad hoc change to sales tax arrangements at this time. In view of the lateness of the hour, I suggest that we not proceed further with these three Bills. That will allow us time to check with the Industries Assistance Commission on the progress of its review and report back to the Committee next week. The Government will not be opposing the amendment moved by the Opposition. In relation to the second of the Democrats' amendments--

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Death of Robert Nestdale-Mr John Ellenbogen: Judicial Hearing-Regional Security

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —It being 10.30 p.m., under sessional order I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight to say a few words about my friend Robert Nestdale, who died today aged 40. Robert was born in July 1949. During his 40 years, a tragically short period for one who had so much to give, he was a man of very considerable achievement. The outlines of his life and career can be given very briefly. He went to school in Sydney at Cumberland High School and obtained a Bachelor of Arts degree from the University of New England at Armidale. He held a variety of jobs in the parliamentary system and parliamentary process. He was an executive of CSR Ltd and since 1986 had served in the position of National Director of the United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF).

SPEECH.PARA: Robert was known to many honourable senators. I knew him as a friend of more than 20 years standing. My colleagues Peter Baume and Robert Hill knew him in particular as a dedicated liberal in the classical traditional small `l' mould or whatever term one likes to use. My friend Senator Knowles knew him as a member of the Young Liberal Movement of Australia. Senator Chaney knew him particularly as a person who had worked on a number of party committees and organisations. Senators Brownhill, Childs, Macklin and Vallentine have known him as a person intimately connected with the work of UNICEF. The President of the Senate, Senator Sibraa, knew him through his connections with the work which from time to time had impinged on the consciousness of the foreign affairs committee. The Clerk of the Senate, Mr Evans, knew him during the period that he worked for Senator Peter Rae. Members of the House of Representatives knew him well. Philip Ruddock, the member for Dundas, and his family were particularly close friends of Robert's. Mrs Sullivan, Mr Dobie, Mr Hall and a number of other members of the House of Representatives had close friendships and connections with Robert.

As I said, he was a committed liberal. He believed in liberal causes, liberal principles and liberal values. He made manifest efforts in defence of those principles at times when they were unpopular, when standing up for them was difficult and when a commitment to them was not easy. He was a committed member of my political party, the Liberal Party of Australia. Indeed, he served as the New South Wales State President of the Young Liberal Movement of Australia from 1978 to 1979 and as Federal President of the Young Liberal Movement of Australia from 1980 to 1981. I served in both of those positions a few years before that. Robert was a person who came through the Young Liberal Movement and had a career within the Liberal Party very much akin to my own. We served on the Federal and State executives of the Liberal Party.

I said that he was committed to involvement in the parliamentary process. He first started working down here in Canberra a little after the time that I started here. He worked first on the staff of Malcolm Mackay, who was at that stage the Minister for the Navy in the period of the McMahon Government in 1971 and 1972. He subsequently worked with Senator Peter Rae and developed a particular interest and involvement in the work that Senator Rae was pursuing in terms of reforms of the Senate procedures and operations and strengthening of the parliamentary committee system.

But, above all, Robert was committed to three great causes. Those causes were Amnesty International, the International Commission of Jurists, and UNICEF. I will not dwell on his work for Amnesty and the International Commission of Jurists but rather focus on the work that he did for UNICEF. He had a remarkable capacity to bring together people of enormously different temperament and interests and to find the common cause that they had between them in terms of advancing the cause of the world's children.

I just mention three of those people, each entirely different, who were roped into working for UNICEF by Robert and who have made, and doubtless will continue to make, enormous contributions to that organisation. My friend Robert O'Reilley is an accountant in Sydney who eventually became the accountant looking after the books of UNICEF and who has been taking care of some of the necessary technical and formal arrangements which must be made in the event of anybody's death. The second is my friend Peter Spies, whose interest was in the commercial world, in duty-free operations and international tourism, who Robert persuaded to work for UNICEF in Sydney and who played a major role in finding UNICEF its new headquarters in Sydney at the most advantageous commercial rates and arrangements. The third is Joan Hall, a person well known to honourable senators and members of the House of Representatives, who is a dedicated supporter of and worker for UNICEF and who had many of her projects particularly stimulated by Robert and the work that he was doing.

Robert also played a role in promoting the establishment of the parliamentary group of UNICEF. We have many parliamentary groups in this building at the moment. I have looked at the list of those who were present at, or who sent apologies for, the first meeting of the Australian Parliamentary Association for UNICEF held in December 1987. The names are: David Jull, John Mountford, Bob Katter, Chris Miles, David Hawker, Michael Macklin, Jean Jenkins, Robert Wood, John Watson, John Langmore, Nick Bolkus, Robert Hill, David Brownhill, Elaine Darling, Kathy Sullivan, Fred Chaney, Bruce Childs, Jo Vallentine, Olive Zakharov, Alasdair Webster, Peter Baume, Bob Brown and me-as diverse and as different a group of people as one could possibly gather within the four walls of this parliamentary institution. The committee, on which Senator Childs serves as Chairman and, I think, Senator Brownhill, Senator Vallentine and Mr Webster as executive members, again reflects the commonality of interests that people have and that have been brought together within this extraordinary organisation.

Robert's concern for children was remarkable. He did not have any children; I think he probably felt that he had all the world's children to look after. Indeed, in a paper by Robert, printed in the Liberal Forum Occasional Papers and entitled `Debt, Poverty and Children in Africa', he made a particular plea when addressing a forum at the University of New England, where he had studied. He said to that forum:

In the three hours of this morning's Forum, nearly 5,000 young children will die in the world. By day's end, the total will be 38,000. The same was true yesterday; the same will be true tomorrow. Equally bad or even worse, comparable numbers of children will be crippled for life and many more will be dragged down the nutritional ladder, day after day, until the stunting of their growth is irremediable and their chances for normal mental development are lost forever.

Robert practised what he preached in terms of care for children, in particular for the children of Africa. He spent a lot of time in Africa. He numbered among his friends African politicians such as Kenneth Kaunda. He participated not only in the defence of children as children but in the fight against racism and the fight against apartheid, which is another cause in which so many of us so passionately believe. He got sick in Africa and was one of those people who returned with, I think, some sort of hepatitis or liver complaint which laid him low for a while but which he struggled to overcome. He was dedicated to children not just in Africa; indeed, he was one of the few people who in recent years went regularly backwards and forwards to Beirut trying to see what he could do in his role as an officer of UNICEF for the tragic situation of children in the Lebanon. He had no sense of personal fear; no sense of personal danger. To him it was part and parcel of his manifest attempts to do what he could within the compass of a life which at that stage he had no reason to believe would not be four score and 10 years.

Robert got sick quite recently and battled against leukaemia valiantly. In particular, he steeled himself to ensure that during the visit to Australia of Audrey Hepburn, as one of the international ambassadors for UNICEF, he was well enough, despite his illness, to cope, to accompany her, to arrange part of her program, to bring her to the Parliament and to introduce her to people at all levels of government and society. He made a particular effort to keep himself as well as he could in order to accomplish what he must surely have known, if not simply suspected, would be the last major contribution which he would be able to make.

I wish to extend heartfelt sympathies-both mine and those of friends and colleagues in this Parliament-to his family, and his parents in particular. Apart from seeing them recently during Robert's last illness, I saw them just a few months ago at his fortieth birthday celebrations. I suppose we all knew at the time that it was unlikely that there would be a forty-first birthday party. They also have coped with great courage and great fortitude in these last couple of very difficult weeks.

I am delighted to see that UNICEF, in the announcement it made today about Robert's death, has indicated that in honour of his work it will begin an appeal for areas of Southern Africa. The appeal will be named after Robert. The project to be financed aims to provide safe, clean water for thousands of African families to help them escape from the cycle of serious diseases caused by drinking dirty water-as simple and as ordinary a thing as we take manifestly for granted, which nevertheless is a cause of death, dehydration and terrible illness for children throughout Africa and Southern Africa in particular.

Robert was above all a gentle person whose life was lived in the service of others and, as I have said, especially in the service of the children of this world. I would like to conclude by referring to two quotations from Shakespeare. Robert was not a particularly artistic or culturally minded friend. His pleasures were in music and much less in things like theatre but he did enjoy; he did participate. I am sure he would not mind my concluding my remarks by drawing on Shakespeare's words. The two quotations which have rattled around in my mind today come first from Julius Caesar and second from The Tempest. At the end of Julius Caesar, Octavius, triumphant, ponders the fate, nature and character of Brutus, defeated. Octavius says of Brutus:
His life was gentle, and the elements
So mix'd in him that Nature might stand up
And say to all the world, `This was a man!'

The second quotation is from The Tempest. Prospero tries to sum up his life and the achievements that ordinary human beings make. Robert's achievements were substantial and real but he would understand what Prospero meant when talking about the life of ordinary individuals. Prospero said this:
Our revels now are ended. These our actors,
As I foretold you, were all spirits, and
Are melted into air, into thin air:
And, like the baseless fabric of this vision,
The cloud-capp'd towers, the gorgeous palaces,
The solemn temples, the great globe itself,
Yea, all which it inherit, shall dissolve,
And like the insubstantial pageant faded,
Leave not a rack behind. We are such stuff
As dreams are made on, and our little life
Is rounded with a sleep.
Good night, Robert. Sleep well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Childs Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to join with Senator Puplick in expressing sorrow on the death of Robert Nestdale, the Australian Director of the United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF). I do so as President of the Parliamentary Association for UNICEF. This was the first parliamentary association formed in the world and, as Senator Puplick said, Robert had a role in that. In fact, he had much more than a role; he was the inspiration for the formation of that association. On behalf of the executive members, and the members generally of that association, I would like to express our sorrow. The executive members from the House of Representatives are: Kathy Sullivan, the Vice President, who is from the Liberal Party of Australia; Bob Katter, the Secretary, who is from the National Party of Australia; and John Langmore and Elaine Darling of the Australian Labor Party who are executive members. Senate members are: Senator Michael Macklin, the Treasurer; Senator David Brownhill, the former Secretary; and Senator Jo Vallentine who, no doubt, will speak this evening.

SPEECH.PARA: I mention the executive because it represents the coming together of all political parties and all the political tendencies in the Parliament. I think that was something that Robert wanted us to achieve. We achieved that. We achieved a `working together' under his inspiration. In our working relationship with him he found that he had real friends across the Parliament. In my case, and I am sure in the case of everybody else, that was based on a recognition of his dedication. We were all impressed with the dynamic, infectious enthusiasm that was so much a characteristic of Robert.

His death is a tragedy. It is a tragedy any time that somebody so young and so vital passes on. I believe that we should attempt to honour his memory. Senator Puplick has indicated what UNICEF is proposing. I know that many senators and members will honour his memory at the memorial service next Monday in Sydney. I invite all honourable senators to attend the launch of UNICEF's report on the state of the world's children in the main committee room next Wednesday at 11 a.m. Although we have lost one life, I believe that Robert would wish us to do something to save the millions of lives that are threatened in the world at present. If we could participate in and improve the work that Robert has been part of, it would be a fitting epitaph to his life's work.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Many people have loved and admired Robert Nestdale and not least those of us who have known him longest. He suffered from leukaemia for a couple of years and died of it early this morning. During his illness he declined to speak of it much and steadfastly refused to allow the illness to interfere with his work or with his life. During the time he was ill he had to cope with the sadness of a divorce, having separated soon before his diagnosis was made. But however hard this was to bear, he did not ever speak of it and he never complained and was never bitter to me about anyone else who had been important in his life.

SPEECH.PARA: Robert was a truly beautiful man and his good looks worried some people, who chose to think that good looks meant that he lacked commitment and depth. But there was so much about him that few people knew. My wife Jenny, shopping one day in suburban Gordon in Sydney, ran across Robert with a little girl. He introduced her to Jenny and it became clear very quickly that she was blind. It then emerged that Robert and she went out once a week, and that part of his commitment and service to his community was expressed through assisting this child to be more independent, more autonomous and more secure. He never spoke of this activity to others. It was as if it just did not matter whether or not others knew and admired him or whether they dismissed him. He knew what he was about and he followed his own star.

Robert Nestdale's belief in justice was passionate and his adherence to classical Liberal values was absolute. He was, as others have said, an active member of Amnesty International. He was active with the International Commission of Jurists. Some here-those who admired and loved another great Liberal, Alan Missen-will recall that Robert spoke at Alan's funeral and lit there the Amnesty candle and gave us some deeply felt words about Alan Missen and Alan's contribution to Amnesty International.

Robert was one of that line of Federal Liberal presidents of the Young Liberal Movement of which Chris Puplick is another representative. He served the movement well and presented a vibrant message of concerned and caring liberalism within the councils of the Liberal Party. It was no surprise that he spent some time professionally with another former senator and another small `l' liberal Peter Rae, with whom he would have shared some personal and political perspectives.

To me he was always a valued adviser and a friend. At times of difficulty in my own political life, Robert offered me support and wise counsel. He offered me encouragement and hope when I needed them most, and for this I am forever in his debt. He always treated my wife with affection and consideration. It was our very good fortune that he was able to join us for lunch just 11 days ago. He was already mortally ill but he drove himself to our home in his own car and he managed to participate in the meal and the social exchanges during an entire afternoon. When he left to drive himself home my wife and I both knew that we would never see him again. But we were so glad that he had been with us and we were honoured that, ill as he was, he had managed nevertheless to be entertained, to show and receive affection, and to accept our loving concern and sympathy for his illness.

Robert Nestdale dedicated his professional life, or its last part, to the world's children. He had a significant role in the United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF)-one that he discharged with great distinction. He was good for UNICEF and UNICEF was good for him. It is to the very considerable credit of UNICEF in Australia that it was able to order its administrative arrangements so that Robert Nestdale, right up to his death, continued to hold his post, attend his place of work and function as well as he was able, all with the considerable assistance of the UNICEF board and of his staff and colleagues. We are very much in their debt for what they did. In fact, he was working at home until yesterday afternoon.

Another very notable Liberal friend, John Dowd, was with Robert and his parents for much of the bad time that followed. In speaking recently with Paul Ignatieff of UNICEF, who had been Robert's superior, it became apparent just how much affection and admiration existed for Nestdale, for his commitment and for his ability. Paul Ignatieff is now in Tokyo, but I know that he would wish to be associated with the words being spoken tonight, just as I know that he will grieve with us at the premature and pointless end to the life of Robert Nestdale. He was born in July 1949 and died today, just 40 years old. His parents, his sister Ann and his brother Stephen are in our thoughts. I say to Ann, Stephen and his parents: Your son and your brother leaves a record of achievement and service and we are all the poorer for his loss.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

SPEECH.PARA: His caring and sensitive side became very clear and even more evident when he became the National Director of the United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF). He did not treat that position as a job; he treated it as a vital part of his life. Every time I spoke with Robert he was continually expressing his ideas and innovations that had the potential to help millions of less fortunate children in the world.

My good friend and colleague Senator Puplick, sitting beside me tonight, has already spoken about Robert. The three of us shared many a laugh together over many years. There are many other people from our Young Liberal era who are feeling very sad today and I would like to include some of their names in this tribute to a lovely man, otherwise known to us as a great guy. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.
