INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I invite honourable senators to rise in their places, in memory and in honour of Mr Nestdale.

INTERJECT.PARA: Honourable senators having stood in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dunn Sen I.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I wish to raise in this chamber a matter of justice. I am referring to a case that is known to many members of both the Federal and New South Wales parliaments, including at least one senator. I know that Senator Bishop has made representations on this matter, as have some members of the other place. I refer to the attempt by Mr John Ellenbogen to gain a judicial hearing for his claim that he was wrongfully dismissed by the Blue Mountains City Council. Mr Ellenbogen has been assiduous, even unrelenting, in putting his case to every parliamentarian who has some obligation to represent his interests, as well as to such bodies as the Australian Civil Liberties Union. I have no doubt that many people have advised him to forget about the whole matter. Indeed, Mr Ellenbogen's pursuit of this matter has cost him much in personal terms.

SPEECH.PARA: However, I believe that most of this cost would have been avoided if Mr Ellenbogen could have gained a proper hearing for his case. I do not want to rehearse the details of this case and I am not qualified to comment on the validity of Mr Ellenbogen's claim of wrongful dismissal. Although some adverse comments on the quality of his case have been passed by more qualified individuals, this is unimportant to the central issue. The central issue is that Mr Ellenbogen has never managed to have his case heard before a properly constituted court or tribunal. The situation is made worse because before 14 April 1985 the case could have been heard before the New South Wales Industrial Commission. After new legislation foreshadowed by the New South Wales Government is passed early next year, cases such as this-that is, cases brought before the Industrial Commission by individuals-will be heard again. Unfortunately for Mr Ellenbogen, the events that led to his grievance occurred in the period when access by individuals to the Industrial Commission was not possible.

In 1985 the New South Wales Labor Government passed an amendment to amend the Industrial Arbitration Act 1940, which removed the right of access of individuals to the Industrial Commission. From that time on only grievances supported by unions could be heard. The current New South Wales coalition government has had a policy of reinstating the right of access of individuals to this court. The New South Wales Government has a problem with this change. All parliaments are rightly cautious about retrospectivity in any aspect of legislation. I do not know what they are going to do about this one. Nor do I know how many cases would be likely to be heard if access to the court was made retrospective to 1985.

Mr Ellenbogen could have been given access to the Industrial Commission either with the support of the appropriate union-in this case the Federated Municipal and Shire Council Employees Union, which Mr Ellenbogen had not joined while employed by the Council-or at the discretion of the New South Wales Minister for Industrial Relations, Mr Fahey, who could have issued a writ of reference to allow this case to be heard. Both the union and the Minister declined to support Mr Ellenbogen's case, as was their right, I stress, and Mr Ellenbogen's attempt through the Equity Division of the Supreme Court of New South Wales to compel the union to represent his case and to compel the Minister to issue a writ of reference failed on both counts.

It might appear that this is solely a State matter in which the Federal Government has no proper interest. However, as in an increasing number of areas, a closer examination reveals that the Federal Government cannot escape the responsibility for ensuring that all Australian citizens will have open and equal access to the courts. The Federal Government has the obligation under the Australian Constitution to fulfil all the conditions of international treaties and agreements. One international agreement very relevant to this case is the United Nations International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights (ICCPR) which has been signed and ratified by Australia. The covenant was signed in 1972 and ratified in 1980 by Andrew Peacock as the Minister for Foreign Affairs, but with a number of reservations. In 1984, our current Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, Senator Gareth Evans, who was then the Attorney-General, withdrew most of the reservations, including the one relating to article 50. Article 50 states:
The provisions of the present Covenant shall extend to all parts of Federal states without any limitations or exceptions.
In a press release on Human Rights Day in 1984, Senator Evans said:
The ICCPR provides a charter of the civil and political rights of individuals within a country and places an obligation on the country to ensure protection of these rights.

He also spoke about the right to a fair trial and the right to equal protection before the law. In 1987, Australia submitted its second periodic report on the ICCPR to the Human Rights Committee of the United Nations. In section 342 on page 136 of the report the Federal Government claimed:
In all Australian jurisdictions, all persons are equal before courts and tribunals.

This assertion seems to me to be contradicted by the fact that Mr Ellenbogen has found it impossible to have his case heard before the proper judicial body. How the Federal Government is to correct this anomaly is not clear to me, but I would like to see some more tangible indication of effort than the polite evasions which have so far followed my representations on Mr Ellenbogen's behalf.

Recently I have had occasion to investigate the constitutional powers available to the Commonwealth and it is now even more apparent to me how ill we are served, in some important areas, by the constitutional division of powers and responsibilities between the States and the Federal Government. However, whether it is through the exercise of constitutional powers or through Commonwealth representations to the New South Wales Government, Mr Ellenbogen has the right to demand that the Federal Government-the government that claims that all its citizens have unhindered access to the courts-ensures that he has his day in court.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to continue remarks, which I had to cut short yesterday, relating to Senator Evans's statement on Australia's Regional Security.
—Senator Vallentine, having already spoken to the motion that the Senate do now adjourn, if you wish to speak a second time, you will need leave.
—I seek leave, Mr Deputy President.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the last couple of years we have seen a run-down of many of the world's long running conflicts because negotiation is now seen as more effective than continued fighting. We have recognised the value of the United Nations as a third party and members of the Australian Defence Force (ADF) were able to assist with the transition in Namibia after the settlement there, just as we have peacekeepers in Cyprus, the Middle East and South West Asia. The Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) has spoken of the possibility of members of the ADF serving in Cambodia if conditions permit. He made a proposal to the United Nations General Assembly this year for member states to establish emergency teams, which could be mobilised at short notice, along with another proposal to establish an international training centre for peacekeeping troops.

SPEECH.PARA: Spending an extra $100m on the working capital fund for peacekeeping is money better spent than $800m on two extra submarines for the Royal Australian Navy. I would propose using the difference to top up our overseas aid budget to promote real security in our region-not the false security generated by having eight submarines instead of six. Some of the money might go to Radio Australia as well, which, as the Minister correctly points out in paragraph 142, needs long overdue expenditure on the maintenance and upgrading of its capabilities. In fact, it is thoroughly depressing how the Minister almost has to apologise for the inadequate amounts of money available for Radio Australia, or indeed the entire overseas aid budget, yet pushes the line that the military should continue to get its share of the budget, currently 9.6 per cent, or just over $8 billion. I compare that with the 1.8 per cent for the foreign affairs budget.

Another useful project worthy of more funding is the diplomacy course now being run at the University of New South Wales. One has to ask how much effort we put into training our diplomats in negotiation skills or learning Asian languages. We value conflict resolution courses at the personal or local level but seem to ignore teaching those skills at the international level. With the constructive suggestions from the Minister, such as the ones I have referred to, Australia has played a useful role at the international level, but all this is spoiled by the continuation of the dual rhetoric.

We applaud events in Europe and the effective obsolescence of the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation (NATO) and the Warsaw Pact, yet we maintain the even more obsolete myth of ANZUS. We take positive initiatives on a chemical weapons ban after being thwarted in our attempts to promote a comprehensive test ban treaty, and again we are stymied by the United States. We could parallel the talks on land-based missiles by initiating discussion on naval arms control in the Pacific, but again the United States refuses to discuss this question. The Minister is keen on a settlement in Cambodia but he is trapped between all the aid agencies and humanitarian groups which tell him one thing and the vindictive men and women in the United States State Department who cannot forgive Vietnam and who still go along with China. In the meantime, the people of Cambodia continue to suffer so that the politicians can play their silly games.

Those of us in the Secure Australia project who have talked about Australia's new militarism have argued various points in relation to the militarisation of our region. We have criticised the unnecessary acquisition of new military equipment which we believe is largely irrelevant to the defence of Australia and which has had a disastrous effect on our balance of payments deficit. Even worse, it has prompted the Government to try to offset the costs of these imports by trying to double our military exports. That way military imports, which are running at over $1 billion a year, would be partly offset by exports doubling from $250m to $500m a year. That is the intention; I doubt whether we will ever reach that figure. We may actually be helping to create threats to our own security in the long run by trying to sell weapons in our region. We worry about a long-term possible threat from India but an Australian company in partnership with a Dutch company has got the contract to design India's big new naval base on its west coast, south of Goa. This is hardly sensible if we are really worried about India's militarisation. That contract, incidentally, was actively promoted by our Government.

The Minister's statement does nothing to allay concerns that the Indian Ocean region is not taken seriously, not given enough attention by Canberra based bureaucrats. The recent promotion of the Indian Ocean as a zone of peace by Mikhail Gorbachev is ignored in the statement. If the threat is going to come from a regional state, then it may well be that we will have supplied the weapons in the first place if we are serious about selling submarines and other items of military hardware to our neighbours. After all, our first military sales drive last December went round South East Asia, and HMAS Tobruk is being transformed into a floating arms bazaar to peddle more of our military hardware in south and south-west Asia after going to Gallipoli next April. Of course, we have just endured the indignity of AIDEX 89, the biggest arms bazaar in the southern hemisphere with some of the biggest rogues in the industry welcomed to Australia by our Government. It is contradictory that we check individual criminals before they are allowed to come to Australia, and with any luck keep them out, but we turn a blind eye to the corporate criminals.

Defence analysts agree that we enjoy friendly relations with almost all the countries in our region but go on to say that because the military capacities required for many types of lesser threats already exist in the region, there is a need for defence planning to take account of the fact that relations could deteriorate, intentions could change and in some circumstances this could happen quickly.

In a number of places in his statement the Minister asserts that there is no country that has or that will have in the foreseeable future the range of naval, air and logistic capabilities that would be needed to both project and sustain substantial conventional forces for major military action against Australia. He asserts that none of the recent military acquisitions by the Association of South East Asian Nations (ASEAN) countries represent a situation in which any ASEAN country has the capability, let alone the intention, to project that kind of major military action against Australia. Indeed in paragraph 70 we are reminded that Australia's defence budget is roughly equivalent to that of all the ASEAN countries combined. In paragraph 63 we are told that we cannot even think of a specific threat. That was evident during Kangaroo 89 when we had to invent an enemy, Kamaria, and the peace movement very imaginatively opened embassies to declare that Kamarians wanted a peaceful settlement and not a war. Unfortunately, such a move was totally lost on the warrior class.

In the Falklands-or Malvinas-war the United Kingdom found that Argentina was armed by the UK's NATO allies, so it is important to note that all these potential threats to the north are currently being armed or wooed by our Western allies as well as our own defence contractors: West Germany, the United Kingdom, the United States, Israel, France, Sweden, Spain, and South Korea, to name just a few. It really does not make sense. We would suggest that it is better to reduce the imports rather than increase our role as merchants of death, particularly bearing in mind the words of the former Minister for Foreign Affairs on the subject of the United Nations Special Session on Disarmament in New York in June 1988 and the warning on our wider development responsibilities given by the head of the World Bank speaking in Washington in September this year.

Further, we are disturbed by the change in rhetoric by the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) in the last two years, where he uses phrases like `regional management' and `a peacekeeping role in the south-west Pacific'. I would suggest that this is a resurrection of what the German Chancellor Bismarck referred to in 1883 as Australasia's Monroe Doctrine and that it is not peacekeeping which he is talking about, but interventionism. I am not saying that Australia should never intervene in any way, although I would draw the line at military intervention. Yet, under General `Kimbo's' management of the military in this country, we have had the Australian defence forces on alert for action four times-not once in defence of our own country, but twice in Fiji, and once in Vanuatu and Papua New Guinea.

I also query the talk about rescuing Australian citizens. They are often getting caught up in unrest somewhere or other and the ADF does not go rushing off to rescue them from places like Beijing or the Makati district in Manila. Qantas did a very adequate job in those situations. It was also interesting to hear the Minister's answer to Peter Thomson's question on the Australian Broadcasting Corporation's AM program this morning. He was asked about the use of the military to rescue Australian nationals. The Minister said, `Well, it's always a question of being sensitive to requests that may be made of us by friendly governments, just as the United States responded to assist the Aquino Administration'. As I read it, that was an admission of an interventionist policy-that the Australian Government would be prepared to consider intervention and if a request came from a neighbouring country we would have to look at it very sensitively and consider that as an option.

I was intrigued by Senator Evans's answer to my question today on the matter of military capability in our region, as he classified it. He effectively abandoned the security strategy, presumably carefully planned, after only 24 hours. The strategy announced yesterday by Senator Evans called for the use of many different policy instruments, including military capabilities, to `maintain a positive security and strategic environment in our own region'. Senator Evans's statement defined `our own region' as essentially the same as that called `the area of primary strategic interest' in the Government's 1987 Defence White Paper.

Questioning the Minister in the Senate today, I pointed out that the 1987 Defence Paper did not envisage significant use of military capacity in this vast area of some 20 per cent of the earth's surface. Rather, it envisaged Australia having a military capacity in a much smaller area-the area of primary defence interest of about 10 per cent of the globe. I asked the Minister to explain this glaring discrepancy between the Government's defence and foreign policy positions. In reply, Senator Evans admitted that it was not envisaged that Australia would have a military role in the larger area, thus abandoning after barely 24 hours the position set out in his elaborate policy paper. I welcome this retreat by the Government, but the contradictions show all too clearly that the Government has failed to set consistent priorities in the defence and foreign affairs areas. Its inability to set out a coherent position even in a prepared paper evidences a continuing struggle between militarism and commonsense in government policy. For once, there seems to have been a rare victory for commonsense, although I suspect it was a fluke as it was based on what must have been a careless error in the Minister's statement.

It is encouraging that the United States and the Soviet Union are going to reduce their military budgets. There was an inspiring article in the Canberra Times on 6 December which mentioned that pessimists were projecting a halving of United States military spending by the end of the century, from $US300 billion to $US160 billion. Why then do we have the ludicrous spectacle of Australia, which has no threat, actually increasing that proportion of the Budget which goes on the military? The logic, Senator Evans tells us, is that there might be a threat sometime in the distant future, even though we cannot see one now. I think that is a crazy approach to security. Suppose every country were to act in this way; that is, although no threat is in view there might be one day, so every country must arm against that unforeseeable threat. What sort of world would that look like? I venture to say that it would be alarmingly militaristic. We are now seeing the US, the Soviet Union and the Europeans saying that the existing real perceived threat is vanishing so they can cut their military expenditure. But not Australia-we are still a country in search of a threat.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise in response to the adjournment debate contribution by Senator Irina Dunn. I do so because, whatever facts she may have stated in her contribution, the essential one-that nothing had been done-is wrong. I do not necessarily blame Senator Irina Dunn for that. Perhaps her informant could have done her the courtesy of letting her know that because Mr John Ellenbogen knew two weeks ago that, as a result of representations by various members of the Senate, including Senator McLean, Senator Chaney and me, Mr John Fahey, the Minister for Industrial Relations and Employment and the Minister Assisting the Premier in New South Wales, had, in fact, determined to give Mr Ellenbogen his day in court. I was issued this morning-and this has particularly irritated me in respect of Senator Dunn's contribution-with a press release issued by Mr Fahey which states:

SPEECH.PARA: I am concerned that an increasing amount of time is being spent on a daily basis by persons of high standing in the community whose responsibilities are being distracted by a Mr John Ellenbogen in his quest to be heard in the Industrial Commission of New South Wales.
Mr Ellenbogen has demonstrated that he will continue to be relentless in targeting community groups and societies, the clergy, parliamentarians at both State and Federal level and on all sides.

I have therefore decided, on a without prejudice basis, to exercise the discretion vested in me under the provisions of the Industrial Arbitration Act 1940, by making a reference to the Commission in Court Session which is the ultimate industrial jurisdiction available in the State of New South Wales.

This decision has been taken after recent extensive consultation with Senator Fred Chaney and after consideration of a submission from Senator Paul McLean. It has been made without having regard to the merits or otherwise of the case and on the basis of the public interest at this point of time being the sole consideration not withstanding decisions in the past.
The Ministerial Reference will be lodged with the Industrial Registrar as soon as convenient. Mr Ellenbogen and other affected parties will be served by the Registrar in the normal course of events.
J. J. Fahey

I make the point that this is the first time this discretion has ever been exercised. It was refused to Mr Ellenbogen by the previous Labor Minister. I might say that Mr Ellenbogen has been assiduous in encouraging support for his position. It would have been courteous of him to have been equally assiduous to let the people who were working on his behalf know that he, in fact, had achieved his goal.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dunn Sen I.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-By way of a brief response to Senator Michael Baume's remarks, I wish to say that this is a remarkable coincidence. Indeed, I am one of those who have been assiduous in John Ellenbogen's cause and have had, in the last days, to separate the person from the principle, which is what we have to do in cases where an individual, as in Mr Ellenbogen's case, has become overtaken by his personal circumstances and has lost very much by his personal case. I wish to commend the decision taken by the New South Wales Minister for Industrial Relations and Employment, Mr John Fahey, in relation to John Ellenbogen. I understand the Minister may be concerned that he has set a precedent. But if he has, I remind him that it is in accordance with his own party's policy of giving individuals access to the Industrial Court. This is a policy with which I happen to agree. At least the Minister can now be consoled by the fact that the voluminous Ellenbogen file can be closed.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 27 September 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is fruit juice the only staple non-compounded food on which sales tax is imposed.
(2) Is it correct that luxury food items, such as smoked salmon and caviar, do not attract sales tax.
(3) What is the justification for such a glaring anomaly.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Most goods of a kind sold exclusively or principally, or put up for sale, as food for human consumption are exempt from sales tax. However, this exemption does not extend to snack foods, confectionery, ice-cream and biscuits, which are taxable at the 10 per cent rate. It also does not extend to beverages. The sales tax treatment of beverages is as follows:
plain milk, tea and coffee are exempt;

fruit and vegetable juice products containing 25 per cent or more Australian, New Zealand or Papua New Guinean juice, and flavoured milk drinks containing 90 per cent or more milk, are taxed at the 10 per cent rate (prior to the 1986-87 Budget, these beverages were exempt); and
most other beverages, including soft drinks, those fruit and vegetable juice products and flavoured milk drinks not taxed at 10 per cent, and alcoholic beverages are taxed at the 20 per cent rate.
(2) As noted above, most foodstuffs for human consumption are exempt from sales tax. This exemption extends to smoked salmon and caviar.

(3) Beverages are taxed at a variety of sales tax rates. The Government's decision in the 1986-87 Budget to tax previously exempt fruit juice products at the 10 per cent rate was designed to reduce anomalies associated with the sales tax treatment of non-alcoholic beverages.

Imposing sales tax on `luxury' food items such as smoked salmon and caviar would lead to major distortions, anomalies and administrative difficulties. Classifying some foodstuffs as luxuries would be extremely arbitrary; items that are considered to be luxuries in some cultures may not be in others. Further, distortions would inevitably arise-there would not appear to be any reason to impose sales tax on smoked salmon but not on fresh salmon, or oysters, for example. In effect, there is no clear distinction between luxury and other food items which could enable them to be distinguished for the purposes of applying sales tax.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health, upon notice, on 31 October 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister aware that an article in the 3 March 1989 edition of the North American Journal of Dermatological and Surgical Oncology states that the argon laser treatment of port-wine stain haemangiomas found on thin skin, such as the skin of the lateral neck and upper lip, has the major disadvantage for the patient in some 87 per cent of cases of the development of hypertrophic scarring, whereas the argon-pumped tunable dye laser permits successful treatment of haemangiomas on these areas, and is therefore particularly appropriate for treatment of the face and neck, and the treatment of young children.

(2) How many flash-lamp pumped dye laser, argon laser, argon dye laser and copper vapour laser machines are there currently in Australia and where are they located (private and public clinics and hospitals).

(3) In the treatment of port-wine stain haemangiomas; (a) what is the Medicare rebate for 15 minute, 30 minute, 45 minute and 60 minute sessions for treatment with the: (i) argon laser machine, (ii) argon dye laser machine, (iii) flash-lamp pumped dye laser machine, and (iv) copper vapour laser machine; and (b) what is the private health fund rebate for each of the above treatments.
(4) What is the range of charges by doctors for 15 minute, 30 minute, 45 minute and 60 minute sessions of treatment by each of the 4 lasers.

(5) What would be the cost to a clinic or hospital of treating a patient with each type of laser equipment for 15 minute, 30 minute, 45 minute and 60 minute sessions, taking into consideration, where appropriate: (a) capital purchase costs; (b) electricity; (c) transformer; (d) water chiller; (e) maintenance costs; (f) laser consumables such as dye, cot, filters and methanol; (g) salary of operator; (h) anaesthetic (local and general); and (i) other relevant costs.
(6) Which State/Territory Departments of Health currently pay the interstate travel costs of patients to enable them to receive laser treatment for port-wine stain haemangiomas.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Community Services and Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) No. However, the Medicare Benefits Advisory Committee, in providing advice to the Minister for Community Services and Health, has considered other studies from clinical literature concerning the efficacy of flash-lamp pumped tunable dye lasers in the treatment of haemangiomas of the skin.

(2) Medicare statistics do not specify the location at which services are rendered. Accordingly, it is not possible to identify from Medicare data the number or type of laser machines currently in Australia or their location.

(3) (a) (i)-(iv) there is no differentiation between the rebates for services rendered using the 4 different machines listed providing the light produced by the laser is within a wavelength of 510-600 nanometres. Medicare rebates for the laser treatment of port-wine haemangiomas are:
Laser treatment of port wine stains-at least 30 mins. duration ...
Laser treatment of port wine stains-at least 60 mins. duration ...
There is no specific rebate payable for a 45 minute session of treatment. The rebates for this length of treatment are the same as those for Item 9451 above.

(b) The private health fund rebate for these treatments is limited to services provided to hospital in-patients. The funds are required, under their basic table as defined in the National Health Act, to pay the difference between the Medicare benefits schedule fee and the Medicare rebate for in-patient services provided in a hospital or day hospital facility. The private health fund benefits for items 9451 and 9452 are therefore $19.00 and $24.00 respectively.
(4) The information is not available in the form sought. However, for patient-billed services processed in the June quarter 1989, the average fee charged for each item was as follows:
It is not possible to provide this information for laser therapy services of 15 minutes duration, because such services are payable under surgery consultation items.
(5) and (6) The information sought is not available in the Department of Community Services and Health.
